The minigames, some are very interesting, there's one where it's needed to invest my time a lot just to recruit a single character. The theater, absolutely hilarious. 

Actually what I found interesting is that the grinding is not that burdensome (after unlocking the trials under the base) and I even had excess money after leveling up all the characters, weapons, and equip them with decent runes and equipment. About the translation or should I say localization, I quite agree that some don't match with the original especially the jokes and how the some characters called each other. From the world building I guess there would be a possibility for continuation, and I can't wait for that :)

Eiyuden Chronicles is too retro and old school for me to recommend. The world map is bare and just an empty series of settings to interconnect the story hubs. There are no secrets to discover as all the locations are marked on the map. The MP system is too restrictive that MP can only be spent during boss fights. There is no way to stock up on MP recovery items for your adventures into dungeons. Some dugeons are creative and have puzzles with interesting mechanics, but others are bare hallways with loot or resources nodes at the dead ends.

I want to like the game but it ended up not being for me. I feel like games have evovled since the era this game was meant for. If this game released during the playstation 1 or 2 era, this would have been amazing for the time.

とにかくキャラの性能差が酷い。
鎧を装備できるかどうかでダメージ差が大きくなりHPが低くて鎧を装備できないキャラは雑魚の攻撃でも2発で落ちる。
攻撃魔法のMPの消費が高いわりに威力が低いので中盤くらいまで魔法キャラは微妙。
後半になると強力な魔法が使えるようになるが高い火力を出せるキャラとそのキャラの半分もダメージが出ないキャラがいて火力差がある。
キャラが多くても強いキャラが限られてるため好きなキャラを使って攻略するプレイには不向きと感じた。
幻想水滸伝の思い出補正ありでプレイしたのでシナリオや世界観は楽しめたけど戦闘だけは苦痛でした。

作为幻想水浒传的精神续作，百英雄传在JPRG模式上带来了经典传承，画面很吸引人，HD-2D风格，像素的人物搭配上3D的场景，有一种非常不错的感觉。
如同游戏名一样，游戏中可以招募上百位英雄同伴，每位英雄均有各自的故事，玩家需要完成任务，或观看其剧情，进行互动来邀请其入队，每位英雄都有不同的技能与特色。收集起来十分的爽，成就感拉满，城建系统也能与各位英雄进行联动，增强了收集角色的动力。经验追赶机制也非常棒，能够让低级同伴获得额外经验快速提升等级，直到与队伍等级持平，让玩家能体验更多的阵容组合。
回合制战斗的玩法，可以上阵6位英雄角色，分为先锋与后卫，内容丰富。作为标配，攻击分为物理与魔法两大类，物理攻击分为斩击、突刺、钝击、格斗、飞击等类型，有不同的附加效果，魔法攻击分为火水风土光暗六大类，属性之间有相互克制，在应对不同敌人时往往需要根据敌人机制，选取合适的攻击方式。战斗中机制多样，掩护、友谊连击，BOSS战时还有许多场地效果，可以使用各种机巧，为玩家带来了新奇的体验，玩起来不会腻。
迷宫探索也很有趣，有经典JRPG的味道，多种多样机关谜题与藏在各处的宝箱，极大的增强了探索欲。游戏内还提供了自动战斗，可以预先设定每个人物的攻击风格，按照自己的喜好选取进攻方式，在战斗中可以一建操作，快速战斗，也算是解放双手了，尤其是在反复刷怪时，大大减轻了控制6个人物所需的复杂操作，节省了时间。
个人玩下来感觉也有许多不足之处，首先不能随地存档，导致不能及时退出游戏，还要去找存档点。暗雷遇怪加上触发战斗的音效，也挺拖节奏的，跑图时还会吓到自己。迷宫中部分场景会遮挡视线，奇怪的键位也不能修改，操作有点难受。
游戏比较慢热，前面几小时可能体验不会很好，很多玩法和功能需要慢慢解锁，耐心玩下来，闪光点不断显现，游戏中内置了丰富的小游戏，玩起来也会有不同的乐趣，推荐给喜欢JRPG的玩家。

Zu meiner absoluten Schande, sind die Suikoden-Spiele damals leider vollkommen an mir vorbei gegangen.
Das Positive ist, dass ich diese Art Spiel nun so mit jungfräulichen Augen betrachten und vor allem entdecken kann. Und ich muss sagen, ich habe mich verliebt! Erstmal zum Offensichtlichsten: Die Grafik bzw. der Stil ist natürlich immer Geschmackssache, ich persönlich finde ihn wunderschön. Gefällt mir sogar noch besser als in dem Star Ocean Remake. Die Charaktere sind nochmal deutlich detaillierter und die Umgebungen sind schön farbenfroh und ebenfalls detailreich. Egal wo man ist, es gibt immer ein paar Leutchen, die alles beleben, ob in einer Stadt oder nur in einem Tor, welches als Übergang in ein anderes Gebiet dient. Kurzum, das bloße Aussehen hat mich persönlich schon verzaubert. 

Der Soundtrack tut zu allem sein Übriges. Ich erwische mich oft dabei, wie ich das Battle-Theme vor mich hin pfeife, der Track recht weit am Anfang auf der Brücke hat mir pure Gänsehaut beschert. Auch die Sounds der Attacken und Angriffe sind gut gelungen und schön wuchtig.

Nun zu einem sehr...unbeliebten Punkt: Die Zufallskämpfe. Ich persönlich bin mit der ersten Pokemongeneration und Final Fantasy groß geworden, von daher bin ich diese mehr als gewohnt. Ja,es gibt momente nach langem Spielen, wo sie auch mich nerven und ich irgendwann mal denke "Och nö"
Aber in Eiyuden Chronicles kommt man eigentlich immer ein gutes Stück vorwärts, sie starten nie, wenn man nur 2 Schritte läuft. In Pokemon z.B. konnte man damals manchma riesige Wiesen durchlaufen ohne einen einzigen Counter, manchmal kam man keine 3 Schritte ohne einen. Hier finde ich das deutlich dezenter, manchmal ahnt man schon, wann der nächste Feind um die Ecke biegt. Natürlich wäre es schön, wenn man die Gegner vorab sehen könnte und nach Bedarf auch umgehen, aber mir persönlich verderben sie in dem Spiel absolut nicht den Spaß.

Der Kampf selber fühlt sich auch anders an, als in den alten klassischen JRPG's. Anfangs kann man nur einmal einen mächtigen Zauber wirken und schon sind die MP dahin, die Fähigkeiten, welche man zur Auswahl hat, halten sich stark in Grenzen und ja, dadurch drückt man meist einfach nur den "Auto"-Button. Aber man wird ja auch stärker, bekommt immer mehr MP und lernt auch neue Attacken und Fähigkeiten dazu. Die Bosskämpfe sind da natürlich das absolute Highlight und verdammt spaßig.

Was ich ebenfalls sehr schön finde, ist, wenn man gerade mal keine Lust hat eine Hauptquest abzugeben und sich denkt "Hmm, in dem Dorf war ich schon länger nicht, vielleicht wartet ja da jetzt ein neuer Held darauf, rekrutiert zu werden." und  das dann auch tatsächlich der Fall ist. Sich umzuschauen wird immer belohnt, zumindest in Städten und Dungeons. Die Oberwelt-Karte dient leider anscheinend wirklich nur dem Zweck, von A nach B zu kommen.

Von den ganzen Mini-Spielen kann ich auch nur schwärmen. So viel zu sammeln und Abwechslung, vom Basen-Aufbau ganz zu schweigen.

Angefangen habe ich das Spiel auf der PS4, leider packt die alte Lady dieses Spiel nicht sehr gut. Ständige Ladezeiten (manchmal bis zu 10 Sekunden), wenn ich die Karte geschlossen habe, musste ich 1 bis 2 Sekunden warten bis ich wieder los laufen durfte und natürlich keine 60 fps. Also nicht sehr gut optimiert.
Auf dem PC jetzt allerdings von all den "Sorgen" keine Spur mehr. Es läuft butterweich, der Ladebildschirm hat keine Chance aufzuploppen und die Hacker im Menü/Karte sind ebenfalls weg.

Was ich persönlich nicht verstehen kann, ist der Trubel um die Übersetzung. Ich spiele mit deutschen Texten und englischen Sprechern. Ja, ich habe auch schon ein paar Fehler in den Texten entdeckt, allerdings hat meist nur ein Buchstabe gefehlt oder einer war zu viel, aber es war nie so schlimm, dass man nichts verstanden hat. Auch passt der gesprochene Text meist super zur Übersetzung. Nicht wie damals bei FFX z.B.
Allerdings weiß ich da nicht, wie die Übersetzung vom japanischen ins englische ist. Vielleicht ist ja gerade die so schlimm.

Es gibt allerdings eine einzige Sache, die mich wirklich nervt. Man kann die Rotierung der Mini-Map nicht abstellen. ARGH!
Darüber kann ich aber locker hinweg sehen.

Alles in allem macht mir das Spiel verdammt viel Spaß und ich freue mich schon darauf, noch so vieles zu entdecken, zu sammeln und zu bekämpfen. Und das Remake von Suikoden I&II ist dank dem Spiel auch gleich auf meiner Wunschliste gelandet.

So, das waren meine paar Gedanken zu dem Spiel, viel Spaß allen Mitzockern =)

Nostalgic

Where to begin with this - it's really trying too hard to tap into nostalgia without simply making a good game. The game is simultaneously overly easy but the combat mechanics don't matter. Random enemies have shields, but there isn't a really fleshed out mechanic where this matters. It has over 100 characters but does little to give you reasons to care about any of them. This is the perfect type of game to watch movies to and hit auto battle, because you aren't going to die anyway and there is nothing to the combat.

And the combat, it's brutal because the animations have inherent delays or are overly long. Suikoden was brisk and combat could be quite fast, even if it wasn't that deep. If I had to compare something recent that is in the ballpark, Octopath Traveler 2 is a vastly better game in every way - story telling, combat, world building.

I am actually a huge fan of the PS1 Suikoden's so this should've been an easy sell. It simply isn't a good game.

I keep seeing complaints about the English localization and something about politics. I'm close to the end of the game (have been focusing more on side content), but the alleged term used I haven't seen yet though it seems to have caused a lot of pearl clutching. Story-wise, it's very on brand with how Suikoden I and II were on politics to the point I wonder if this is being treated as a remake of sorts on their end so they can effectively bring the IP in-house.

edit: finished the game. Never saw the dialog in question, though I don't use necromancer girl (from a very quick play of her, seems she's best when allowed to go last and can wipe trash off the screen. Leene can do that but at the beginning of combat) in my party so if deeply offended, don't use her.

I think the only things in the dialog that I've seen that I was a bit eh about:
1) a character calling a villain a farthead or something
2) a character in the party seems very different from how they're portrayed in Rising (in fact, I feel like the characters and voice acting were better in Rising for the characters that were there. I don't care one way or the other about the new sprites for the affected characters).

Alright, that out of the way. The game has been quite fun and feels like the sequel that Suikoden I and II deserved. There's so much about the game that is great that honestly, I don't even know where to highlight. Expanding the roster is fun, finding which characters work best for me is also fun... just the usual Suikoden loop is well done. I have no idea why, but the Eggfoot or whatever racing/breeding minigame is kind of enjoyable (not enough to be its own game, but fun here and there).

As far as the negatives:

1) I find the war mechanic to be a bit suspect as once you have the upper hand, you can basically chase the unit(s) until they're dead and they can't retreat to a different direction to get away from you or anything, they just freeze as you charge on them. 
2) The beyblade minigame doesn't feel incredibly fleshed out as knowing where to look for beyblade opponents is a pain. They all look like regular civilians and outside of some of the character quest stuff, they don't have the arena thing sitting in front of them to let you know that's what they're for. Same with the card game really. Not deal breakers, but could be better.
3) I don't think I realized it at the time of the crowdfunding campaign, but the items in game you can tell were things to be bought in the higher tiers of the kickstarter are kind of jarring. Wish there were a setting to strip them out and replace them with things that seem to be in universe, but it is what it is.
4) The building UI is a pain as soon as it starts getting into Castle levels 2+. I thought it was a cool "hey, not a listview" thing when I initially saw it, but later on when most of the nodes are off screen, you have to move cursor around a lot to find nodes that need to be done which gets to be a chore above level 2.

エンディングと英雄の試練エンドレスも一通りクリア。
幻想水滸伝2の精神的リメイク。
幻想水滸伝2を名作と思う人は遊んで損はなし。
紋章→レンズと頭に入れればそのまま遊べます。

良いところ
語りすぎないながらも納得感のあるシナリオ。
キャラクターが魅力的に描かれて使ってみたくなる。
どの仲間を連れてイベントを進めても一言コメントのような差分がそれぞれに用意されている。
劇場に関してはフルボイスで今の時代にやるあたり、ちょっと頭がおかしくてすばらしい。
アイテムドロップ率の上昇アイテムがほぼ確定レベルでアイテム集めが爽快。
最大強化した後の挑戦コンテンツとしての英雄の試練がある。

悪いところ
5/1現在、ラムを仲間にできないのとエンカウント率のバグは修正が入ったようだがちょくちょくバグっぽい挙動は残る。ある日リャンが起こしに来るところレイナが来てリャンのセリフを喋ったのはビビった。
FPS制限は機能しておらず、なんらかの別の方法で対処がおすすめ。
メニュー周りのUI。ステータスを確認したいのにアイテム欄が開き、そこから横にスクロールを何回かしないとステータスにたどり着けない。しかも微妙な読み込み操作不可時間が間に挟まるという不快感。
ステータスを見て英雄コンボの相手がわかるようになっている開示情報であるなら、
どうせなら仲間を編成する場面でも誰と誰を組み合わせるかでどのコンボが使えるかを確認できるようにしてほしかった。
ミニゲームの数は多いが、それぞれに戦略性はあまりなくて時間をかけるかパターン総当りかゴリ押しみたいなノリで初見は新鮮味があるが慣れると作業感が強い。
英雄コンボはごく一部の有用なものを除いて、各自で同SPを消費した場合のほうが効果が高く演出を見る以外に使い道がないものがほとんど。sp消費なしか軽減、効果の上方修正がほしかった。

感想
とても楽しく最後までプレイしました。
良いところも悪いところも多々ある作品ですが、期待には応えてくれた作品だと思います。
惜しむらくは、108星の石版や真なる紋章のようなワクワクする外連味がもっと欲しかったかなと。
真なる紋章と原初のレンズだとやっぱり前者のほうがかっこよさがどうしても。

村山氏のシナリオで続編が遊べないことは大変悔やまれますが、この百英雄伝とても楽しませていただきました。
この作品を世に出してくださってありがとうございます。御冥福をお祈りいします。

I am very disappointed I waited 1.5 years for this game for it to come out and be very, very, very mediocre.  This game does nothing new nor exciting for the genre.  The combat leaves so much to be desired that it just becomes stale and disconnecting very fast.  Magic is also so underwhelming and relies on so much resources that you're just better off just sticking with physical characters to make exploration last.  It's also sad that out of the 120 characters, only a dozen or so of them are truly viable for combat while the others just aren't usable because of their pathetically comparatively low or unbalanced stats.  And the story?  Super tropey and dumbly predictable.  It's very safe to say that it's nothing you haven't experienced before.

All in all, I was hoping for an absolute epic of a tale.  At least that's what the trailer made me feel I was going to experience.  Instead, I was given a very standard cast of characters with the most traditional of 'evil empire vs other nations' story that does nothing to keep me absorbed and intrigued enough to keep me going.  It's a very standard and very introductory JRPG to those who have never ventured into the genre but for those of us who consider ourselves veterans, we may have to settle for simply sensing the smallest bit of nostalgia, if nothing else.

素人の幻想水滸伝Ⅱのファンが作ったゲーム

そんな印象です。全ての要素を見渡しても玄人なのは音楽とキャラデザのみ。
それ以外全てが酷いですが、突出して酷いものが3点

①ボイス関連
各声優の力量の差も目立ちますが、何より各ボイスの収録環境、音質がバラバラなので
シングルRPGでボイスチャットでもやってるかのような新体験が出来ます。
当然音量もバラバラです。

②シナリオ演出
大まかなプロットは悪くないです。ですがほぼ全場面シナリオ演出があまりにも酷い
（というかテキトー？）
ティザーにも出てくるノアとセイの一騎打ちですが、ファンは幻水2ラストの主人公と
ジョウイの名シーンを期待したでしょう。
実際はアレの5億分の1の感動・感傷すらありません。演出・導線の悪さが積み重なり、
序盤の大一番のこのシーンですらビックリするほど薄っぺらくてチープなシーンに
なってしまっています。
台詞回しなどもあまりに酷く、仲間勧誘の「これからよろしく」等は使い回しな為、
非常に淡泊かつ無機質。「幻想水滸伝２」好きの学生が限られた時間の中で再解釈し、
学芸会で劇をやりましたという印象。
そういえばまた別の話ですが主人公ノアの主力ルーンのクレイジーな掛け声は
何故あれでOK出してしまったんですかね？

③戦闘システム
正直これが一番酷いです。「バランス」などという言葉は全く考慮されておらず、
戦闘がビックリする程退屈です。
まず、MP消費に対する魔法の効果の薄さ。上位レンズを使っても
MP消費と威力・回復量が全く見合っておらず、回復は道具、威力に関しては
魔法職は外してマッチョなキャラを持ってくる方が効率的です。
次に敵モンスター攻撃のダメージ量の高さと味方キャラのHPの低さ。
終盤までずっと敵の攻撃が痛いです。
適正レベルにしようが防具揃えようが全く変わりません。
防御力高いキャラを編成しないと何一つ改善されません。
そして、取得経験値制御が極めつけです。
ダンジョンの指定レベルより高いレベルになると経験値は下がり、
低いほど経験値が数十倍にもなります。
つまり敵が強いからレベルを上げて～みたいな事はほぼ出来ません。
逆に3～４回戦闘すれば適正レベルまですぐ上がります。意味あるんですかねこの戦闘。

以上の点を総合して出てくる結論が
通常攻撃が強く、HPと防御が高い「強いキャラを使ってください」という事です。
キャラによってこの格差があまりに酷く使えないキャラは本当に使えません。
逆に使えるキャラって10人もいないのでは？
100人以上居てこの個性の出せなさ・作れなさは飽きれ果てます。

戦闘周りについてはテストしていない/テスターを雇っていないのは明らかなので
1点も点数あげられませんね。
UI、バッカーの英語表記、等まだまだ不満点ありますがキリがないので
他の方のレビューを参考に。
音楽に関しては拠点のBGMを始め、耳に残る/雰囲気を形作る、
良いメロディが本当に多いです。正直勿体ない。

I enjoyed it overall. The story was a little basic, but I enjoyed the large cast of characters. A lot of the dialogue was fun and the amount of voice acting was impressive. The music was consistently great.

The traditional JRPG battle system was fine. Lots of characters have unique skills, which makes experimenting with new parties fun. I found the war and duel systems pretty simple and uninteresting. Also, both weren't used very often.

My biggest gripe is the mini games. Fishing is boring, but exactly what you'd expect. The racing (they're actually time trials) is pedestrian, but has a minigame breaking bug that reverses the controls. Beyblade is awful (and poorly explained). The card game is a pile of RNG. The egg creature raising/racing is a lot of staring at your screen waiting. Cooking contests are surprisingly RNG and incredibly slow. This wouldn't be awful if characters weren't locked behind a long stretch of beyblade and cooking. On the upside, the racing and card game characters only require a couple a pop. However, I like achievement hunting and some are brutal for the mini games. Like beating every one of the 120 characters at cards.

There is a fun theater mini game where you can cast any character in any role and they have unique and voiced dialogue. Someone poured effort into that part.

Finally, ran great on my steam deck.

I'll be succinct: This game is a design abomination which wishes it were Suikoden 1/2 while being worse than Suikoden 2 in every single way. The plot is poorly-paced and inferior to Suikoden 2, the characters are (somehow) more one-dimensional than Suikoden 2, half the main cast is formed from "expies" of Suikoden 2 and the story is on a Saturday-morning-cartoon level and involves a crazy amount of hand-waving details. Most of the characters have no concept of personal boundaries and not-Nanami is one of the most frustratingly written and disagreeable characters I have had the misfortune of seeing in a video game.

Your hero is presented as a "meddling do-gooder", which in effect means you advance the plot by randomly helping every flavour-of-the-week generic Tom, Dick and Harry you run across regardless of your actual duties or priorities (let's be real,  you don't have any because the writing is godawful) and much of the content is shoved into the game not because it has a reason to exist, but because "it was there in Suikoden 1-3 and kickstarter backers are hungry for nostalgia". 

To make matters worse, game balance in this JRPG is an afterthought. The MP system is amazingly badly thought out, spells are overcosted and the main way of restoring MP is through items which don't stack well and clutter your inventory while barely being enough to restore half the cost of a single spell in lategame. To make things worse, any spell which does damage is more or less useless because you would probably achieve better damage results from attacking or using skills. There are just so many things wrong with this battle system that it's difficult to enumerate them, such as the vast majority of enemies blithely ignoring your front line and attacking your back row, party member stats being badly balanced to the point where some characters are nigh-unusable, and the amazingly limited customisation which comes from having only one interesting accessory slot - but the crux of the matter is that I just don't find battles fun nor interesting at all.

To its benefit, the music is quite good and the character art is competent, but that doesn't make up for everything else. If you've never played Suikoden 1 or 2 before, I highly suggest you wait for the remaster of that to be released on Steam and avoid this egregious abomination.

Eiyuden Chronicle: Hundred Heroes is a brand new JRPG developed by Rabbit & Bear Studios, a team led by Yoshitaka Murayama (as well others) who previously created the iconic [i]Suikoden[/i] series published by Konami. For this reason, the game can be considered as the spiritual successor of [i]Suikoden[/i]. It’s worth mentioning that Hundred Heroes already has an action RPG ([i]Eiyuden Chronicles: Rising[/i]) that acts as its prequel and is set in the same world, so give it a look if you want to enjoy this new series from the beginning.

In Hundred Heroes you play as Nowa, a young fighter who joins the Eltisweiss Watch, a mercenary group that tries to maintain peace. During a joint expedition with the Galdean Empire, they discover an ancient and powerful artifact called the Primal Lens, which becomes the spark for war and causes the Empire to start the invasion of Eltisweiss. Thanks to his valorous actions, Nowa is soon promoted to leader of the resistance. His main goal is to build an army by hiring new recruits, but the story doesn’t entirely focus on him. He is the classic muted protagonist that is defined by the player’s choices, but ends up being overshadowed by the huge cast of characters that surrounds him. There are over 100 characters to be recruited (including the missable ones) which is a really impressive number and they are fully voiced in both English and Japanese, except for a few non-important dialogues. While the story premise of a powerful artifact causing a full-scale war is nothing original, it is masterfully narrated through the multiple characters’ points of view. If you love games filled with war themes, political intrigue, magic and plot twists, you certainly won’t be disappointed. There are of course some similarities with the Suikoden series, so you might feel some deja-vu moments.
 
The combat is turn-based and you can have up to six members in your party, plus one more support character who can only use passive skills and bonuses. During battles you are able to see the order of actions for both your party and enemies, so you can use it at your advantage by focusing your attacks on a specific enemy before his turn. Characters have an SP bar which regenerates over time and is used to perform skills, but also a MP bar which is used for spells and must be restored by using items. Positioning is also important in battles because some skills only have a limited range, so you need to check your party members’ types of attacks. Additionally, characters who have a special bond can perform a powerful attack together, which encourages you to try different characters. Since there are over 100 characters in the game (though not all of them can fight), it’s impossible to use them all and you will likely find your favorite ones. The experience points are scaled for every character, so even those who have been used less and have a lower level will quickly catch up to the party’s level. Combat also includes minor quality-of-life features such as an Auto-battle option, which proves to be useful when you need to grind a bit through regular battles that no longer require your input. If you lose a battle, you also have the option to rematch or resume from the last save point, which is a time saver. Boss fights are quite intense and require tactics that can change in the middle of the battle, encouraging you to use the battlefield at your own advantage (such as hiding behind an object to protect yourself from a powerful enemy attack). There are also multiple Army Battles in Eiyuden Chronicles. These are essentially turn-based war battles that play like a strategy game, where you form legions (each led by one of your characters) to fight against the Empire’s ones. Army Battles are probably the weakest aspect of the game because they are almost entirely scripted and most of the time you feel like a spectator who has not enough control over the battle. 

Graphically speaking, the game makes a good use of the depth of field to mix ultra-defined and colorful environments with beautiful pixelated characters. The art style is great and each character has a very unique design. The performance on PC is perfect and I didn’t encounter any bug or glitch. In terms of music and sound design, Hundred Heroes is also impressive. As mentioned earlier, all characters are voiced in English and Japanese, and the game features some fantastic soundtracks as well, especially the battle theme.

[h1]Verdict: 8/10[/h1]
Eiyuden Chronicles: Hundred Heroes offers a genuine old-school experience through gorgeous, modern graphics. The story is always engaging and it’s fun to explore the world looking for new characters to recruit into your army. It’s really sad to think that this is the final work of Yoshitaka Murayama, who passed away earlier this year, but I’m sure many players will treasure the game because it’s a love letter to classic JRPGs and a worthy successor to [i]Suikoden[/i].

Eiyuden Chronicles is an excellent experience, especially for people who enjoyed the Suikoden series.  The game is filled with situations that are similar to what you would have experienced in the Suikoden series, especially Suikoden 1 and Suikoden 2.  

There are various bugs reported for the game, especially for the swich version, but the developers have stated they are committed to fix these with future patches, and their comments are clearly very earnest.  One thing to consider is that the pillar of this project, Yoshitaka Murayama, passed away in February.  He was heavily involved with the bug check of this game which likely impacted the end result.

However, the overall game is joyous to play and definitely scratches the "Suikoden itch" that many Suikoden fans would have.  It is basically a must-buy for fans of Suikoden.

Eiyuden Chronicle: Hundred Heroes is the perfect successor not only to Suikoden, but to everything the JRPG fan loves from ages past. This is a game I have waited so long to witness and explore and in the 12 hours I've put in so far, it's been everything I hoped for.

Eiyden Chronicle has brought the world of Allraan to life through some beautiful 2D and 3D art styles that are strong reminders of the classics brought into the new age. The addition of brilliant voice acting brings the characters and personalities to life allowing for a deeper connection to those around you and narrative.

The mix of play style between turn based team combat, the grid based War system and duelling all keep you on your toes for resolving conflicts, even the boss battles throw in Gimmicks to stop the battles feeling like nothing but a button mash. The War system has always been something I enjoyed from Suikoden, letting your characters take the lead into an all out battle with your army rather than the simple turned based fight.

One of my favourite aspects of Suikoden was having a player base to look after and a home for your recruits, I won't spoil the details, but for me it always made the narrative so much stronger in building up bonds with your characters and really helped show they were more than just fighters for your party.

Overall, as a huge fan of the classic JRPG games. I can say that this will go down as one of the classics itself for both those who grew up with games like Suikoden and Vandal Hearts to those who are stepping in for the first time. This might be a successor, but it's leaving it's own mark on the genre.

The story is serviceable but will not blow you away. The graphic is a perfect blend of old school sprite with 3D enemies and environment a la HD 2D. The music while decent doesn't feel overly unique or memorable such as Suikoden II, and I liked Motoi Sakuraba's work in Star Ocean II more. Let's deal with the elephant in the room: The localization.
It really is very bad. Whoever did it should be ashamed of themselves; and the voice acting is absolutelly horrendous. It's like someone told the voice actors to speak as if they were in some zany morning kids anime. My advice if you don't speak japanses, is to play with english subs and japanese voices. At least then you get the -tone- of the voice actor, and can try to read the text in that tone to help you out. It's not always possible, such as that time the person whose daughter's life is on the line, decides to call the one threatening his daughter "farthead". It's jarring, it's utter nonsense, but these truly jarring moments, are few and far between.

Okay, with that out of the way; here are some MORE criticisms:
[list]
[*] The main character feels like he just wandered into the plot and decided to stay. He has next to no motivation, a very poorly connected backstory and overall is very flat. Sadly not much you can do about that.
[*] There are too many playable characters, that sadly just simply do not work in the game. They are either too weak, or have stats in all the wrong places, making them not just a little weaker, but full-on unplayable. Sure, they can be carried in a strong party, but if you make your party out of these characters, they cannot beat the random enemies at their level.
[*] The battle plan system is fundamentally just not working. This might get fixed in the future, but sadly, as it is, it's just in your way.
[*] MP costs are far too high for what you get. Magic hits like a wet noodle and you are limited to a few casts per rest, which means you won't be using it much at all. It does not feel like the magic stat is currently, correctly, or at all, affecting Rune magic damage output; only basic attack output (if the character has a magical basic attack, which many don't)[/list]

So why am i giving it a recommended? Well... because it's a lot of fun! I love gathering companions like they are pokemon, i love testing out zany party combinations that don't really work well, but is fun to watch. I love the old school jrpg feel, and I like the often over-dramatic storytelling. I love that your enemy is called Mighty Dux.
This certainly feels like a Suikoden game, and while it struggles to live up to those; it does do some things better. Voice acting is a great addition (again, avoid the english voice acting). It gives a touch of flair to the characters that were missing in the past.
The greatest thing it does though, is it gives you 3 "attendant" slots in your party. These slots can be filled with "story-critical" characters that you may not want to use in your active party. This was one of my main gripes with the old games. So often you are forced to bring certain characters on certain quests, and you have little control over your party; this is not a thing in Eiyuden. You can always bring whoever you want! You don't even have to use the main character!

If you like Suikoden, you'll like this. If you loved Suikoden, you may be a little disappointed in places, but should still like this. The translation is fine for the vast majority of the game, just do not use the english voice acting, my goodness...

Lemme start off by saying that if Steam provided a neutral option for reviews I'd be using that. The game is fun enough so I'm gonna go positive but it's not without its flaws.

[h3]The Good[/h3]

[b]The combat.[/b] It's nothing revolutionary but it flows nicely, you got a vast array of options, there's over 60 characters you can field so you can customize your team to great extend and the addition of the SP system really alleviates one of the major issue that made combat boring in a lot of other jRPGs.
[b]The music[/b]. I rarely pay attention to ambient music or battle scores in the majority of games I play but in this case the game managed to capture my attention on several occasions outside of big moments. They really work with the locations and greatly enhance the experience and tone of a place/moment.
[b]The town management.[/b] It's a simple enough system that feels rewarding and is mostly self contained. Seeing your HQ grow and develop isn't anything new to the Suikoden franchise that this game is emulating but the way it was done here felt nice.
[b]The minigames.[/b] There's a vast array of them and you can absolutely lose days to them. I wasn't a fan of all of them and not everything is developed equally(like beigoma and food wars having an extensive line of battles you need to do to recruit some people at the end of it while the card game is somewhat just there etc) but there are at least some that are gonna appeal to everyone's taste.


[h3]The Neutral[/h3]

[b]The story.[/b] It's just a mediocre cliche jrpg power of friendship thing. It feels undercooked, you often get told instead of shown, the ending feels incredibly rushed with the major antagonists just don't have any depth to them. They just appear, hint or throw some exposition about their motives/history/role and then just fizzle out. There's even an entire faction that's been present from early in the game we barely get any info on even though it seems like a major player. I'm guessing they're saving that faction as a focus for a future title but it just feels like their role was supposed to be bigger but cut out in the end.
[b]The recruits.[/b] I understand that it's a gargantuan task to make 120 characters feel important and give enough time to everyone but there are several of the optional recruits that you talk to them once to recruit them and then they never again play any part in anything. There's no small scenes at the base between them, no mail system where their personalities can come through, no anything besides the hot springs which isn't enough. Even worse what you get is a "background" checker that gives you a little bit of info on who they are and in there several of those are stated to have ties to other characters in your base either prior to their recruitment or after, however you never see any interaction between them. One of the earlier examples is Wyler and Kuroto. While Wyler's background states he trained under Kuroto prior to the game events if you have Kuroto in your party while meeting Wyler for the first time there's not even one line of dialogue between the two.
[b]The tone[/b]. It's clear the devs tried to secure a rating appropriate for younger audiences so the game's tone, subject matter and dialogue all feel a little flat, if not outright weird, at times. It's not so bad that it ruins the game but it certainly takes you out of it a lot of the time.
[b]The world.[/b] What we got of it is good enough but it feels severely limited. Not only is it all separated into smaller sections with no true feeling of a connected map but it also feels like a lot of things that were added shouldn't have been. One big example of that is that we get an absurd amount of unique beastkin companions(like 10 different races) yet we only ever visit 2 places where we are introduced properly to those races(Treefolk and Shi'arcs). The Lycans, foxians, bull people, lizard people etc. we never get to see integrated anywhere, they just feel like "quota hires". In fact for most of them we never even see another person of those races anywhere in the world except the ones we recruited.

[h3]The Bad[/h3]

[b]The localization.[/b] I'm not a native speaker so I couldn't understand everything but I did study japanese for a few years so I played with the original voiceover. What I did notice is that there are substantial tonal shifts for several characters completely altering their characters and a lot of the time the english text is not matching the japanese script in the slightest. I wouldn't expect a word for word translation as that's just as rubbish, localization after all is not only about translating but also about adjusting things for international audiences but this is Persona 1 levels of bad. 
[b]A general feeling of "not all there".[/b] Be it the story, the characters, the systems in it, anything it just feels like it does the bare minimum to function and there are things that were meant to be there that have been omitted due to time restraints, bad design choices, lack of manpower etc.
[b]Dishonorable mention for the Battle Plan system.[/b] Even though they tried to give us a Gambit system to let us customize out team battle AI when we use the Auto function they designed it in such a horrid way that it's utterly useless. There's only one option where you teams follows individual priorities but with that option you have no way of limiting resource usage(be it MP or items) so you either go with the very inefficient default AI to reserve resources or you go to customized commands and watch your casters become useless after 2 trash fights unless you keep feeding them MP recovery items.


If I were to score this I'd give ECHH a 6 out of 10. It's passable in what it does and I did have fun with it but that general sense of "not good enough" is really bringing it down. It's still a fun experience for people that like the genre and possibly a decent introduction to it but it's not a masterpiece. I do remain hopeful for the future of the franchise though. If the devs take all the criticism to mind for the sequel we could eventually get a stellar game as the bones are already there, it's only the meat that is missing.

As someone who grew up with Suikoden, I am extremely happy with how this game came to be. Sure, it's not perfect--there are bugs and glitches from time to time--but it checks all of the things I love about JRPGs and Suikoden. It also works really well with the Steam Deck, which is a bonus.

The dialogue, although light at times, does not take away from the heart and soul of the story. The characters are all very diverse, each with their own personalities that the voice acting breathes life into. The artwork is nice as well and there are a bunch of characters that reminded me of the others I've encountered at having played all the Suikoden games. There are moments I actually burst out laughing and moments when I was somber and angered on behalf of the characters I am journeying with. I particularly like Francesca, Ymir, and Perry--from the new roster. But my faves will always be the OG trio: Garoo, CJ, and Isha because they introduced me to the lore and the adventures to be had in this world.

The battles can drag a bit, though. And the teleportation can get a bit annoying with the added dialogue every time you warp someplace. The minigames are all so fun, albeit a bunch of them requires farming for things that can help you through--like the money needed to purchase cards, finding the recipes, and farming enemy drops for beigoma. There's something about the overworld music that makes me remember Wild Arms, though, but I don't really know why that is.

I really do love everything there is in the game, and I feel like I would be replaying Suikoden again (for the umpteenth time) right after I beat this game, and the NG+.

《百英雄传 Eiyuden Chronicle: Hundred Heroes》是由Rabbit & Bear Studios制作，505 Games发行的传统jrpg。本作制作组为《幻想水浒传》的原班人马打造，可以说是《幻想水浒传》的精神续作，在经历了众筹、主创村山吉隆去世等事件后，游戏终于在2024年4月与大家见面了，让我们看看这款游戏的表现如何吧？

首先游戏的主角诺瓦原本只是一位默默无闻的守卫军新兵，而他的朋友塞恩则是一名年轻有为的军官。而随着故事的推进战争的爆发，诺瓦组建了反抗军并且试图联络精灵龙族和其他人类帝国一起反抗邪恶帝国的入侵，反正就是王道的剧情设定，诺瓦建立了据点发展壮大反抗军，而另一方面自己又去世界各地寻找英雄豪杰来壮大自己的队伍，正如标题对应的百英雄传，游戏中多达百名英雄可供玩家招募。

游戏的画面相当精致也比较复古，采用了近几年比较流行的HD-2D形式，将 2D 像素人物放置在模仿手绘背景风格的 3D 场景中，同时允许流畅的镜头移动以及高端光影和气体渲染效果。采用光影、模糊等手段配合游戏的像素风格设计，整体画面表现相当不错。而另一方面本作对于游戏人物的设计也是下了一番功夫，游戏中有多达120名以上的角色可供玩家招募入队，而有意思的是每个人物都有其独特的立绘以及特色技能，虽然一些角色人物塑造比较一般，但可以看得出制作组下了一番功夫。

本作的玩法之一就是去招募各路豪杰英雄，这也是游戏的一大特色，在其他rpg中完成任务一般都是给予一些道具和奖励，而本作则是直接招募英雄入队，每个角色都有不同的任务要求，例如去打怪，去找一些东西，找人，甚至跟他对话就会加入队伍。每位角色都有其独特的能力，一些可以在战斗中发挥作用，而一些则是帮忙建设自家的据点。不过这英雄豪杰并不是这么容易找到的，玩家需要进行大量的跑图搜索，只有靠近人物后才会显示触发，这也是游戏前期比较痛苦的一个地方，不过当你完成目标，招募成功那种成就感又是无与伦比的。

战斗方面依旧是传统的回合制设计，游戏中可以上场六名角色进行战斗，角色发动技能需要消耗mp，一些角色则有自己的独特技能消耗sp，速度则是影响人物的先后出招顺序，游戏并没有什么太多的战斗玩法，更多的是考虑角色之间的搭配和技能的使用，一些角色组合还可以放出合作技，相当华丽炫酷。

而除了普通的战斗之外，游戏后面还会遇到战棋玩法的战斗以及有趣的1v1战斗玩法，可以说是比较新颖的一点了，毕竟其他rpg基本玩到底也就一种战斗玩法。

整体游玩下来，本作可以说是完美继承了传统jrpg的特色，经典的jrpg，复古的像素风格，玩法也是传统的jrpg那套，有趣的是游戏有多达百名角色可供招募，每名角色各有特色，战斗也做了多样化设计，喜欢jrpg的玩家不要错过。

最初は本拠地の育成に必要な仲間を集める、お気に入りを使うくらいでいいかと思います。初回プレイは仲間集めは無理せず先に進めてください。そうしないと多分疲れます^^;


自分は幻想水滸伝1&2が大好きで、今でもPS史上最高の作品だったんじゃないかと思っています。
その後のシリーズはプレイしていないのですが、今回とても期待していました。

当時の幻想水滸伝を思うと懐かしいドット3Dグラフィック、綺麗な背景画面にとても嬉しくなりましたが、その時のものをそのまま持ってきただけといった状況に見えます。
過去を知っているので、各種不便なところなどは仲間を集めたり、街をアップグレードしていくことで改善していく意図としてわかる部分も多いです。

良い所あり、好きで楽しいんですが、それと同じくらいか、それ以上にきついと感じる部分が多いです。

ストーリーも前述した幻水1、2に比べてかなり遠慮した内容ですし、主人公に特別なバックボーンもなく、なんとなく流されて戦っている感じ。


期待していた分落差も酷いのかもしれませんが、傑作、秀作とも言えず、駄作ではないですが佳作にも届かず、凡作だなという印象です。

あえておすすめをしないを選択しました。あくまで、昔の幻水をプレイしたことがある方向けのゲームです。
最近の3Dになれた若い方には、ドット3Dが汚く見える意見があるのも、納得します。


いろんな良いところ、改善点を挙げるのは沢山の意見があるので多くは割愛しますが、どうしても気になる部分だけ。


■良い点
・沢山キャラクターがいるので、とりあえず誰か刺さるキャラクターがいる。
・獣人族系のキャラクターが素敵。
・ミニゲームの豊富さで寄り道が楽しい。
・細かい選択肢の違いにもボイス付きのセリフがあって、選択肢ごとのリアクションが楽しい

■どうしても気になる点
・ミニゲームの育成レースがスキップできない
・街の育成が終了するまでダンジョン内でのMP回復の手段がほとんどないので、ボス連戦になったりすると魔法使いは役に立たない。というか、MPの消費が大きすぎて普段から使えない。
むしろ魔法って必要ある？な感じ。

・英雄コンボのダメージがほぼ一人分なので個別のスキルや単純な殴りのほうが強い。
・2マス使用する大型のキャラクターが、2マス使うほどのメリットがない。
・ルーンの自由度が全くない上に、ほとんどのキャラが4つから5つの枠しかない。入れ替えれるのは2つくらいで、かつ、キャラによってはレアリティの低いものしかつけれないし、他のものが使えない。好みのキャラを活用したくてもこの影響でパーティ選択から外れることがしばしば…。

・ボイスでキャラごとの音量差が激しい

特にミニゲームの育成レースで、今どきレース場面をスキップできないのはちょっと失敗してるなと思いました…。
あの育成レースゲームの大御所、ウイポでさえレース場面はスキップできるんですよね…。
よっぽどのことがない限り周回できないですよ…。1時間くらいやっちゃいましたけど。
特にキャラクターが仲間になるとかないミニゲームでこんな仕様にしたら誰もやらないのでは？

次回新作を作るとしたら、百英雄伝シリーズじゃないほうが良いと思います。

This is the return to Suikoden we’ve all been waiting for. I’ve sunk 30 plus hours into this game and according to guides I’m still fairly early on. I tend to take my time with jrpgs, though.

The voice acting is mostly great, though I kind of miss the silent contemplation of Suikoden 2 and 3.

The battle system will feel familiar to anyone who’s played Suikoden, but it has some very refreshing additions to make battle more complex and strategy more important. If you’re a seasoned JRPG player, I suggest starting on Hard Mode (say no when it asks if you want to play on normal for customizable difficulty).

Story wise, I’m very engrossed. It hasn’t QUITE reached Suikoden levels of good yet, but let’s be honest that’s a very high bar to clear.

Visually it’s gorgeous. Colorful, beautifully animated 2D sprites, in the same pixel style as Suikoden 1 and 2, are set against gorgeous and vibrant 3D environments. 

The most impressive aspect so far is the music. Suikoden has always had amazing, moving, beautifully composed music, and Eiyuden lives up to that legacy and sometimes exceeds it.

If you like minigames, this game is full of them and they’re all very deep and even have some entertaining narrative framing that makes them feel right at home in the game world. My favorite so far is the card game, but I haven’t even unlocked the beast racing/breeding yet.

For now, I’m giving this game a 4/5 l. If the story holds up to the standards I expect from a Suikoden successor, I’ll put it up to 5/5.

Je viens de 100 % le jeu et franchement je trouve que le jeu à été rush à partir de la moitié du jeu. Il y à des villes et régions qu'on ne visite jamais, du genre celles des elfes ou des hommes dragons. Il y à des pirouettes scénaristiques assez ridicules franchement et des ellipses à outrances.

/SPOILER/ Le coup de Perrielle qui va dans le camp ennemie et la trahison de l'homme dragon qui s'en suit; d'ailleurs pourquoi ils rejoignent l'empire ces teubés ?? On sait que les hommes bêtes sont vu comme du bétail par l'empire, ça n'a aucun sens pour eux de se ranger de leur côté, j'ai trouvé ça ridicule /SPOILER/

L'absence TOTALE de post game est vraiment triste aussi et je ne vois aucun intérêt au new game +.

La quête de duel de cuisine est absolument une purge, je veux plus jamais avoir à refaire ce truc infâme. C'est beaucoup trop long pour rien et le mini jeu est vraiment nul. Le trophée ou il faut faire 1 put**n de million avec le commerce, qui est le misérable qui a osé faire une telle chose ? Il mérite la taule sans déconner, c'est criminel de faire des trucs comme ça.

Le ton du jeu de manière générale est beaucoup trop enfantin, très niais par moment et j'ai trouvé ça vraiment dommage. Le jeu est aussi beaucoup trop simple, j'ai tri shot tout les boss finaux, j'aurais pu les faire en mode auto, d'ailleurs je pense que je l'ai utilisé pendant 60 % du jeu au moins. Les mages bien que plus faible au début deviennent stupidement fort plus tard rendant les autres classes obsolètes.

J'ai bien aimé les duels, les animations sont vraiment bien faites je trouve par contre les champs de batailles c'est nullissime, il y à aucune stratégie. J'ai vraiment bien aimé la construction et la décoration de la base aussi. Les courses sont anecdotiques mais le jeu de carte est plutôt sympa par contre.

Lian et Marisa sont (ce n'est que mon avis) vraiment insupportables du début à la fin, j'avais envie de les baffer bordel. Sinon il y à beaucoup de perso qui ne servent absolument à rien car aucunes attaques utiles et des stats ridicules. Surtout comparé aux mages qui ont une palette de sort bien plus grandes que les autres classes, ils sont beaucoup plus versatiles et peuvent tout faire. En plus, allez savoir pourquoi ils ont des stat défensives excellentes qui vont de pair ou sont supérieures à beaucoup de cac.

Graphiquement la DA est plutôt sympa mais il y à beaucoup de choses qui piques les yeux du genre les ombres escaliers.

Voilà, j'ai bien aimé le jeu malgré tout mais je peux pas m'empêcher d'être déçus pour un jeu à 50 euro.

Game is fine in many areas, but I got stuck with the bad ending and couldn't get the last character because the devs thought it was a good idea to lock away certain characters before the major turning point in the story where you need to have all the characters to get the good ending. The last character I needed required another character to get. The other character was locked due to story reasons and I couldn't use them. The devs completely screwed up by doing this brain dead move and screwed over my game. In reality you need to have everyone an entire mission before the major turning point.

The later cooking fights require you to button mash for 40 of the 45 seconds to get the bar full. Why? I wouldn't blame anyone for using Steams built in turbo function for controllers to get through it cause there was literally no reason for there to be a button mash that's 45 seconds long for every single cooking fight.

Somehow the devs had the great idea to put in a "help" tab in the menu to explain things which could come in handy (like that fact that the game never explains how weapon ranges work on characters and isn't in the tutorial when it really should be, but at least it's in the "help" menu), but they forgot to put in any info about what the stats on characters mean. What does the "arm" symbol mean? What does the "hand" symbol mean? What's the difference between the "wizard hat" and "staff"? None of this is explained in game anywhere and you just to figure out that the "arm" is physical damage, "hand" is accuracy (I think?), "wizard hat" is magic defense, etc. How the devs forgot to include this info in the help tab is just mind boggling.

Also the devs put rare items in shops that only have a 10% chance to show up every 30 minutes unless you save scum (which none of this is ever explained in game). You need some of these items to finish building your town. Stupid mechanic and the game deserves a negative review just for that. Fire who ever came up with that dumb idea.

I don't even know where to begin with this game. I backed this game years ago thinking it would be a great Suikoden successor. Instead it's a buggy, janky mess, with tons of overlooked things, with unfun and repetitive minigames, with more problems with the continuity of the story than I can shake my fist at.

Nothing makes sense, the world feels static, everything is extremely bland. Stuff gets conquered but you can walk back in 2 minutes later and it's basically fine. There are no consequences to anything. The story is honestly what a teenager could come up with. Where's the personal conflict with the MC? People said "it's great that he's voiced, he feels more relatable" but he's so immensely bland. Riou from Suikoden II with no VA and not a single line of text (only dialogue options) had more personality than this guy.

There are nearly no nuances or any of the inner turmoil, or political conflicts that were made by these guys back when they made the Suikoden series. It's honestly mind-boggling how backwards this game is on the writing side of things compared to the original games they apparently made. I'm a huge fan of political conflicts in fantasy worlds where things are more grounded but this game just does it in such a superficial way it's almost an insult. I'm only finishing this game out of obligation because I paid for it, and because I want to see the end of this trainwreck.

So many bugs, still unfixed. Stuff like the controller having no native dead zone is a serious red flag. This is basic stuff. I barely brush my finger on the control stick and my character walks endlessly even if I touch nothing. Navigating the menus is a joke with such long transition times, and you can spam cancel to make the menu continuously reset itself instead of exiting if you spam it at just the right time. A lot of these bugs were known over a month ago when the demo went live, and many days before the game went live due to playtest. All that was fixed is one recruitment bug, more or less, yet there are multiple others still in the game.

And don't get me started on the minigames. They have no self-contained progression system. You want to do a card game? Go buy like 200 packs and instantly be overpowered, then wipe the floor with every NPC - do this 120 times for an achievement. The same exact match, 120 times, when they are quite long. It's a snorefest. Wait, this game has Beyblade? Nice! That's cool. Oh wait, out of the tutorial you cannot play it at all - you need to grind random monsters for drops so you can even have competitive tops. It's a joke. No thought or coherence went into these designs. The fishing minigame is a bland and boring "press button at the right time to catch the fish". We had better than that 20 years ago.

In fact we did. Go play Suikoden. Literally any of them, maybe even Suikoden IV, the one people say is the worst. At least you have a cool ship castle instead of a boring, bland castle that barely seems to change as you upgrade it. Yeah, I got the last level of the castle - it still looks the exact same as before. It doesn't get new areas or anything. Some stuff, very rare, creates a room or two but they are very specific and don't really have much of a use. And the timing for the upgrades, too. I got level 3 castle like 20 hours in and I was stuck with it for 50 hours so far. It took me all this time to finally get level 4. And barely anything changed. The resources gathering part was a legitimate concern early on, then it became a nothingburger and it might as well not exist for all it provides to the game. Just like a lot of the design that went in this.

It's so disappointing and... bland. This whole game is bland. Minigames are bland. Characters are bland. Story is bland. And if this story has even one more deus ex machina instead of having the characters legitimately figure out a solution to their problems, I'm going to scream. I don't even need to mention the localization or anything because it doesn't matter if it's "bad" or if it's "not bad" or whatever - the rest of the game is just bland as a product on its own. Seriously, this is a joke compared to Suikoden and I am very sad.
I still have so much more to play but this feels like a true spiritual successor to Suikoden. Im so happy it exists and ive been loving every minute of it.

TLDR: Eiyuden Chronicle might be worth your money, but only if you’re desperate for another Suikoden game. Everyone else should save your money, and play it on Xbox Game Pass instead. EC gets more right than it does wrong, but it keeps one foot firmly planted in the past, and not always for the better.

My qualifications: I’ve played through Suikoden 1&2 multiple times, doing almost everything worth doing in each. I supported this game’s kick starter as a “slacker backer”, pre-ordering a game for the first time EVER because I believed in this game and the people who made it. EC is clearly a passion project Rabbit and Bear Studios didn’t have to make. Sadly, series creator Yoshitaka Murayama passed away before he could see EC’s release, but is this truly his magnum opus, or does EC fail to surpass the heights of SK2? IMO, both are true.

You should only buy this game if you want to do everything in SK2 all over again, and I quite literally mean EVERYTHING. This begs the question: if EC offers little to nothing new, why not just play SK2 instead? EC tries to differentiate itself mainly through new difficulty options, since one of the greatest weaknesses of SK in hindsight was that its extremely easy. While some of these work, others don’t.

No Items in Battle and No Escape from Battles specifically are the wrong approach. Group healing and revival items are rendered worthless, since basic healing does the job for less money outside of battle. Even on the highest difficulty you’ll be auto-resolving battles in no time, and the leveling system is very forgiving so under-leveled characters can catch up quick. This too is rendered pointless. Rather than force players to fight every battle, the game should’ve given us a reason to fight them by making them truly challenging. Hitting “Auto” and opening the menu to pop healing afterwards doesn’t require skill, it’s just plain tedious. Fortunately, the game allows you to tailor which options you want, and which you don’t.

Finally, I’d like to talk about EC as a game to play remotely. I can’t be the only one who was excited to boot this up in Steam Link and play anywhere. I even bought a cheap android handheld with the task in mind under the mistaken belief the Developers had remote gamers in mind. Sadly, the Switch version is reportedly the worst version of all. This version offers barely any resolution options, and makes no considerations for users on smaller screens. As a guy with perfect vision, I was squinting to read text on my handheld. If you have any kind of visual impairment, this game is a hard pass on everything but the largest screens.

Overall, the game is slightly above average, and gets a lukewarm thumbs up from me. SK 1&2 were amazing RPGs in their time after all, but we have some serious quality of life issues that make EC fall short of what it could be, being more of a mimic than a true successor.

This game is a travesty.  I like playing games on the hardest setting.  


1) Difficulty setting = After dying a few times I was impressed on the difficulty.  Until I discovered the secret.  Any battle can be won on hard early on by revive spaming.  The AI has a simple brain to attack the weakest party member, which is fair, but is exploitable.  All you have to do is keep someone barely alive and the boss or mob you are fighting will kill it over and over again while you take chunks of its life off.  Sad. 

2) Military battles are terrible and designed for 3 year olds.  I swear my kids can probably beat these battles.  They require no strategy and simply end after one enemy gets spooked about not being able to steamroll you, which by the way all you do is do not attack and gain the high ground.  You never get to attack because you just stand on the high ground and they throw themselves at you while you eat a ham sandwich.  Awful.  There is only one battle that you get to control it to its conclusion and by that time you have achieved far too many deus ex machinas for it to be challenging.  ALSO YOU CAN ONLY ATTACK ONE SQUARE WITH 3 UNITS TOTAL REGARDLESS OF ORIGIN RENDERING PINCHER ATTACKS IMPOSSIBLE.  HAHA WHAT?

3) the story is bad and loaded with screaming annoying women.  I am not sure if a feminist wrote the dialog of this game or an anti feminist did.  The characature of the personalities in this game for the women  is laughable bad.  I found myself actively rooting against them or trying to get them killed off if it was possible.  I dont even know if its possible to bring Perille back to life because frankly the game was much better with her dead.  

4) this game was clearly a ripoff of Suikoden 2 with elements of 1 and 3 thrown in.  Marisa is literally Hugo.  Lian is Nanami, and Nowa/Seign are Jowy and Riou,  The problem with games and movies now of days is they take an original writer and he just rewrites/copy+paste the same game or movie hoping to cash in on the nostalgia factor and hopes no one notices.  Lawrence Kasden is such an example.  Star Wars Episode 7 was complete garbage and so was this game.  

5) real life political subtext.  Ill let you play the game, but I was rooting for the Empire to beat me the whole time, but it wasnt possible because the game was stupid easy and put you on auto pilot for hours on end while having the user have no input on the actual storyline.  

6) basement powerleveling.   This literally breaks the game.  I was uncovering characters for a few hours trying to catch up to the story and i found this girl who does demonic time trials in the basement.  I decided to try it out at level 45.  Found an easy group of 6 mobs and all the sudden I was level 56, then the next easy battle I was level 60.  This is really bad.  WHY?  Endgame content is non existent and they retaking territory is so terribly written and completely dissapointing.  

7)  Cooking.  Bad.  Cant randomly cook and discover recipes like the past and all you do is spam a few dishes to always beat your opponent.  Also the challengers never switch up their dishes making them lose most of the time.  Pathetic.

8) Eggfoot racing game.  This was fun.  Got hooked on this a bit in the middle of the game.  Then I played a bit more and all the sudden I could unlock the best racers right at the end.  Thanks for wasting my time.

[h3]前言 [/h3]
《百英雄传》作为《幻想水浒传》系列的精神续作，由原班人马进行开发，得益于玩家众筹而问世。这部作品围绕战争和友谊展开的宏大史诗，刻画了上百位角色，在系统、战斗、玩法、角色招募、人物造型等方面都能看见幻水2的影子，将《幻想水浒传》系列风格真正融入了现代JRPG的游戏。

[h3]王道故事下的群像剧 [/h3]
在人类、兽人、精灵等种族并存的富饶大陆上，帝国为了扩张势力四处搜寻蕴含强大力量的原始透镜。在帝国掌握了核心科技后，利用匪徒作祟的借口突袭了埃提斯维斯前线，国破家亡的主角诺瓦临危受命，被迫走上了建立反抗军基地（名字可选梁山，多随机几次就能刷到），招募伙伴（聚义）进行抗争的道路。

在废墟上建立的反抗军基地，仅有十几位英雄好汉的情况下，主角诺瓦在大陆冒险的旅途中带回一位位志同道合的朋友厉兵秣马，发展基地。每位英雄都有各自的剧情故事，通过完成提交基础道具、搜寻稀有材料到战胜敌人、携带特定角色邀请等多种入队前置任务，将其带上梁山。

游戏前中期玩下来感觉整体慢热，因为弱引导的任务系统，主线任务之外的其余对话也没有日志保存和地图指引。所以遇见的每一段剧情都要仔细观看手动记录，以免漏掉关键信息卡任务。通过这种方式强制引导玩家去观看剧情，对新人玩家十分不友好。

在帝国与联盟组队探索遗迹的主线剧情过后，主角诺瓦地图上招募三个队友入队，探查矿井后触发回乡剧情，就开始两军城战，受命建立反抗军。同类的王道建城故事剧情，比如前作幻水2 的辉盾纹章，二之国中的王子身份，拥立首领都是有其背景和天命的因素在内，但本作中让一个偏远山村的新兵被佩丽尔选定为领袖没有逐步提升的名望和令人信服的天命选定，担此大任的理由是否太过突兀。

[h3]延续原作的玩法模式[/h3]
百英雄传最主要的玩法内核，一个是传统JRPG下的打怪升级爆装备开宝箱的战斗玩法，一个是招募伙伴升级城池的城建玩法，包含与之配套的军团作战等附属玩法。其余的旁支玩法和功能性依靠角色入队解锁，而不是一股脑的全部呈现出来。

我方可选择3313模式，按照3前锋-3后卫-1支援者-3同行者的方式组队。战斗系统下，前锋后卫六名队员为主战力，支援者可以提供开场支持。角色武器固定金币升级，其余装备可以根据职业随意更换。技能方面可以通过符文槽来自由选择，还有同队相关角色的羁绊组合技能，带来简易的build构筑玩法。强力的经验补正简化了高带低练角色的枯燥过程，游戏体验直线上升。

游戏中怪物采用暗雷触发方式，战斗通过敌我速度差依次行动，本作没有二倍速，也不能跳过战斗，六位角色每轮手动选择十分繁琐，建议多带药品使用预设战术自动战斗功能。Boss战有特殊机制，比如前期的躲掩体、打地鼠二选一、争夺机器控制权，利用机巧可以简化战斗过程，但是纯靠运气的打地鼠机巧确实让人头大。

在军团战玩法中虽然给予了招募人物的登场机会，但相较于同类游戏的玩法表现上，还是显得差强人意。玩家操控战旗代表军队单位进行移动，一个轮次下只能调整方向或者移动一格，没有战场战术和策略性的体验，看小兵零零散散的战斗演出，枯燥而乏味。右侧的战况牺牲位则是众筹玩家名单，这种感谢方式真是令人忍俊不禁。

[h3]百位CV的豪华阵容[/h3]
音乐方面表现略显中规中矩，但也有部分亮点燃点。前期城破后的主角突围单挑战，本应成为朋友的双方出于各自立场不得不对立战斗，通过音乐渲染敌强我弱但因背负使命不得不战的两难境地，观众的情绪在战斗引导下逐步升温，带来了一幕出彩的剧情演出。

游戏中每位出场角色剧情对话中都有专属CV，可以算是大手笔了。这些人物角色性格各异，有的还反差感强烈。初期入队的奶妈法兰洁丝卡平时宛如邻家大姐姐，但在激怒她后就会变身暴力法师，从剧情对话和满怒状态下的符文技能都有表现，人物性格塑造十分成功。

[h3]新技术复古日式传统 [/h3]
3D环绕型大地图与2D的房间场景、像素人像相结合，描绘出的不同村落文化下的建筑风格，在现代技术的加持下，各种场景细节处理十分不错。但诸如战斗没有二倍速，更换队伍和符文前期只能回城去旅馆和商店，袖珍到极点的背包容量和物品堆叠数量、全凭记忆的支线任务等设定，也极大影响了游玩体验。另外，游戏的汉化部分有误，力量符文的描述居然是提升体力，结合状态栏看应该是提升力量才对。

[h3]总结 [/h3]
百英雄传作为一款众筹产出的精神续作游戏来说，抓住了原作最核心的部分继承下来。丰富的人物刻画与剧情配音，海量的角色收集与培养，有趣的建城玩法和小游戏，多样的boss打法设定，诚意满满值得肯定。但慢热且稍显生硬薄弱的剧情过渡，枯燥漫长的暗雷战斗，以及便捷功能的缺失，也极大消磨了探索热情。期待后续的更新优化，为新玩家带来更好的游玩体验。

From what Iv'e played (so far) it seems to take what made those old school RPG games from the 90's so good, and bring it to a modern standard. The graphics have the nostalgic feel from your childhood, and brings with them, the charm and design you like. The gameplay is pretty straight forward: go here, kill that, level up, upgrade your gear etc. The story is fun and engaging so far. and the fact that there are over 100 heroes for you to meet and recruit is amazing. The cast is varied, and full of life. I like what iv'e played so far, and I'll definitely be seeing this journey through to the end. Also, the fact that this is a turn based fantasy RPG makes me happy, especially since Final Fantasy has decided to go full action combat now.

While the game is fun I cannot really recommend it unless it goes on sale. After playing it for about 20 hours I have noticed many of the problems the game has. The story is not really that interesting so far and while there are a lot of characters to recruit they mostly feel empty without any substance. All the characters you recruit do not seem to get much in terms of dialog or backstory and many of them that can be used in combat are outright useless. 

Another major problem I have with the game is the combat. You have a frontline for your tankier characters and a backline for your squishy characters. The problem is that against most bosses  your lineup does not matter whatsoever as the bosses seem to intentionally target your characters with weaker defences. This leads to the problem with how much damage your chars take and why most of the chars in the game are useless. If you have a high defence char then they will take little damage and take what the bosses dishout. On the other hand if you have a character with low defense scaling you might as well let them die as you will just spend all your turns and items on fruitlessly trying to keep them alive while the boss 1-2 shots them over and over again. If you revive a character the bosses seem to prioritize rekilling that char their next turn. 

As far as I can tell you cannot do anything to prevent your weaker chars from being mowed down and useless. Taunts are useless, you can taunt every turn with Iugo they will just ignore him. You could use dodge with Lian but you will be wasting your time as it seems to give her 5% more dodge at best. You could use shield with mellore but is that tiny shield going to stop her from getting oneshotted? I can tell you now it wont. 

I feel I need to point out that I am playing on hard difficulty so maybe these problems are not as bad on normal. I would also like to point out I am not complaining about the game being difficult because it is not, I have only had trouble with one boss and its because they constantly put my whole team to sleep with no way to cure it. The fact is I clear most bosses with my 3 bruisers in the front row easily after my back row gets wiped out. I could probably make the game even easier if I  put 3 more tanky chars in the back row even if they had short attack range and just used them as extra damage sponges/item tossers.

Lastly I see a lot of people complaining about the localization and voice acting. Personally I dont think the voice acting is that bad but maybe I am just not that picky (after all I am a filthy heathen that often watches dubbed anime). As for the localization with no reference to what is in the original script I dont find it that bad except for a few pieces of dialog. An example would be when two characters who hate eachother are having a heated exchange and one of them calls the other a fartface.....yes he actually calls the enemy he hates a fartface I am not making this up. There are other examples and a few spots where the dialog is just off but overall it doesnt really bother me and for the most part I think its ok.

Eiyuden Chronicle: Hundred Heroes" é um RPG de aventura que oferece uma experiência rica em narrativa e estratégia. Aqui está um guia rápido para iniciantes

Dicas para Iniciantes e Modo Iniciante: Para quem nunca jogou um JRPG antes, o jogo pode parecer complexo. Felizmente, "Eiyuden Chronicle: Hundred Heroes" oferece um modo iniciante que simplifica algumas mecânicas e fornece dicas úteis durante o jogo. Além disso, aqui estão algumas dicas para iniciantes:
Entenda os Fundamentos: Familiarize-se com os conceitos básicos, como movimentação no mapa, interação com personagens e combate por turnos.

Experimente Diferentes Personagens: Cada personagem tem habilidades únicas. Experimente diferentes combinações para descobrir quais se encaixam melhor em seu estilo de jogo.

Gerencie seus Recursos: Use itens e magias com sabedoria. É importante manter sua equipe saudável e pronta para enfrentar desafios.

Explore o Mundo: Não se limite à história principal. Explore o mundo de Allraan para encontrar tesouros, missões secundárias e novos aliados.

Não Tenha Pressa: JRPGs são conhecidos por suas histórias envolventes. Aproveite o jogo no seu próprio ritmo e mergulhe na narrativa e nos personagens.

The localisation is close to insulting and reduced the writing to absolute crap, the music is forgettable, many of the mechanics are shallow or plain unexplained, the plot is childish and lacking the humanising depth of Suikoden, the pacing is absolutely jarring and the minigames are boring, the duels are confusing and messy and the "war" battles are basically elaborate cutscenes you can't loose or really make any meaningful contribution to. 
Missing characters in Suikoden wasn't so bad as the games themselves were a joy to play. This I could not wait to end. 

It's an old-school JRPG and spiritual successor to Suikoden, so I don't regret buying it at a discount, but I have no intention of replaying what is essentially the video game equivalent to a theme-park ride in tribute to a great franchise. 

It does make me appreciate the magic that is the Suikoden Series though. a 5/10 for me.

--Review-in-progress. More to be added when I complete the game-- TL:DR: If you love Suikoden 1 and 2, then this game is for you. If you dislike those games, you'll dislike this. If you haven't played those games, then you should do so before considering Eiyuden.

Be aware that a bunch of right-wing crybabies and incels are brigading the game/devs right now because some 'gamergate' incel types have been raging about it on Twitter and YouTube, and it's become the latest target for the X brigade's war on 'wokeness' (lol). The localisation is fine. The hysterics from incels is peak cringe (I've literally seen them claiming the localisation is "evil" on the Steam forum lmao). Anyone saying they need a 'direct translation' is simply being disingenuous, and anyone who knows anything about Japanese language will know that direct translations don't work. As we all know at this point: when someone complains about "wokeness" they are just trolls and/or dysfunctional people. These people have tried to review bomb the game, which is why I'm putting up a review-in-progress.

With that out of the way, this feels like a true successor to Suikoden 1 and 2, moreso than Suikoden 3-5 did (and I love those latter games too). Visually splendid, gorgeous sprite work, tons of charm, with modern sensibilities. The 3D environments look lovely (which is very rare for a JRPG), even the dungeons look nice and are interestingly designed. Tons of characters, tons of secrets, plenty going on, Lots to explore. I'm only 13 hours in and I'm having a blast so far building up my army and castle, and am yet to see anything remotely 'woke' here (besides the typical Suikoden story about building and uniting a diverse army in resistance against a corrupt empire, of course).

If you haven't played Suikoden, then you should play those games (1 and 2 at the very least), which will give you an idea if Eiyuden is for you.

作为众筹作品算是及格的。
三人组里男主女主的配音声音闷的厉害，料理赛真是又臭又长，男娘魔法师的伤害爆炸，主角他妹这孔也太强了，讲真不看攻略根本收不齐120人，最后各人结局的时候能不能慢点放，根本来不及看完就切换了。
法师队太强了 物理队就是小丑，一个地狱火直接烧1300~1700的伤害，带够药 任何主线boss根本顶不过buff的三回合。

Als ich hörte, dass mir Eiyuden Chronicle ein spiritueller Nachfolger der Suikoden-Reihe herauskommen soll, hatte ich gemischte Gefühle. Einerseits Freunde, dass diese großartige Reihe endlich wieder ein wenig auflebt, andererseits Sorge, dass das Spiel meinen Erwartungen nicht gerecht wird. 

Nach einigen Spielstunden stelle ich aber mit Freunde fest, dass das Spiel meine Erwartungen vollkommen erfüllt und zum Teil auch übertrifft. Das Spiel ist vor allem an Suikoden 2 (und 1) angelehnt und greift einige Elemente aus diesen Spielen auf. Die Grafik orientiert sich stark am Retro-Style und wird hier und da mit HD-Grafiken untermauert. 

Die Story ist bislang eine sehr klassische Suikoden / RPG Story, was ich aber ebenfalls als durchaus angenehm empfinde. 
Vor allem begeistert bin ich von der Musik des Spiels, welche die Szenen perfekt untermauert!
Von den kleinen negativen Dingen wie "Laufen gegen unsichtbare Mauern" kann ich in diesem Spiel vollkommen hinwegsehen.

Die Charaktere, die man im Laufe der Geschichte trifft, haben alle eine eigene Individualität, sodass man eine Bindung zu diesen aufbauen kann. Dabei hilft auch die gelungene Synchronisation. Alles in allem übertragt das Spiel die Atmosphäre hervorragend. 

Ich bin von dem Spiel begeistert. Es hat jetzt schon einen besonderen Platz in meinem Herzen.
Ich freue mich sehr auf die restlichen Spielstunden und kann es absolut empfehlen!
There's some minor dialogue bugs (people saying things before you prompt them) but otherwise the game is fun and enjoyable.

这是个JRPG游戏，但更像有好多个小游戏的嘉年华游戏，游戏主要玩法都没做好。
粉丝向，不值，200块拿去吃顿好的吧，制作组的野心很大，当然惰性也很大。
如果这个作品建立于“精神续作”的基础上，那么就注定不会太好，撑死了也只是个致敬作品，在精彩程度上，决定了它为数不大的上限。
游戏不支持键鼠改键，对手柄玩家没影响，中文翻译质量堪忧，一个相同的名词却在不同场合有几种翻译。
关于JRPG体验，是比较糟糕的，6个人在回合制游戏里，算是亮点，其他游戏都是4个或是少有的5个，但这也会成为弊端，某些对局会处于互相拉人死人的节奏，角色数量多，战斗毫无亮点，也体现不出6个人的好玩之处，以及平平无奇的连携技，动画速度慢也是硬伤，战斗是来打架的，不是看你的动画演示的，再好看热血的动画，看多了被拖久了时间也会腻。
战斗系统沿用的前排后排，很死板，而且既然是回合制，战斗人数又有6个，应当有更多策略可言，无法改变前排/后排的数量，在战略上就不会有太多的阵型思考空间，就无脑战士前排法师后排？不同于其他队伍4个人的RPG游戏不讲究前后排，这游戏战斗可是6个人啊，都不能在站位上分工明确，就像一盘散沙。
建议出个5*5的方格可以自由部署队伍人员的位置，有前排中排后排，并且处于不同位置有不同加成，而不是死板的前后都3个，这样就有更多的战略性配置，比如5保1、2保4，让6个人都有明确分工。
讽刺的是这款游戏讲述的就是战争，而实际上的战争和过家家一样，我不知道在玩什么。
好歹也算是个新游戏了，有点新机制行不行。

When you look at the artwork, listen to the music and the game as a whole, you see a labor of love and every person that developed this game clearly poured his/her soul into this.

Edit: Refunded the game, when story is fixed ill buy it again maybe. Urban new speak in fantasy rpgs are not done.

I love this game so far. It harkens back to a simpler time where JRPGs focused on a positive, world-saving friendship, even in light of the dark events happening in the world. 

Recruiting new allies is very rewarding, and I'm so happy to see a Suikoden style RPG in the modern era. The graphics, and sound design are both very strong, and the game doesn't take itself too seriously.

There are some areas of the game which could use improvement; notably the war game system being opaque, & the ability to cancel out of activities you can clearly see will fail. 

I'm loving it and I'm so happy this kickstarter was a rousing success.

I want to like this game more than I actually like it...

There's just enough going right that I'm interested in finishing it out, but there's just some things wrong that I find irritating.  For example, during the recruitment of an early character, the guards you are speaking to suddenly have completely different voices and accents.  The translation of the game itself is also questionable-to-bad, particularly with some of your earlier companions.
 
There's also glaring animation issues.  For some characters as they walk, particularly walking in the Y-direction (up/down), they will kick their legs out at an angle as if they are all bow-legged.  It's extremely jarring.  The kangaroo hops are also very janky, especially if they stop moving mid-hop.  Then there's the battle camera...  The way the camera shifts around in battle is a bit maddening.  In Octopath Traveler, it happens on big events (full Boost attacks, etc).  For Eiyuden Chronicles, it'll move around when you go through the process of selecting each hero's actions.  And that takes time... which slows down the already antiquated, slow-pace of this battle system.  This is a recurring theme, where a lot of the menu changes seem kinda slow.

All in all... it's fine.  The game isn't a masterpiece, but I'm not putting on some rose-tinted glasses thinking Suikoden I and II are perfect either.  If released today, they would be equally clunky.  

But that's all it is.  Just fine.  Not spectacular.

Since this game claims to be a spiritual successor to Suiko Series, I will review it in comparison of Suiko Series. (possible spoilers ahead). Suiko 1&2 is 9.5/10 for me, this game is around 8 (mostly for artwork and gameplay).

[b] [u] What I like about this game: [/u] [/b]

[u]The Map[/u] is quite easy to navigate for a game with a 3D map.

[u]Artwork and Gameplay[/u] is awesome

[u]Game Vibes[/u] just screams Suikoden series, no doubt about that.

[u]Easy level Grinding[/u] (optional) with boss rush mode.

[u]Minigames[/u], this game have a lot of mini games.

[u]Gameplay and Team building[/u], Classic Suiko gameplay with some new additions. I like the rune customization although it took me awhile to understand.

[u]Menu System[/u] is quite informational, including displaying what a rune can do, which character got unite attacks together.

[u]Light Scenes[/u], game filled with several light scenes that can make me laugh.

[u]Money and Resource grinding[/u], grinding is easy, and I am able to equip characters and setup their gears easily, including raising weapon levels.

[u]Monster Bestiary[/u] that includes a full drop list in library really helps (please do items collection and descriptions too in the next game)

[u]Castle Upgrades[/u] now have unlockables.

[u]Theater[/u] is just awesome with the all the VAs and stuffs. Watching various cast play different roles is just great.



[b] [u] What I dislike [/u]; (what the game could be improved on):[/b]

[u]Game Story[/u] is light and probably more geared torward younger audiences, story is not heavy like suiko 3... Suiko 2 and 1 is best in terms of story, Storywise, this game story telling is in between Suiko 3 and 5. I would give it a 7 for story.

[u]Lore building[/u] need to be improved. Many races and location, but backstory is somewhat lacking.

[u]Character design and backstory[/u], first of all, their names are not easy to be memorised and the character are somewhat easily forgotten. 
[spoiler] Even the main character and main villain backstory is too simple, without any significant dilemma faced whatsoever [/spoiler],

I felt while although the character personality is reflected by VA, I felt kinda hard to establish connection (less involvement) with the characters.

Character somewhat felt one dimensional (no character growth), we mostly see only the good side of them, but not the bad...

These imperfections could make or break a character, and make us easier to relate to a particular character.

English VAs made like most of the young girl characters in game sounds like a cheeky brat. XD (the only exception where I quite enjoyed the VAs is in the theater mode)

Please Devs improve this in the next game, Suiko 1 and 2 is a good example... (I like experiencing their story through in game event than being told in a simple text from investigation etc). Flik's Story in Suiko Series is a good example of character backstory. 

I could see referencing from popular anime like full metal alchemist on some characters, but I hope the character design is more unique and original next time.

[u]Music[/u], although the music is quite good, the emotion generated and felt are nowhere compared the mixed emotions and experiences that I got when I played Suiko series, especially the first and second game. This is especially true in town and in-between scenes.

I find the music is not memorable enough to differentiate towns and establish the emotions during the scenes.
if I have to say what I dislike the most about the game, this probably takes the cake.

[u]Ending Credit[/u] (100s Character epilogue story) - Scrolls too fast after to both sides of the screen after only a short delay, I can't read it fast enough on some characters. Too much fancy wordings too.

[u]Lotsa Bugs[/u] - notable for lots of visual bugs involving character sprites appearing where they shouldn't have (duplicates, etc).

[u]Game development[/u] felt rushed and didn't go through a proper timeline for beta testing before going for public version.... especially during the later stages of the game.

[u]Small details[/u] improvement can be done, 
i.e showing all the eggfoot races so I can see the prizes and item description so I can decide whether It's worth it to spend time doing it.
item description in english localization also can be improved, please use simple words that's easy to read rather than using some fancy words.

[spoiler] [u]No Tear Jerker.[/u]  The best part about Suiko 1 and 2 is they have memorable scenes, with tearjerkers... this game probably had none of these memorable scenes... [/spoiler] it's mostly a "feel good" game throughout the story... which is nice, but kinda boring sometimes. No tense ups and downs during the plot whatsoever, these made the plot felt rather flat. [spoiler]Hell, a village is burned and I don't feel sad or sorry at all XD [/spoiler]

[u]War[/u] felt boring in this game. I liked Suiko's 2 War the best. (good customization and good strategy aspects)

[u]Strategy Plot Story[/u] during war and the politic part of this game is somewhat lacking. (Story made me felt like the War is won based on luck mostly rather than brilliant strategy by the strategist).
 
[u]Rare finds items[/u] in shop is annoying, no Old book explaining which shop to find rare items, AFAIK, and no tutorial regarding the mechanics behind it.

[u]Fishing minigame[/u] is a time waster and serves no purpose than collecting fish, finding the right fish to recruit a character. It could be improved by adding prizes for achievement such as number of collected fish collection.

[u]View Angle[/u] made it hard to find treasure chests in some maps.

[u]Duel[/u] is less interesting and mostly serves as a showcase for cool artwork by the game devs only.

[u]No Gambling[/u] minigame, i.e the dices. :'(


There, my justification for the 8 Score. If the Bugs are fixed and the flaws is to be improved, this game has potential to be a spiritual successor of Suikoden.
