A very flawed gem suffering from way too many technical issues.

I wish I could recommend this game; I truly do. There are so many things to like here, but the flaws, bugs, and non-functional features make it hard to recommend.

The developers have left multiple progress-breaking bugs in the game and are very slow to address them. Loading screens are everywhere, and there is no frame cap in the game, except for half refresh rate V-sync or full refresh rate V-sync (aptly named as 30fps and 60fps caps in the game settings). Thus, one needs to use RTSS or another frame-limiting software to cap the fps. Otherwise, if you play in windowed mode, you will see 1000 fps. You know something is missing when both the opening intro and credits are bugged and unfinished.

Many game systems do not work as intended or are bugged or even outright broken.

The game's core revolves around collecting multiple heroes. Unfortunately, quite a few recruitment events are bugged and require either a workaround, a mod, or a patch to complete. There are also quite a few recruitment quests that are time-gated, so prepare to spend hours recruiting just a single character.

The game does not explain anything, so be prepared to check the game's help menu to understand what is going on.

Localization has received a lot of criticism from others. It's passable, but the English script differs from the Japanese script. The English script contains many typos, even with something as basic as "your" vs. "you're." The English voice acting is horrible. I do recommend switching to Japanese voice acting, which is better but suffers from a really bad audio mix, as does the rest of the game.

When the game is good, it really is enjoyable. Collecting a vast array of characters and building your own city feels rewarding. The story is pretty mediocre—it’s not bad, but it’s so forgettable that it’s a shame the characters aren’t utilized better. Almost all of the characters are underused, and even if you want to build your own party, most of the game restricts you to a few specific characters. It seems many elements were cut from the final product, leading to some odd dialogue both early and very late in the game.

Wait until the developer, if ever, fixes most of the issues, and this game could be much better. At this point, it's a solid 7/10.

Alrighty, a proper JRPG. 

There's a lot of dissent about the quality of this game looking at the reviews of others. Really it is going to boil down to a pretty simple question. What do you enjoy about playing a video game? If it's story, this hits. If it's visuals, this hits, if it's customization it can sorta hit, if it's about freedom, this game will not hit. 

It's a JRPG. a Japanese style, role playing game. Why is the J, in JRPG significant? Well, usually it's due to the nature of the game, and the "numbers up good" feels that come with it. There is grind, there are loopholes, and there are ways to break it. Just like any other JRPG, like the Chrono series, the Final Fantasy series, so on, so forth. All JRPG's.

This is the spiritual successor to the series of Suikoden. Some may agree, some not. Nevertheless with my play time, I genuinely feel like I'm playing a Suikoden game. This isn't always a good thing though. 

I remember when I first played Suikoden as a kid. It was wild. So many party members, so many interesting folk, so many combos of party members. It was wild. I loved it, and I love this. Full stop.

This does not mean there aren't flaws. I will follow up with the things I do not like about the game currently.

1. Limited inventory space, but a need to gather - Fuck this combo. If you want me to gather shit give me the fucking inventory to carry it. Fuck you and your 30 slots for items. If you're going to limit inventory space, then give some kind of method to quickly improve the situation. I shouldn't be juggling healing herbs, runes, and equipment like this, 11 HOURS into the game. It's idiotic and bad game design. You fucked up on this part of making it too similar to old school RPG's. Inventory management is *not fun* for most anyone. It's not a quirk, it's not a good choice, it's not challenging, it's fucking annoying. You already balanced against healing item abuse in how you do combat. I'll come back to this.

2. You hid a bunch of fucking characters. Time and again I fucking *hated* this about Suikoden. You've created a situation where players have to go to all of the locations on the map over, and over, and over, and over, and over, and over, and over, and over, and over, and over, and over and over, and over between every. single. fucking. story bite. Don't want to miss anyone, because you old Suikoden developers taught me early on that if I don't recruit everyone, Gremio dies for good (reference to Suikoden 1. No spoilers, except for Suikoden 1.). I do not like your visuals, your cities, or your dungeons, jungles and mazes enough to do this between every story bite. It's exhausting. Maybe it gets better later on, but at 11 hours all I have seen is evidence of the opposite. 

Beyond this though, it's a fucking excellent JRPG. It hits all of the notes. The story *so far* moves at a good pace. It lets you infer and make easy guesses as what's going to happen early on, but from there the tropes start to become less relevant. The characters are so far pretty well written and made. The story has been good so far, too. I am invested. 

Combat. It's easy. I've been playing on hard so far, and only the boss fights really have any difficulty. Nevertheless, you can grind out a win regardless of how you play simply because of the JRPG numbers up system. The visuals are good, the Hero combos are good, and there's plenty of surprises as to who can combo with who, but that said *make it easier to find these combos*

I do appreciate they add a "you're too strong for these guys, lets bounce" option once you're overlevelled for a guaranteed run from an encounter. I have seen that there are FAR less encounters on 60 fps versus 30. So congrats on using dated technology for rpg encounters in a new rpg I guess. Still, the good comes with the bad. 

Overall though, This game takes me back to my roots of playing video games. These frustrating things that I mention were the norm when I was younger. I'm used to it. The reviews show that many are not. There's a middle ground, and this company could reach it with a few patches.

2024/05/01時点

クリアしたので感想を追加します。
クリアまでのプレイ時間は48時間ほどでした。
仲間を探してウロウロ（＆クソエンカウント）
していた時間が半分はあった。
仲間を探してウロウロするゲームなのだから、
エンカ率低下のアイテムはもっと早く出てきてもよいと思う。

これから購入を考える方へ、
この作品には以下の要素が含まれています。

・適正Ｌｖ＆装備でも後衛がザコにワンパンされることがある
・なんなら柔い前衛もワンパンされることがある
・ザコとして登場する敵が全体範囲のダメージ+石化を使う
　※コカトリス（親）を許すな
・最終的にはレベルを上げて物理で殴るのが最適解　

最終的に良かった点
・テレポ周りの仕様
快適でよかった。
いちいちキャラがしゃべらなければもっとよかった。

・ラスボス討伐からエンディングまでの流れ
ストーリー展開に不満はあるが、ここの演出は良かった。

最終的な不満点
・後半になると端折られはじめるストーリー
最終盤にかけて、ストーリー上あきらかに
丁寧にやらなければならない部分を
ダイジェストのような形で終わらせている。
ここから反撃だぜ！と思っていたら気づくと終わっていた。残念。

・アイテムの所持個数ならびにスタックの考え方
アイテム所持数は拠点の強化により
最大で70個となるが、全く足らない。
（サポートキャラでも増加できるが、
　貴重なサポート枠を割くことは難しい）
特に未鑑定品を１個１枠にするのは本当にやめてほしい。
また、装備とルーンは消費アイテムとは別にして
所持上限を分けるべきではないかと思う。
持ちきれないドロップアイテムを諦めることに関して
プレイヤーが感じるストレスを
開発は軽く見積り過ぎているのではないか。

・鑑定はまとめて一回で終わらせてほしい。
いちいち「なんでも鑑定団」みたいな演出はいらない。
10個とか20個とか単位で鑑定を行うことを想定していないのか、
ならばなぜその数が入手できるドロップ率にしてあるのか、
仕様の調整がチグハグで十分できていないように感じる。

・強いルーンを装備できるキャラが決まっており育成自由度が低い
装備できるルーンの種類については
各キャラの特性ということで納得できないでもないが、
ルーンのレベル上限については、
何等かの方法で拡張できるようにするべきではないかと感じる。
飛属性の「乱れ撃ち」のルーンを装備できるキャラいなくない？
→最後に仲間になるキャラが装備できた。
　ただ、固有技のほうが強くて「乱れ撃ち」を持たせる意味が
　あまりないような…

・攻撃魔法のコスパがとても悪い。
例えば、火属性の全体攻撃ができるＬｖ５魔法、
消費ＭＰは125で、ラスダンのザコはワンパンできる。
筆者のクリア時点での魔法使い系キャラのＭＰが421である。
ザコ相手に３発でガス欠になるのだ。
このゲームはダンジョン内に回復ポイントが存在しない＆
それぞれのダンジョンが比較的広いため、
プレイヤーはボスに至るまでＭＰを節約せざるを得ず、
ザコ戦で魔法をぶっ放している余裕などはない。
プレイヤーは敵を物理で粉砕し、
ＭＰは回復にのみ粛々と利用することになる。
つまるところ、攻撃魔法は空気である。
消費MPが半分でもいいんじゃないかと思う。

・英雄コンボが弱い
発動メンバー全員がスキル使って殴るのとほぼ同じ、
下手すると威力で負ける。
メンバー限定になるのだから、
威力が現在の1.5倍くらいあってもいいと思う。

・サポートキャラのサポート演出が余計
戦闘時に効果を発生させる系の
サポートキャラの演出が余計。
戦闘テンポが非常に悪くなり
サポートキャラを使う気がなくなる。
セリフとバフ効果のエフェクトだけで良い。
もしくは演出オンとオフで選択できるようにするとか。

・ベーゴマ
コマ本体の性能でほぼ勝ち負けが決まる。
プレイヤーの介在できる部分が少なすぎる。
もっとパーツとか改造とかいろいろあるでしょ？
３本勝負なのもテンポがわるい。
だいたい強いコマを手に入れる方法が
敵からのドロップって…ベーゴマ勝負する意味は…

・釣り
魚が掛かったらボタンを押すだけ。ゲー無。
魚を釣ること自体のメリットが少なすぎる。
魚をポイントに変換できて
アイテムと交換可能とかできなかったかな…？

・料理対決
せっかく「前菜」+「メイン」+「デザート」になっているのに
料理ごとの組み合わせでのコンボ効果とかは
全く考慮されていない。
審査員の好みですべてが判断される。
審査員が味音痴すぎて相手の料理人がかわいそうになってくる。
※すごい料理人のはずなのに、60点満点で11点とか…
あとボタン連打させるのやめろ。

・戦争
だいたいどうやっても勝つようにできていてイベント戦に近い。
１エリアに入れるのが３部隊までなので

2024/04/26時点

13時間ほどプレイ。
最初の戦争イベントを終わらせて、
序盤を抜けたくらいと思われる。
Lvは35ほど。

幻想水滸伝はⅠ～Ⅳまでプレイ済。
名作ＲＰＧ「幻想水滸伝Ⅱ」の
精神的後継として開発されたとのことで、
大きく期待を寄せられていた作品のようで、
先に公開されていた外伝的作品
「百英雄伝rising」をセールの際に購入し、
思いのほか面白かったことからこちらも期待があった。

プレイしてみた感想は、
幻想水滸伝Ⅱが好きな人が作ったんだろうなという思いと、
当時のＲＰＧをやりこんだ人間向けの難易度設定、
忌憚なく言わせてもらうと、
かなり難易度高めに設定された戦闘バランス。

具体的に言うと敵の攻撃が痛すぎる
＆回復に関するリソースが少なすぎる。
味方の最大ＨＰが150～250として、
味方で一番硬いキャラが10前半のダメージの攻撃を
一番柔らかいキャラが喰らうと50とか60とか減る。
前衛よりも後衛の防御力が低くなることは当然で、
そこに文句を言うつもりはないが、
手に入る最高の防具を身に着けてなお、
後衛が3回殴られると死ぬというバランスはいかがなものか。
キャラごとに防御系のコマンドが異なることも
これに拍車をかけており、
防御力の低いキャラはきまって「回避」や
一定量のダメージを肩代わりする「シールド」しか使用できず、
敵の出現数が多く集中攻撃で沈む可能性がある場合に
防御でしのぐことも難しくなっている。

プレイ時点では硬い前衛キャラが
柔らかい後衛を積極的に「かばう」ことも不可能。
仲間の中に「瀕死の味方をかばう」能力を持つキャラがいるが、
そもそも瀕死にならないように立ち回らせてほしい。
※ゲーム中盤に「自分と同列キャラへの通常攻撃を防御する」
　至高の（暗黒）騎士レイナ（謙虚なので「さん」付けでいい）
　が登場するが、
　防御してくれるのが「単体への通常攻撃のみ」で
　特殊攻撃を防げない、
　武器射程がＳのため、
　最も防御が必要な後衛に置くと防御しかできなくなる、
　など、あもりにも使いづらでしょう？
　考えたやつ絶対忍者だろ…
なお、本作には、防御力のほかに、
ダメージを減少させる「装甲値」というパラメータがあり、
通常は盾を装備できるキャラに付与されるのだが、
アクセサリーにより盾を持てないキャラにも装甲値を付与できる。
装甲値付与のアクセサリーは
筆者のプレイ時間で最近でてきたもので、
これを装備させることにより後衛瞬殺はだいぶ減ってきたが、
瞬殺をさけるには、
このアイテムを固定的に採用せざるを得ないことを意味しており、
アクセサリー枠の選択肢を極端に奪うこととなってしまっている。
このあたりはもうちょっと何とかできなかったか。

上記の通り、
ガチガチの前衛キャラを基準として
敵の攻撃力が設定されているため、
中装、軽装のキャラは非常にダメージを受けやすく、
頻繁な回復が必要となるが、
最も気軽に使える初期の回復魔法の消費ＭＰは10。
Ｌｖ30を超えたあたりでの
魔法使い系キャラのＭＰが200前半程度だが、
この回復魔法は使用キャラの魔力に応じて回復量が増えず、
なぜか回復量は40で固定である。
（消費ＭＰ40の全体回復が対象キャラのＨＰに応じた回復量のため、
　回復量40固定はバグではなく仕様と思われる）
中途半端なＨＰで戦闘にはいると上記のとおり瞬殺がありうるため、
こまめに回復を行うと、とても魔法の回復だけではＭＰが足りず、
昨今のRPGでよく見るセーブポイントの全回復機能がないことから、
ダンジョンには必ず大量の回復アイテムを持っていくことになる。

が、しかし、ここでアイテム所持数の限界値の問題が生じる。
初期のアイテム所持数の上限は３０個となっている。
これにはレベル表記があることから、
物語が進むにつれて上限がＵＰすると思われるが、
まずは３０個である。
シリーズでおなじみ「おくすり」枠の回復アイテムは、
これまたシリーズおなじみの６個１枠での取り扱いとなるが、
これを相当数持ち込むことになり、
そこに蘇生用のアイテムや状態回復用のアイテムを加えると
大体１０枠は回復アイテムで埋まる。
拾った装備やルーンも１枠とることになるため、
ダンジョン内でアイテムが一杯になることも珍しくなく、
持ちきれないアイテムを泣く泣く整理せざるを得なくなる。

ここに加わるのが、探索中の帰還の面倒さで、
ダンジョンからの即時脱出用のアイテムはあるものの、
筆者のプレイ時点では街の間を移動する、
いわゆる「ルーラ」や「キメラの翼」的なアイテムがなく、
ダンジョンから出て街までは徒歩移動。
アイテムの預け入れ、引き出しが拠点でしかできないため
取っておきたいアイテムは拠点に預けに戻らねばならず、
複数のダンジョンを抜けて別地域に行くようになると
このアイテムを預けるための帰還が非常に面倒になる。
いまのところエンカウント率を下げるような
ルーンも出てきておらず、
敵とのＬｖ差に応じて得られる経験値が減少するという
幻水シリーズおなじみの仕様もあって、
小銭以外得るものがない戦闘を複数回繰り返し
ダンジョンを抜け、本拠まで戻るという行為を強いられるのは
ストレス以外の何物でもない。
せめて、各地の宿でアイテムの出し入れが
できるようにはできなかったか。

※感想を書き込んだ直後にテレポート能力を持つキャラが加入し、
　移動についてはとても楽になりました。
　また、自拠点のアクセサリー屋を強化することで、
　エンカ率アップ、エンカ率ダウンのアクセサリを
　購入できるようになります。

一番楽しく、そしてプレイヤーを引き込まなければいけない序盤に
最も苦労と不便を集中させるのは、
ゲームが進んで拠点が発展した際の
また、キャラが強くなった際の
カタルシスにもつながるものかもしれないが、
あまり不便にし過ぎて続ける気をなくさせるのもどうかと思う。

また、バグなのかは不明なのだが、
宿に泊まった時に回復するのがパーティメンバーだけで
パーティに編成されていないキャラは回復しない。
いちいち編成しなおして宿にとまるのが非常に面倒なため
改善してほしい。

今作はクラウドファンディングで作成されたためなのか
おそらく出資者の名前を付けられたと思われるＮＰＣが
ゲーム中に頻繁に登場する。
カタカナ表記の名前の中に、
いきなりアルファベットのＮＰＣが登場するので
最初は翻訳漏れなのかとおもったが、出資者の特典なのだろう。
ゲーム開発の難しさを考えると
やむを得ないことという納得感の一方で、
若干世界観が壊れるところもあり、
「なんだかな～」という感想もある。

期待値が高かったことから、
色々と不満をあげてしまったが、
プレイの端々に「幻水あるある」を感じて
なんとか楽しくプレイを継続できている。
きっとクリアまではプレイできると思うので、
クリアしたら感想を修正しようと思うが、
現時点ではシリーズファンでない人には勧められないと判断する。
よって評価については「おすすめしない」としておく。

Toujours en cours de ponçage de jeu, mais jusqu'à maintenant (50h~ de jeu en prenant mon temps), c'est un plaisir. 
J'ai soutenu le projet sur kickstarter, et ait eu le jeu en contrepartie de mon aide au financement. 

La narration, chouette dans l'ensemble, rien qui chamboule les codes du JRPG, mais ce n'est pas un reproche. Le large éventail de personnage jouable et varié est un plus (on peut en détester, c'est pas un soucis, on les échange avec ceux qu'on préfère et on c'est réglé). Certes, certains sont vraiment plus faibles que d'autres, mais le jeu n'est pas assez difficile pour que ça soit un problème (sauf, en difficile avec les options de défi d'après ce que j'ai pu lire mais je ne m'y suis pas encore frotté). 

Pour le gameplay, c'est parfois un peu lent (dans le sens où, aujourd'hui, on veut nos RPG vitesse x8, fast travel dans tous les sens et cetera) mais très appréciable. Et certains choix de design n'aident pas (une clock sur l'apparition des ressources plutôt qu'un rechargement de zone, des personnages qui demandent de remplir des condition qui s'ouvre une fois qu'on les rencontre sans check si ça a déjà été fait avant, du genre, prouver qu'on peut récupérer 3 minerais de fer quand on en a déjà 90 de stocké).

Pour les musiques, rien de dérangeant, quelques pistes m'ont légèrement marqué mais rien de transcendant non plus.

Pour ce qui est des deux sujets qui animent les chaumières en cette sortie de jeu :
- La localisation (que certains voudraient être une traduction), j'ai constaté une poignée de petit soucis, comme un chat qui a le dialogue d'un autre PNJ, un espace manquant ou une ponctuation inexistante à de rares occasions. Je n'ai rien trouvé de politique, je n'ai pas rencontré ce problème que semble avoir 85% du forum steam, de twitter et d'un peu tous les réseaux sociaux AKA "Ils ont wokisé mon JRPG". La seule petite note vraiment négative que j'ai a placé la dessus, c'est un terme utilisé pour parler des forces ennemies, et qui me perd à chaque fois car il me semble vraiment loin de ce qu'il devrait définir (mais on s'y fait).

- L'autre soucis, aujourd'hui réglé, était la présence de bugs, un de recrutement pour un personnage dont les conditions de rencontre du bug étaient très facilement rencontrable et un lien entre temps de rencontre aléatoire et fréquence d'image. Mais ces deux choses ont été fix.

Enfin, si j'ai un conseil à donné aux personnes qui veulent se lancer dans l'aventure, c'est de ne pas hésiter à dormir à l'auberge de la ville de départ et de faire du stock d'objet de soin.

Sur ce, j'y retourne !

I am only 4 hours in and already this is bringing me back to days long past. Days when I would grind away hours playing Suikoden, seeking out every single hero and mini game and figuring out ideal party compositions. 

But more than that? It feels both nostalgic and refreshing. The spritework, the battle gimmicks, the sheer personalities of the characters. All of it would not have been out of place in a new Suikoden Game, yet Rabbit and Bear bring us something all their own. The biggest draw is the Voice Acting. Something Konami tried to do with the later Suikoden games, the VAs in both languages do a brilliant job.

Do you need to have played the Suikoden series to appreciate this game? Not at all! If you enjoy Turn based RPGs, open worlds, and the very real possibility of missing playable characters because you didn't backtrack or explore every last micrometer of the map, then you will enjoy this game! 

Should you? Honestly, if you have the ability to, yes. But only because there are a lot of nods and love letters to Suikoden found in here. 

Final Thoughts: EXPLORE EVERYTHING! TALK TO EVERYONE! BACK TRACK! Never think you are done with a village just cause you did a bit of story.  And enjoy the blood, sweat and tears Rabbit and Bear poured into this brilliant world and story.

I played this in Japanese audio, with traditional Chinese, simplifed Chinese, Japanese and English. I have no problem with the Japanese VA, however the English text do not represent the actual product. Both the Japanese and Chinese text are close to the original. Zippadalips Ohpadamind Shablooey is zip the lips, open the mind, shablooey. 

In the Chinese and Japanese version, it is an enchantation which can be translated to Al Kazam or Abracadabra or even Hocus Pocus. You can google ' 急急如律令 ' it is literally a Taoist enchantation which the Japanese dialogue and text also suggest an enchantation of sort.
Instead the English translation tell you to zip the lips, open the mind and shablooey. I am not sure what is the purpose of inserting Zippadalips Ohpadamind Shablooey instead, probably need IQ 300 to understand.

The other aspects of Eiyuden, is structured like a Suikoden spiritual successor.
You recruit 100+ heroes, bring them to your castle, build up an army to tackle war battles and defeat the opposing army. Even though war battles are just a very small portion of the game, they are tactical RPG mini-game.
Most of the time you will be exploring dungeons and looking to recruit characters. Out of the 100, there's probably a third of them you could bring for dungeon exploration and turn based battle. Level them up and prepare for war. The levelling system is every 1000exp per level up, as you get nearer or over the enemy's level, grinding gives diminishing EXP. 
Unfortunately, there is character tier. In the past, character stats play a smaller role. However in Eiyuden chronicles, you have character with 50 more stats across many category making vast majority of character feel like a downgraded version not worth using. Even in blacksmithing, some of these already OP character gain 4 points of attacks per weapon level up, while there are some that only gain 1-2 points. Even though there are character unique skills and combined techniques, these difference in stats are too overwhelming which makes those characters with low stats less effective in dealing damage. Even the damage they take is like 80 vs 1-20 for a character with 200+HP. So why would you use a character that hardly take more than 3 hit when you have one that hit hard and virtually impossible to kill?
There's party member which hoard 2 character space, deal about the same damage or even less. Would you bring 2 attackers to deal 140 damage per hit with both having 200HP or would you prefer to bring a large character to deal 80 damage while having same amount of defence and 100 more HP?

Spells now costs muscle point instead of it being number of usage for the 3 spells in Suikoden, making it extremely difficult to use high level magic at the beginning. Your MP start around 100, the 3rd magic costs 60MP. At level 36, my mages have less than 300 MP, cast the 3rd spell 4x and run out of MP to even use the 1st and 2nd spell. Because of this, my team comprises of all physical attackers with an inventory full of curatives even though there is a limit due to the implementation of limited inventory space.

Apart from the bad stats distribution/ spells/ large character/ inventory space/ English localization, all the other aspects is enjoyable: the music, mini-game (except fishing), war battle, turn base battle and gimmicks for boss battles, funny follow-up dialogue from dumb choices the protagonist made (not the entire script is translated badly, there's funny moments even in Japanese dialogue).
Zip the lips, open the mind, shablooey.

This game is a love letter to the JRPGs of the PS1/PS2 era. If Suikoden was amongst your list of favourite games, buying this game is a no-brainer since it's essentially a spiritual successor from the same team, made with so much love and attention. I feel like I've been transported to my childhood bedroom without a care in the world.

The story beats might seem reminiscent of Suikoden II at first with the Nowa/Seign and Riou/Jowy parallels, but I promise you'll quickly see that isn't the case as the game progresses. The game, overall, isn't as serious as Suikoden II, but it definitely treads into the world of political intrigue and has passionate tactical battles and very cinematic duels. It starts off on rails, but once you make it past the first big military battle, the game opens up in a big, big way. By the end of the second military battle, the world is your oyster. I haven't progressed the main storyline in about six hours with how much other stuff I've been obsessed with!

Eiyuden Chronicles feels like a warm hug from an old friend. There are so many wonderful familiar mechanics and fun inclusions (hot spring scenes, cooking contests, art collecting, minigames that you can sink hours and hours into), and even if you aren't a Suikoden veteran, you'll no doubt be delighted by the sheer mind-boggling variety that can be found in this game.

Pros:
- There is SO much to do. It's so easy to spend hours on end playing the game because if you get sick of progressing the story, there are minigames galore to sink your teeth into
- It's very well-paced -- I never felt like something was getting tedious (save for the Proving Grounds which I would absolutely recommend a guide for because it's literally a moving labyrinth -- every game has a portion that a player dreads and this was Eiyuden's)
- The battles are short and snappy, and the "Auto" function and the various rules you can set for the AI behaviour make random encounters a breeze
- It's a beautiful game that still captures the essence of PS1 spritework
- The voiced dialogues make the game absolutely vibrant
- The variety of characters is absolutely hilarious and I'm always looking forward to my next recruit
- The castle expansion system is delightful and the castle in general is so much fun to engage with!

Cons:

The Suikoden Spirit is there.., the varied and diverse cast of characters is there..; the town/city upgrade system is there.., the classic feeling gameplay is there.

But the language has been gutted by vile, predatory localization taking advantage of likely unknowing or unaware game developers. Instances of 'did you just assume it's gender?' and 'another muscle-brained chud' have outright ruined portrayals of otherwise endearing, charming, interesting or polite characters. Lian is an insufferable snot, Perry's depicted as a shout-y, scheming rich-girl, adult characters throw around terms like 'farthead' and plenty more.

I've followed the progress and news of this game for years because Suikoden's one of the few games I've held dear to my heart whilst growing up.  I wept when the news of Yoshitaka Murayama's passing spread. And now, I feel disgust and contempt as, after two months beyond his passing, the game is released with such a slimy, disgusting and utterly disrespectful localization brought around by the likes of Brian Gray; who is known for cutting out and replacing 'GeNdErEd' or 'OfFeNsIvE' language and words with more 'appropriate' terms.

If you don't care about such disrespect; go ahead and get the game. You'll probably have a good time. But I genuinely can't recommend this game until either a proper fan-translation/AI-translation mod is released or the developers become wise to this underhanded localization and update it accordingly in the future.

The game is just sloppy and rushed compared to similar products of equal or lower value. 

Examples of sloppy:
- XP Gain boost item does not work
- Inconsistent language conventions "deal x damage to all enemies" and "applies x damage to all enemy". Just weird. 
- There is a cutscene early on where a character joins your party and is also in the cutscene. The character appears in two different positions in the cutscene because of this. It can be avoided if you don't have her in your party.

Some other things that are missing QOL items:
- No battle speed changes
- Slow menus (super slow navigating)
- No smart menues, it should remember which screen I was on so I don't have to tab back over to the desired screen. Wouldnt be as big of a deal if it wasn't such a slog doing it. 
- There's an animation when using consumables outside of battle and again, just a slog.
- Not enough auto battle options (but I just came from Unicorn Overlord so I might be spoiled)
- Can only change runes at towns (no reason for this, it's tedious to make me go back to a town for this IMO)
- No saving anywhere, only at save points (again, just wasting time / progress) 

Some of these systems seem like fluff that is added to give artificial difficulty but it's really just added tedium. 

I think there's a good game here but I'm having to overlook a lot of negatives to get there. I don't think I'd recommend it at this point in time. Hope I didn't come off as entitled in this review. Still going to finish the game, recruiting new characters and experimenting is fun for the time being. I'm hoping unlocking rune slots opens combat up more.

[h2]ภาพรวม[/h2]
Open World JRPG Suikoden-like ในรูปแบบ 2.5D ที่แทบจะทุกอย่างเป็น 3D ยกเว้นตัวละครเป็น 2D pixel art ที่คล้ายๆกับ Octopath แต่มีความร่วมสมัยกว่า เป็นเกมที่ดี แต่ไม่สุด ทั้งในแง่ของระบบตัวละคร, ระบบต่อสู้, เนื้อเรื่อง, UI ส่วนตัวแล้วให้อยู่ระดับกลางๆ ไม่ดีมากแต่ไม่แย่ ส่วนมากแล้วคนที่เล่นเกมนี้ก็น่าจะเป็นคนที่ชอบเกม Suikoden ซึ่งเกมนี้ก็ได้แรงบรรดาลใจมาเต็มๆ เรียกได้ว่าไม่ผิดหวังในส่วนนี้ นอกจากภาพที่สวยงามขึ้นแล้ว ความรู้สึกในขณะที่เล่นก็รู้สึกคล้ายกับว่ากำลังเล่น Suikoden ภาคใหม่อยู่จริงๆ แต่นอกจากภาพแล้ว ก็หวังว่าจะมีการพัฒนาในส่วนของระบบเกม, UI ที่ดีมากกว่านี้ ถ้าใครที่ชอบ Suikoden อยากหวนคืนวันวาน เกมนี้นับว่าควรซื้อเป็นอย่างยิ่ง

[hr][/hr]

[h2]เยี่ยม[/h2]
[list]
    [*]ความเป็น Suikoden like
    [*]ภาพสวย
    [*]ระบบเกมเรียบง่าย เข้าใจง่าย
    [*]มีตัวละครให้เลือกเล่นเยอะมาก (ตามชื่อเกมเลย ก็คือมีเป็นร้อย)
    [*]เสียงพากย์มาเต็ม (JP ดีมาก แต่ส่วนตัวไม่ค่อยชอบพากย์ EN มันค่อนข้างไร้อารมณ์ร่วม)
[/list]

[hr][/hr]

[h2]แย่[/h2]
[list]
    [*][b]ระบบการพัฒนาตัวละคร[/b] แทบไม่มีความลึกอะไรเลย สกิล(Rune)ก็ไม่มีความหลากหลาก อุปกรณ์สวมใส่ก็เป็นแบบลำดับขั้นที่เพียงแค่ซื้ออันที่แพงกว่ามาใส่เรื่อยๆจนสุด แทบจะเรียกได้ว่าใครเล่นก็เหมือนกัน
    [*][b]ระบบการต่อสู้[/b] แทนที่จะเรียกว่า "Turn-based" อาจจะต้องใช้คำว่า "Round-based" แทน คือปกติมันควรจะเป็น Turn by turn ตาม speed ของตัวละคร/ศัตรู ถึง turn ใคร คนนั้นก็ action แต่สำหรับเกมนี้ไม่ใช่ เมื่อเข้าฉากต่อสู้ผู้เล่นจะต้อง command ตัวละครทุกตัวทันที แม้ว่าศัตรูจะมาแค่ตัวเดียว ไม่ว่า speed ใครจะมากน้อยเท่าไหร่ก็ตาม และเมื่อ command ทุกตัวแล้ว จากนั้นก็แค่รอดูตัวละคร action จนจบรอบ และเมื่อถึงรอบใหม่ก็ต้อง command ทุกตัวอีกครั้ง วนไปแบบนี้ ต่อให้ศัตรูเหลือ HP 1 ก็ตาม.. ความรู้สึกมันคล้ายกับการที่เราใช้ auto battle แล้วนั่งดู และนอกจากนี้ยังมีข้อเสียอีกตรงที่เราไม่สามารถวางแผนเป็น turn ได้ เช่น เรารู้อยู่แล้วว่า turn นี้ตัวละครตัวนี้เราตายแน่ เราให้ตัวละครที่ speed ต่ำกว่าศัตรู ชุบชีวิตรอไว้ แล้วตัวถัดมาก็ให้ heal เลย ถ้าเป็นเกม turn-based จะทำแบบนี้ได้ แต่เกมนี้จะทำไม่ได้ เพราะต้องวางแผนเป็นรอบ ไม่ใช่เป็น turn
    [*][b]Hero Combo ไร้ประโยชน์[/b]... มันคือ action ที่เป็นสกิลร่วมระหว่างตัวละครที่มีความสัมพันธ์กัน ซึ่ง idea แบบนี้ดีอยู่แล้ว ตามแบบ Suikoden และ animation ก็ค่อนข้างดี ด้วยความที่มันเป็นสกิลพิเศษ มันควรจะดี แต่กลับ damage น้อยกว่าการโจมตีแยกกันแบบปกติ นั่นทำให้ผู้เล่นส่วนมากไม่ค่อยได้ใช้
    [*][b]เนื้อเรื่องเป็นเส้นตรงเกินไป[/b] และน่าเบื่อในช่วงแรก.. อาจจะพูดได้ว่า ใครเล่นก็เหมือนกันในส่วนของเนื้อเรื่อง บางช่วงของการสนทนา มีตัวเลือกขึ้นมาให้เลือก แต่จะเลือกอะไรก็ไม่ต่างกัน ไม่มีทางแยกการดำเนินเรื่อง เลยทำให้ค่อนข้างน่าเบื่อที่จะดำเนินเรื่อง

Antes de todo decir que pague por el desarrollo del juego (kickstarter financiando el Knight edition) y que lamentablemente Murayama falleció en el desarrollo. 
Ambas cosas comentadas anteriormente son el punto de énfasís para no recomendar este juego por lo ocurrido con la traducción.

Soy fan de la saga Suikoden desde sus orígenes en PS1, pero lo que han hecho con la traducción de este juego en todos los idiomas excepto el japones es una falta de respeto a "LOS PATROCINADORES" y al difunto director del juego "MURAYAMA". 

Con esto aclaro que por ser patrocinador (NO PUEDO DEVOLVER EL JUEGO, ME LO COMO CON PATATAS)

El juego a parte de tener políticas de inclusión LTGBI+ / DEI, como poner frases estúpidas en el segundo jefe (GOLEM) al derrotarlo "pero es macho?" (desde cuando los golems tienen género), también tiene una traducción mediocre y paupérrima que ni siquiera coinciden con los diálogos de duración de los personajes y si tienes un mínimo nivel en japones (si has visto anime con doblaje japones + sub español) te darás cuenta que los diálogos no son los correctos y son peores que los de google translator (recordemos que no estamos en los 90, estamos ya en 2024...)

Referente a diálogos duración: Veras textos largos en español, pero los personajes dirán 2 palabras en japones
Diálogos incorrectos: las conversaciones no coinciden con las intenciones del personaje 
Diálogos in concluyentes con las acciones: tras resolver el primer puzzle de la primera mazmorra el lobo te pregunta (necesitas ayuda?). Ayuda en que... si ya resolví el puzzle a eso sumado lo anteriormente mencionado

Otro caso son las expresiones de movimiento con las intenciones de los personajes
Ejemplo: Frota frota y no se que / vamos vamos vamos (inseguridad al mostrar la runa).

También incluso hay textos que ni se tradujeron al español y se quedaron al ingles como la estatua del agua que se encuentra en la ciudad después de matar al Golem (cuando te mandan la tarea de reclutar personajes en la taberna)

Lo dicho, recomendare este juego cuando un grupo de traductores traduzcan el juego correctamente como tenia Murayama escrito en el guion, cuando eso ocurra editare esta reseña y pondré el enlace a la traducción ya que me parece una falta de respeto enorme que la obra de este señor que ya no esta entre nosotros se distribuya así de mal en todos los países (excepto en japón - idioma nativo) sin respetar su obra original en la que le dedicó tanto tiempo a su desarrollo.

Por lo demás el juego me parece bien cuidado y se nota que Murayama hizo su mejor esfuerzo en complacernos, pero la editora 505 Games se paso la traducción por el arco del triunfo sin respetar la obra original y faltando le el respeto también a los patrocinadores del proyecto (yo inclusive) que pusieron dinero de manera anticipada (4 años atras) y que querían disfrutar de un JRPG a la vieja escuela.

[h1]Summary List:[/h1]
[h3]Pros[/h3]
- Combat
- Music
- Characters
- Story
- Visuals
- Duels
- Base
- Minigames
- Voice Over

[h3]Mixed[/h3]
- War Battles
- Localization

[h3]Cons[/h3]
- Background Image for Towns and Outdoor Dungeons.
- Party/Item Management Menu
- Some Missing QoL features


[h2]Pros:[/h2]

[b]Combat -[/b] Combat is fantastic. Always have loved the 6 team parties, the front/back row set up, hero combos*, and rune system. Playing on hard, and not grinding levels, has led to having some difficult boss fights that require using all the combat mechanics except hero combos.  Yes, random encounters will devolve into using auto-combat. But outside of souls-like games, I have never had "difficult" random encounters or trash mobs. Some of the rare random encounters will act like mini-bosses and auto will not be good enough unless you are overlevelled. *Only complaint is hero combos do not seem worth it unless they heal or buff. Damage on them seems bugged.

[b]Music -[/b] The music is top notch. They do a great job at using it with the main story. The only thing I want from the music, is even more of it! Not really music but the only thing I would critique in the sound category is that they could have used some more ambient/background noise in places. Like tavern sounds, city bustle, nature noises, applause, or sounds of cheers. 

[b]Characters -[/b] The characters are great. Very distinct, anime-like personalities. I struggle with deciding who to use in my party cause I like so many of them. There are even characters that I thought I was going to not like off first impression and then came to really like them. Whether that is from story moments or use in combat. As someone who loved Suikoden series, I can already see some of these optional side characters continuing their stories in any hopeful sequel. 

[b]Story -[/b] The main story is very solid and interesting. Having trouble on what to say without spoilers. I highly enjoyed it. Looking forward to learning more of the world in a hopeful sequel. Love all the nods to the Suikoden series and there are quite a bit. My main critique about the story would be its pacing. A lot of events just happen back to back it feels. Some events are stated to happen in incredibly fast amounts of time early on. I felt like this could be handled better with more hints at what your enemies, allies, or strategist is up to.  

[b]Visuals -[/b] The characters, enemies, and animations are fantastic. I have always thought the Suikoden 2D visuals were some of the best. These are just more defined and beautifully animated for the modern era. The 3D dungeons and towns are good but clearly give a feel of older generation; probably a limitation of developing for Switch too. Have surprisingly caught myself though finding a blend of the superb 2D characters and the 3D world still giving me multiple eye catching moments. Main critique: The background image in towns/outdoor dungeons.

[b]Duels -[/b] Duels return from Suikoden and are just as fun. The story moments and animations are great. Do wish they used them more for recruiting too.

[b]Base -[/b] Base building system is solid, fun progression. More interaction with building up the place compared to Suikoden games. You can quickly build passive resource generation early on that will take care of the vast majority of your needs. Only thing I would change is that I wish our base was one of the Runebarrows. Would have made it more aesthetically distinct. 

[b]Minigames -[/b] Minigames have been enjoyable. The Theatre is by far the best with you being able to slot any recruitable character into roles with vast majority of it fully voiced. Hot spring is typical Suikoden. Card game is really solid. Beigoma is not for me but was able to enjoy its side-story. Eggracing is decent enough for what it is. Really enjoy the cooking side-story but sadly the cooking mini-game has been outright bugged since release. Easy to win but not working properly. Main issue: All the games could use more polish/QoL.

[b]Voice Over -[/b] Most of the voice over work is great. Japanese voice over will have some notable credits for anime fans. English voice over is also good for the most part. Had many favorites. I enjoy the use of different accents to bring characters to life. With that said, there are also english ones that feel like they are not so good or the voice doesn't fit the character. 


[h2]Mixed:[/h2]

[b]War Battles -[/b] War battles are alright. I preferred the more Fire Emblem-lite system from Suikoden 2. These ones play out more like a basic version of Total War fights, without the RTS. It is more obvious they are 

[b]Age Rating/Localization -[/b] Has some clear issues in places but overall negativity blown way out of proportion. From what I have seen though is that the main story itself is the same. Outside of 1 character personality that seems heavily changed throughout, it is just certain random moments with some characters will seem super off and out of nowhere. A lot of the G-PG insults come from the game itself going for a E10 rating, which just takes you out of the moment when these adults are using 5-10yr old language. Most people would not blink at the dialogue if it was using insults age appropriate to the character. 


[h2]Cons:[/h2]

[b]Background Image -[/b] In towns and outdoor dungeons the background image uses 3D terrain models with very little texture or detail. The low detailed background only works when you do your best to hide or ignore it. But you will sometimes get these outdoor pan out shots, and the background becomes apparent to you. Worst is probably if you go to the top of your castle for the scenic view, and it just green and brown shapes with no detail. 

[b]Party/Item Management Menu -[/b] The general menu you will be opening and using the most, for party and item management, is very clunky to use. Takes a good while to get somewhat used to it. Still always catch myself fumbling through it. Will say that I feel that the menus for stores, mini-games, and other home base stuff is mostly done well. Warehouse could use a sort option.

[b] Other Thoughts -[/b] There are some other QoL things I find a little frustrating the game lacks but might get updated. This is my list of things as of May 9th 2024:  

1. Game [i]NEEDS[/i] a Help page that details what each stat does. Power, Magic, Phys Def, and Magic Def are obvious. But what exactly does Skill, Speed, and Luck affect? Nothing in-game tells you at all. As well as character elemental affinity added to their status page so people know what magic they have bonuses or negatives with.

2. Game could really benefit from a side-quest log for recruitment. Sometimes you might forget what someone wanted and its annoying that you have to google and hope for no spoilers or go all the way to them just to be reminded. 

3. All mini-games could desperately benefit from a pass of polish. Nothing wrong with the games themselves. Things like winning 2/3 beigoma ends the match instead of having to play a 3rd pointless round. Speeding up the animation placement of cards or switching of turns in the card game to make matches go by at a better pace. Fix joystick controls for shi'ark racing. Or cooking not bugged. 

4. Epilogue slides need to be slowed down. Hard to read. 



Overall, I love the game. Been waiting for this for so long. I am happy to have the spirit of the Suikoden franchise return. A franchise that was so dear to my heart growing up. Eiyuden is a world that has felt instantly familiar to me. I greatly enjoyed it. Hope there will be a sequel. 

Cheers Rabbit & Bear!

If you are a relic like me, you probably feel like games have gone from creative art form to monetization engine. This game aims to remind you of the great before times, but it also reminds you how much you've grown to enjoy certain quality of life features. 

The graphics and music are excellent, the story and characters are good, the voice acting is varying in quality. I really enjoy Garr who sounds like store brand Steve Blum, and of course Francesca is a treat (I get the feeling they had to heavily censor her to make the game kid/nintendo friendly). I really enjoy the front and back row system of this game and hope some of the later abilities utilize them in interesting ways. 

A pretty common staple of old games is the wild west difficulty imbalance which feels present here, ranging from pushover easy to Spy Bot (You'll see) hard. I enjoy needing to manage Hp and Mp as well as my consumables. The game has challenge mode options built into the "Hard" difficulty, but you can also change individual settings like enemy AI, no money from battles, stores cost more, and more. You can't adjust difficulty after you start the game.

I don't need every game to have fast travel, but with how often i want to go from place to place, it would certainly help with all the back tracking. I want to recruit all the characters so naturally after every story beat I'm doubling back to make sure there isn't something or someone i missed. I heard someone claim the spot right before the last quest i did was the 10 hour mark, my play time is 19 hours currently with about 5 to 8 hours being dedicated to back tracking. 

Requiring save points to go to bed for work the next day makes me feel extra old and tired.

Edit: Fast travel is acquired at a place called Hishan (Spelling may be slightly wrong) so don't spend too much time early worrying

I'll write a full legit review for this game once I've completed it. I just wanted to get it out of my system. 

As someone who works often with Japanese translators, the localization is actually fine. For example, the "rub a dub dub" line that people are complaining about actually comes from a type of phrasing with no direct translations. It's a comedy styled version of someone rubbing something for luck, like getting scratcher tickets. So in terms of localization (which is not the same process as translation), rub a dub dub is actually the perfect fit. A lot of the time when translating, if there are no direct translations for a phrase, you go with something that feels similar. 

It's a beautiful game with beautiful music and art, and if you actually understand Japanese language culture instead of just pretending to, you'll know the localization did well in capturing the characters' and their personalities.

First of all: This is not Suikoden. It is a spiritual successor to that series, and it does follow it very closely - sometimes, even a bit too closely, maybe - but it is its own thing. That said, comparing the two is inevitable. And here, Eiyuden does go toe-to-toe with some games on the series, but never reaches the highs of Suikoden II, in my opinion. However, those are big shoes to fill.

First of all, the plot: It's about what you'd expect from a Suikoden game, but there's a certain innocence and light-heartness to so much of it. It's the same thing but on a different tone. Not that there aren't darker moments - or that Suikoden didn't have lighter ones - but it is pending a bit to that side here. This can be a good or a bad thing to you, but in my opinion, it worked, and it's not that detrimental to the overall plot as some people would expect.

Characters are overall good, and the voice acting in particular suprised me, both in quality and quantity. Not every line and character is perfect, but most of them work really well. The recruitments and plot progression themselves had a bit of a Suikoden I feel to it - it's a bit rushed, and a lot of people join just because they join, but again, it's not a bad thing, just something to be improved on sequels.

This a good base for something great, but some things need a bit more polish. At launch, there were some pretty big bugs, and some minigames needed more balancing. Some things felt a bit rushed, some things needed more work, but... this is a really solid start, and I can't wait to see what's next.

EDIT 1: After finishing the game, I can say: This sure feels like we have Suikoden back. It's not the same, if all you care about is the lore, but it does fill that same void and it hits all the exact same beats. It's amazing how much I loved this.

Quelques heures de jeu seulement au moment d'écrire ces lignes, mais déjà envahi d'une grosse bouffée de nostalgie. Eiyuden se voulant successeur spirituel de Suikoden, on rentre directement dans le vif du sujet dés les premières secondes avec une intro qui, bien qu'un peu molle, mène vers un écran titre copié/collé de son ancêtre le plus connu. On sait directement où on met les pieds des menus aux graphismes en passant par le gameplay, et on sent la volonté d'offrir aux fans ce qu'ils attendaient... avec quelques touches de modernité ou de changement. 
On se laisse facilement emporter par l'histoire, qui démarre (lentement) comme un tutoriel XXL plantant le décor, les premiers personnages et quelques éléments de gameplay. La musique est exceptionnelle et certaines boucles sont déjà du genre à bien s'imprimer dans le cerveau, mais je n'en attendais pas moins. 
Le mélange pixelart/3d est simple et efficace, les décors sont assez fouillés et vivants, et les combats dynamiques et colorés juste ce qu'il faut. 
Pour le reste, le mieux est encore d'y jouer et de découvrir par soi-même...

Quelques bémols tout de même : 
Les dialogues sont parfois assez moyens à mon sens, et j'ai du mal avec certaines voix (EN), mais c'est assez personnel et n'est pas influencé par les guerres traductrices que j'ai pu lire. Si un jour une autre traduction est proposée comme étant plus fidèle, ce sera juste une bonne occasion de recommencer le jeu.  
La seule "activité" annexe disponible au départ (la pêche) qui consiste à un QTE à une seule touche, je trouve ça moyen comparé à ce qui a déjà été proposé en la matière.
Attention de bien configurer la deadzone en activant steam input pour les manettes qui ont du vécu et un peu de drift (vivement un patch).

La plus grande frustration au final est de ne plus pouvoir fouiller chaque caisse, chaque pot, chaque vase, chaque tiroir et j'en passe en espérant y trouver quelque chose :) (souvenirs, souvenirs...)

Here's the thing.  Do I recommend the game?  ONLY IF - Let me emphasize a bit better for those that can't read properly.

[H1]IF - AND ONLY IF - YOU PLAYED AND ENJOYED WORKING DESIGNS' LOCALIZED GAMES BACK WHEN YOU WERE A KID.[/H1]

You're like... wha?

That's all the outrage is.

There are people who hate any sort of humor; any sort of innuendo; any sort of "anime" in their games.  They want the characters to be faceless, generic, no-personality hacks.  Which makes those same people get tired of the game in 10 hours and never touch it again.  Because said games aren't memorable. 

The humor is benign.  It's childish.  It's a throwback to a past era - which is what they promised you.  But in many cases, the outrage is misrepresenting quotes.

If you encountered Bigfoot out in the woods, you MIGHT ask, "is that a he or a she?"

In the modern era...you'd get canceled for even asking such a question.  But what I just shared?  That's what's triggering the outrage you see.  Misrepresentation of benign localization.  There are no crass remarks, no sexualization, hardly no fanservice, etc.  It's Rated E and it shows.  But it also clearly appeals to the widest (non-triggered) audience.  Most under 18 won't care.  So if you're a parent, it's a fine game for your kid.

That said: you care - or SHOULD care - about the game.  And that's why I'm here.   Now that you understand where the faux outrage is coming from...here's my thoughts on the GAME.

✅ [H1]It's NOT Suikoden.[/H1]

This is a fallacy from a lot of people who don't like the game.  They expected Suikoden 6 or whatever.  It's INSPIRED by Suikoden.  It's not Suikoden.  Just like Blackjack isn't Poker simply because they both use cards with suites.  It's nowhere close to Suikoden though.  Maybe 4, but that's it and that's a stretch.

✅ [H1]It's EXTREMELY Throwback.[/H1]
Yes, you need to hit save points by traveling back to town (from the overworld. Dungeons have quite a few save spheres spread out).  Yes, there is fast travel but it has to be unlocked; until then you're footing it.  Yes, there's a bit of backtracking.  Yes, there are annoying quests.  All hearkening back to the foregone era.  They told you what you were going to get.

✅ [H1]A LOT Of Talking Cutscenes.[/H1]

I share this because if it bothers you, SKIP THE GAME.  Because there's a lot.  In fact, you'll have points where you walk 10 steps to another cutscene.  It's that bad.

❌ [H1]Uninteresting Characters.[/H1]

Yep - just like Suikoden 3.  Absolutely.  You won't remember 99% of the characters here.  You'll barely remember the story.

✅ [H1]Interesting - But Repetitive - Battle Engine.[/H1]

I remember the first time I played Lost Odyssey and was impressed at a unique approach to battle.  That wore off quickly.  This battle setup isn't bad.  But it's repetitive and the "newness" wears off quickly.  Just like Octopath Traveler, in fact.  There's strategy and techniques and gimmicks and all that, but don't go in expecting some Dark Souls experience or even challenge.

❌ [H1]Inconsistent Performance.[/H1]

It's strange.  In dungeons and buildings and whatnot with all sorts of ambient occlusion and shadows, I can get 120fps solid.  The moment I walk outside?  Fritters up and down between 58-ish and 90, then every so often will stabilize at 60.  I suspect what's happening is a lack of VSync (there's no setting for it) and my GPU is doing whatever it wants.  At some point I'll play with it.  There's also some microstuttering that's more annoying than anything.

✅ [H1]Great Music.[/H1]

I can't say there's any memorable music, but it's great sounding at least.  It flows nicely with the game experience.

❌ [H1]Excessive Sidequests/Recruit Quests.[/H1]

More of a nitpick, there are times you'll enter town and hit a cutscene to hire a character, then the game wants you to follow them wherever and end up in a quest.  It sounds logical, but when you think about how many characters are in the game?  It's clearly padding for the sake of it.

It also suffers from the "Dragon Quest IX" disease ("go kill three wolves!!!..., ah, but wait.  You must use this tactic that fails 99% of the time, oh and you have go at night.  Good luck!" BS)

❌ [H1]I REALLY Hate Inventory Limits.[/H1]

Yes, I know, you get a larger bag eventually.  But there was no reason to have a constraint in the first place.  Even still, it's made worse by the fact that nothing in chests is worth keeping really; so your ADD about opening every chest results in a 3-second pause while the game tells you that your bag is full. It's annoying.

❌ [H1]Relatively Small, Uninspired Overworld.[/H1]

By which I mean, there are areas that look like you can go and you can't; invisible wall syndrome.  The map is compartmentalized and broken up into (annoying) sections instead of contiguous.  To be fair, Suikoden had the same thing going on (especially 2), but they weren't this small.  The graphical detail is also nothing to write home about - this might have been mitigated with 2D-HD (maybe).

Overall, I think it's worth the price being asked.  There's enough here for enjoyment - but again:

[H1]IF YOU DON'T WANT OR LIKE THROWBACK, DO NOT BUY THIS GAME.  BECAUSE THAT'S ALL IT GIVES YOU.[/H1]

I'll start off with this: as a Suikoden fan since 2003, Eiyuden is like a pipe dream come true. I'll make sure to review the game without any kind of bias. The game definitely has its flaws, everything does. If you're putting off the game due to the recent surge of "woke" translation in this game, especially if you're a Suikoden fan, you're missing a lot.

For a game that is trying to appeal to Suikoden fans, this game succeeds rather amazingly, there are moments where it made me think "Wow, this is really nostalgic!" especially with the beautifully crafted dynamic sprite-works.

I've read that some people are a bit put-off by the 2.5D style, but I think Rabbit and Bear Studio managed to merge the 3D world with 2D sprites quite seamlessly. The characters blend perfectly with the world for the most part.

The game has a lot of beautifully arranged music, but this game suffers from reusing music, making it feel generic, boring, and it sort of breaking the otherwise beautiful map designs. It takes away its uniqueness because of that.

The system and transitions...are eyebrows-raising more often than not. If you're trying to switch tabs from "Items" tab to "Equipment", you'll have to deal with some slow transitions and micro loading times that is 100% annoying...or if you want to get to Status tab, you have to cycle through many other tabs before you can get to it. Don't get me started on attack button during battle. The X button needs to be more responsive...

Despite what people say about the English localization, other than a few cringe and eye-rolling dialogues here and there, I think they are doing a decent job at conveying the message of the game, save for some parts where they omitted or changed the personality of the characters.

Having an exact translation could be quite awkward, and honestly the westernization of the game scripts reads nicely for me. Sure, there are some out-of-place, modern lingo being put in the game, but it's not game breaking at all. Some of them managed to get a chuckle out of me.

Also, the part where a character replied to our main character saying, "We beat him" with "Are you sure it's a him?" doesn't feel woke at all. To me, it's more like "It's a giant rock, I don't think it's a him or her." It's only a quip, or a badly written joke at most, and that's not even the bad part of this whole localization issue, yet people made that the reason they wouldn't even touch the game.

The actual issue is actually how inconsistent the translation team translates some of the action tooltip for the game, people need to focus on that instead--even so, that kind of inconsistencies reminds me of Suikoden's translation. Like I said previously, "Wow, this is really nostalgic!"
---
Eiyuden Chronicle: Hundred Heroes is 100% a love letter to Suikoden fans, but this isn't saying is a good or bad thing as a love letter can be either well or badly written.
There are many things to fix and take note of if they want the game to flourish, but considering this is Rabbit & Bear Studio's first time ever producing/developing a game, most of these bad reviews listed for the game are understandable. 


Ultimately, despite the bugs, inconsistencies, and many other problems, I give Eiyuden a "Recommend." Don't skip on this game.

Kickstarter backer about to finish my first playthrough. Overall has much of the look and feel of a certain classic JRPG series minus a few things. Doesn't quite scratch the nostalgia itch completely, but it certainly comes damn close. 

The beginning of the game can feel a little punishing in parts but once you get rolling it's not a hard game on normal mode. Going to try Hard mode in my next run.

Pros: Beautiful art and music. The 2.5D style is perfect for the game. Despite the huge roster of characters, most don't feel like useless additions, everyone seems to have a purpose to serve in the game. Definitely give some of the other combat characters a look over and a try, almost all are useful in their own ways. Setting and lore is engaging and a lot of effort was put into the world building. Story overall may be a little generic, but it works for the genre and gives it that classic feel.

Cons:  Endgame feels a little rushed. Hard to finish the HQ before you get to the last dungeon unless you lurk around and really work on it. Forces you to progress pretty far in some of the mini-games to get some recruitable characters, so if you don't enjoy those it can get tedious. For instance, Beigoma was not my favorite but some people may enjoy it. Some characters come so late that you don't really get to enjoy them outside of NG+.

Overall I give it a very solid 8.5/10. I'll probably replay it a couple times and look forward to the DLC chapters to help bulk things out.

[h2]シールドコマンドは有効に使える[/h2]
コマンドによって付与されたシールドは、そのシールド値のダメージを累積で受けるまで付与され続ける。

兄想いの普通に性格のいい子なのだから許容しよう。
ミランの声可愛いから仲間にしとけ。

[h2]何故、最序盤を回想にしなかった[/h2]
操作方法と主要キャラ説明のためのチュートリアルストーリー。
これが終わると唐突に[i]「そして半年後……」[/i]
普通は「そして現在……」だろう。

序盤は歩け。進め。ただまっすぐ。

ダンジョン.ogg、フィールド.oggなのか？サボったのか？

現代のキャラゲーは仲間加入理由を、ガチャ引いたことに収束させているため誰が仲間になってもいいのだ。

意図したファン獲得という問題
例えばUIにしても、これを開発者が意図していると、これで合っていると想定した場合、購入層とターゲット層が食い違っている可能性がある。
武器は武器屋、道具は道具屋、魔法は魔法屋。
装備は装備せねば意味がない。
かつての古いCRPGはそれが様式美であり現代でもそれらの層にとっては自明である。
しかしながら、現代のスマホゲに代表される最適化されたシームレスな画面遷移に慣れてしまった我々にとって、この様式美は今更も今更。
最早我々は、ゲームウ〇スだのゲーム工〇卜だののような攻略サイトがなければプレイもままならないだとか、ストーリーを全部説明しよう！してもらわねば何も理解できないだとか散々なゲームプレイ状況だ。
あの時代のCRPGのファンならいとも簡単に踏み越えていける問題に躓く。
だが、躓いて思う。そうだった、かつてゲームはプレイしづらいことこそが全てだったと。
このプレイしづらさは、例えばそろばん使用を強制される表計算アプリ。

顧客が本当に求めていたもの

そもそもゲームプレイという無駄を行う無駄に、コスパやタイパを持ち出してはならない。
不便なUIだから覚えるんだ。
使いづらいシステムだから考えるんだ。
意味不明なストーリーだから補完するんだ。
そうやって街の名前も何処に何屋があるかもイベント発生場所も脳直になるんだ。
それを我々は没入感と呼んでいた。
最初はキャラクターの薄ら寒い会話をボタン連打していても、脳直になった頃には感情移入をし始めてしまう。
ロールプレイングしているのにプレイが便利なんて求めていなかったんだ。

This game's slow combat gameplay will have you yawning in your seat, as attacks skills are lackluster and there are hardly any skill to unlock or customization options for characters.
The frustration continues as magic spells cost an exorbitant amount of MP, draining your resources quickly and leaving you feeling powerless.
Running speed is painfully slow, making traversing the game world a tedious chore until you find the necessary dash boots accessory or recruit hero into your team.
To add insult to injury, most heroes in the game are considered trash tier, offering little in terms of excitement or enjoyment. Bag space is limited, forcing you to constantly manage your inventory and make tough decisions about what to keep and what to discard.

One of the most baffling aspects of this game is the ability to recruit kids and have them fight alongside you in battle a questionable and distasteful mechanic that left me feeling uneasy and confused. the eye-rolling and cringe moments are abundant, and English voice acting leave so much to be desired. 

Despite investing a whopping 71 hours into this game, i still can't justify the steep $49.99 price tag. Save your money and steer clear of this lackluster title.

例えば戦闘開始からの入力受付がちょっと遅いとか、「逃げ出した」のシステムメッセージが長いとか、上にエリア移動した先で上押したらエリア戻ってしまうとか、シーン切り替えが唐突に感じたとか、新マップ入るたびに観光ムービー流すとか、戦闘のフィニッシュを当てた後にトドメセリフが流るバグをスルーしているとか、戦争がもっさりしてカタルシスを感じないとか、なんの前置きもなく５連戦とか、フラグを半端に進めた仲間の所在がわからなくなるとか、ファストトラベルを利用するたびに〇〇〇〇のセリフが入ってテンポ最悪とか、そういう細かい不満もたくさんある。ついでに〇〇〇〇の失敗ネタは擦りすぎて寒い。

だが特にひどいと感じた一つはカードデュエルだ。場に二枚のカードが出たとき「リーチ」のカットインが流れるが、このミニゲームのルール上、リーチなどなんの意味もないことは理解できるはずだ。それなのに演出を盛り込んだのは、作り手がゲームを理解していないからではないだろうか。

このような作り手の精神の希薄さについては特に指摘したい

仲間探しゲーなのに、町中になんの報酬もない民家が３、４つもあるのはプレイヤーに対する罰なのだ
上級素材を集めに行って、下級素材が５０個もインベントリに入るのは罰なのである。
最近の木っ端アプリゲーはそういうことをするが、幻想水滸伝はそんなことをしなかったはずだ。

そのくせ、犬猫の名前が一匹一匹設定されていたり、謎の戦死アナウンスがおそらく内輪ネタに溢れていたりと、プレイヤー置き去り要素も散見される。

話も演出も幻水2に引きずられ過ぎである。

Longtime Suikoden fan and this game scratches the itch

BUT! it feels a bit to much like Suikoden 2.
Main hero and Sub Hero finds a Primal Lense that activates for them (Bright shield rune and Dark sword rune from suikoden 2 anyone)
Then main hero and sub hero finds themselves at odds during the war (Suikoden 2 anyone?)
Then they start to worktogether (Suikoden 2 anyone)

But aside from that this is a great game, I just wish they had taken another path in the story rather than reskinning suikoden 2, because i find a lot of similarities between the two, not nessecarily a bad thing.
But I wanted a more fresh story, they also took a bit from Suikoden 3 with the 3 "main" heros even if Nowa is the main main, you sometimes switch between the "main heros"

but as a title to establish lore and build on the lore in the Prologue title Eiyuden chronicles: Rising it does a good job. Even if the main story is a bit Rince and repeat from suikoden 2 (not 100% sure, but felt a bit to much like suikoden 2 for my taste, I wanted something fresh) it is a good story, and follows the old suikoden trope of needing to find everyone but 1 hero to get the last hero (119 before last fight more or less)

Also is a bug in the game where if you ni Darphen talk to the blond female before you have the quest to talk with her it makes you unable to beat the game unless you do the unoffical workaround which I had to do to get it to work, on console you are however in need to restart or load far enough back.

Ultimatly it is a fantastic suikoden spiritual successor, and I can't wait to see more of them in the future.
Now if they could for once make you able to play a Main Hero with a Sword, Shield and Heavy Armor with high number of rune slots that would be fantastic, doesnt need to be that right away but honestly i am tired of the half martial artists wielding silly weapons ><. Rayna, I wouldnt mind a title where you play as a Rayna character (You will get her in the later part of the games, but that look -chef kiss- to bad her rune affnity/slots sucks)

As a fan of Suikoden, this game really feels great.

Gameplay 8/10 : Overall it's great but the one thing that i dislike is actually the rune lens. Many of the rune-lenses slots are tied to the character and rune lenses is not free for all type, making customization very limited. Duel mechanism is pretty hard to master, it's not as simple as old Suikoden's duel. You need to break in Eiyuuden and probably won't be able to won flawlessly. Gimmick is nice addition to the game, but one thing that i hate in early boss gimmick (the one to recruit Mellore). I almost always fail to guess the right one, so the battle take longer.

Music 7/10 : Not the best of Motoi Sakuraba. Sure, some ost were great but most of them is kinda generic and bland. The war preparation music isn't dramatic enough, that's for sure.

Difficulty 8/10 : Play in hard mode, seriously. it's fun. Recruiting is far more lenient than suikoden which many were without any info at all. I haven't play that far but in early game, recruitment seems easy enough compared to Suikoden (in S2, mukumuku's recruitment is the best kind of trolling for sure).

Interface 7/10 : Well, I know that in old suikoden there is no journal of some sort to list quests, but i do think that in modern gaming, we need one. Many were busy with life, we tend to forgot some things, or our progress. The menu is kinda... well, good.. but it's designed with xbox/ps controller in mind, which is okay.

Control 9/10 : It's easy to navigate and move in the map. No issues thus far.

Animation 6/10 : Feet moving too fast in many cutscene were weird enough lol. Some use normal speed, some use 10x speed or something lol. It's kinda inconsistent and just weird, sometimes it ruins the serious moment.

Character Designs 7/10 : Not really a fan of most. The art is kinda inconsistent but i understand that the art was made by various artist so the style is quite varied. Elektra and Maxim are great tho. I like the new Camus and Miklotov lol.

Story ?/10 : Can't comment yet.. i haven't got far but sometimes it feels bland and forced. Like the destruction of Nowa's hometown.. didn't have any impact at all.

That's it for now! Will change later after I finished the game. Happy playing~

経験値システムに関しては馬鹿過ぎて呆れました

・移動速度が遅すぎる
・移動速度を上げる為には、パーティーメンバーの貴重な装備枠を１つ消費してダッシュブーツを装備しなければならない（ほんとゴミ）

・アイテム欄最大30個とかいつの時代？すぐ一杯になって薬草捨てさせられる
・回復魔法の消費MPが多過ぎてすぐMP無くなる→すぐ薬草食うになる→でもアイテム欄最大30個という負の連鎖
・メニュー画面の画面推移が遅すぎ
・同行者なのに道中でパーティ編成不可能というイミフ
・取得経験値アップのグロウバッチ装備してもアップしない
・経験値システムがおかしい

【経験値システムバグの解説】
・レベルが上がるにつれ、同じ敵から取得できる経験値割合が小さくなる（これはバグではない）
・上記システムの影響により、例えば他のキャラより１レベル低いキャラが、次のレベルまでの必要経験値が少ない時に沢山の経験値を取得してレベルアップした場合、先にレベルアップ済みの他のキャラよりも、次のレベルまでの必要経験値が少ないという現象が発生している

【経験値システムバグのイメージ】
■条件：ある敵を倒した際、Lv.2の時＝250経験値取得、Lv.1の時＝1000経験値取得
・キャラA：Lv.2　次のLv.までの必要経験値2000－250＝次のレベルまでの必要経験値1750
・キャラB：Lv.1　次のLv.までの必要経験値50－1000＝次のレベルまでの必要経験値1050
以上により、後からレベルアップしたキャラBの方が、次のレベルまでの必要経験値が少ないという現象が発生する
なんだこのふざけた経験値システムは、いいかげんにしろバーカ

This is more of an early impressions sort of review -- if you're a fan of Suikoden and have been languishing in despair as Konami allows yet another fantastic and storied series to rot in obscurity, you absolutely owe it to yourself to play this game. It is a spiritual successor in every sense of the term, and while there are some gameplay elements I would have liked to have seen go in a slightly different direction, I've been having an absolute blast playing this.

The story is pretty typical fare for Suikoden -- lots of intrigue, betrayal, revenge, and star-crossed bonds of friendship. I'm sure it hasn't developed all of its threads at this point, but it's been serviceable enough that I haven't wanted to put it down in 10 or so hours of playtime. Nowa and Seign's relationship is clearly attempting to evoke Riou and Jowy's friendship from Suikoden II, which is a smart choice.  It's also largely been succeeding, owing in no small part to a great and convincingly sympathetic performance by Seign's voice actor.

The roster of characters is appropriately boisterous and colorful... not a lot of subtlety in the supporting cast, but that's to be expected when you're competing for lines with a hundred other characters. One neat thing I will point out as a veteran of the Suikoden series is that non-story critical characters seem to interject in cutscenes more than I would have expected, which is a nice touch. I can't remember how much of that there was in later Suikoden titles, but it makes them feel like meaningful additions to the party long after recruitment.

As far as the gameplay is concerned... it's new Suikoden, and it's quite good so far. I don't have a whole lot more to say than that at this point and I'll probably update my "review" when I finish the game. In the meantime, if you miss the days of scouring the map for new characters to recruit to your cause and occasionally forgoing the usual adventuring party in favor of grand, pitched battles alongside your comrades, Eiyuden Chronicle is a must play.

I'm a little mystified as to why there are so many complaints about the language localization.  The game has options to have everything in Japanese and everything in English.  Are people playing the game with a mix of both specifically to learn Japanese?  I guess I could see where it would be disappointing if that's your goal but it seems like an odd thing to be given so many negative reviews for.  I've only played in full English and while there have been one or two mildly confusing phrasings, it's been fine for me.  

The writing and voice acting are on par with most RPGs.  It's not as good as The Witcher 2 and 3 which are probably my gold standards, but there's nothing I've encountered that was any cringier than some of the dialogue in Baldur's Gate 3 which everyone seems to find well-written.  As for confusing phrasing, I'll use BG3 again and say that one night Gale asked me whether I'd like to learn some magic to which I said yes only to end up spending a "magical" night with him which I'm glad he enjoyed but wasn't my intent-- dude could have a least taught me a spell after taking advantage of the vicissitudes of the English language like that.  I haven't accidentally hooked up with anyone in this game-- up to you whether that's a pro or a con. 

Anyway-- 
Cons: 
~Battles could stand to be a bit faster on auto mode
~I suspect it's going to be annoying later on that characters don't gain experience outside of the party and I'm not going to want to switch my highest leveled ones out and have to grind the others up, but that's in keeping with many rpgs.
~Few odd places where it stops to load a cutscene only to have nothing of consequence happen in the cutscene-- stuff like when you enter a mountain path and it stops and everyone walks dramatically onscreen only for someone to say "Let's hurry, we've got no time to waste!" and end scene.

Pros:
~Story is nothing groundbreaking and is a slow burn which may or may not be to your taste.  The world-building is solid and fun and I've enjoyed it so far but I don't really expect high art from an RPG story.  I'm a habitual scene-skipper if I'm not into an RPG story and I haven't wanted to skip any yet except those referenced above.
~I've enjoyed the characters so far and there's a good mix of the serious and the endearingly ludicrous.  Saw a couple of mentions of annoying pcs which I assume were referring to Magical Girl Mellore but she seems like a charmingly earnest oddball to me.  Francesca's battle commentary has made me laugh more than a few times.
~The art is a pretty great modernization of old school rpg aesthetics and I've really enjoyed it so far
~Boss battles have been pretty outstanding and fun so far.  I particularly got a kick out of the Kogen fight and its intentional messing about with the tried and true strategy of "kill the healer first!".  Always a fan when an enemy's mechanics play into and even build their character like Yuthus in that battle.
~Supporting this game supports the legacy of Yoshitaka Murayama, who I was sorry to hear had passed away.  Obviously I didn't know him, but the man had a hand in creating a lot of fun memories and a sense of wonder and adventure for a bookish, shut-in little kid like I was and I'm thankful for that.  I'm glad the world has had the privilege of having people like him in it.

All in all, I've been having a lot of fun!  As a person who's first RPG was Dragon Warrior One on the NES when I was like 10 (unless you count "Adventure" on the Atari), and someone who loved Suikoden since the first-- it's a pleasure to play a game that warms some of that nostalgia.  If you're an RPG or Suikoden fan, I'd definitely recommend it.  If not, your mileage might vary but I still think it's well-worth putting some time into.

As a hardcore Suikoden fan, this is an easy thumbs up. It's absolutely nowhere near the high point of the old series, but it's perfectly serviceable and hits the right spots for nostalgia to kick in. 

But there's been very few points where I'd recommend it to anyone else.  It's lows are REALLY bad and it's highs are just pretty good.

The plot is generic Suikoden. Evil empire, encouraged to start a resistance army, face off against your friend on the battlefield... y'know... the usual. I actually enjoyed most of the characters and the plot.

The dungeon design ranges from mediocre to absolutely dreadful. Mostly, it's a linear path with branches for chests. Mostly, it's more forgettable than bad but the low spots were hard-to-see hidden paths, long stretches of boring nothings, and doors locking behind you preventing you from resupplying...

Because this game LOVES to lock the metaphorical door behind you.. and I repeatedly found myself unable to switch party, buy supplies, free-roam, etc until I beat the rock wall that is the next boss/several bosses. After a few soft-lock risks, I found myself afraid to move forward until I was over-leveled and overstocked. This severely hurt the experience.

The combat system is deeper than it looks at first glance, and more importantly deeper than the useless tutorials teach you. It has a massive focus on initiative timing, multiple MECHANICALLY different damage types, unique defenses/dodges per characters, load of options, etc. There is alot here to love here... BUT...

Balance is non-existent.  Some characters are amazing, some are useless, most hero combos are inferior to basic attacks, and I've found magic to be entirely worthless. One of the first bosses in the game took me 45 minutes due to an insane life pool, yet nothing has come close to that since. It's been a roller coaster of difficulty spikes. It NEEDS some balance patches.

This leads to the best/worst part of the game... bosses. Nearly every boss has a gimmick.  Sometimes it's a literally battle "gimmick" such as having a random chance to hit the boss with a powerful attack or avoiding powerful attacks by hiding. Sometimes it's a non-labeled "gimmick" such as the boss countering certain attacks or having an ultra-attack every X activation. Learn the gimmick and you'll win the fight. 

The problem is that too many gimmick fights make me feel like I'm exploiting the mechanics more than playing the game. Guess what... having the characters in the front blocking to avoid triggering the combo just isn't fun... neither is a party-wipe sleep spell before you can buy defenses for it.

This is made worse by many specific battle mechanics that end up feeling more tedious than challenging. Whether its enemies with "Intelligent targeting" that will all target one single hero repeatedly or being unable to revive since enemies will 100% of the time target a revived hero before they can heal... I found myself abusing the systems rather than playing the game. (For example, stocking up on revives to guarantee a wasted enemy action each turn)

Recruiting is fairer than the past games and easier to find heroes. On the other hand it's now a series of fetch quests which has lead to me spending hours grinding for rare drops for each of the different characters. I can understand if it's one or two characters.... but I've had to catch the rare fish, find multiple rare artifacts, find the rare lumbers/irons/bones, etc.  It's reaching a point where things are just tedious. (I've probably spent 4 hours of my game so far trying to recruit 3 specific heroes due to trash my RNG) 

All of my complaints are made worse by bugs in the recruiting, random battle rates, balance jank and potentially other hidden stuff. I've had a few crashes, I've had a few areas where things seemed to get locked, etc. 

I do feel that this review is far too negative compared to my actual feelings... but these are the emotions that are standing out. I do like this game alot and that's why I'm giving it a thumbs up even now. But they still have work to do to make this anything close to a great game. (And I do have faith that they'll put in that work)

##2024/04/26編集
エンカ率修正されてレベリングが十分にできる為、戦闘バランスが改善。
またプレイ10～15時間くらいで移動における不満点が解消されます。
あとは声量バランスが改善されれば文句なしにオススメできるのだが…
幻水１･２ユーザの私が以下気になった点

１．声量バランス
あまりおすすめできない理由はダントツでコレ…序盤１時間以内で遭遇する挫折ポイント。
フルボイスやったぜ！だったのが、没入感崩壊レベルで頻発するのでそのうち恐怖になる。
キャラのここ喋ってくれるんか！？って位に会話量が多いのは素直に嬉しい要素。

２．ルーン周り
幻水といえば紋章、それの代わりがルーン。
回数の代わりにＭＰ消費となった為か序盤は数発しか打てないのはご愛敬。
唯一不満な点といえば、付けれるルーンの種類・数（ステ補強・パッシブ等）が
キャラ毎で固定だという事…幻水ならではではあるんだけれども
ここはもう少し自由度があってほしかったが、即ちこれ不便を楽しめって事。

３．戦闘バランス
アプデが入りエンカ率が修正されて十分なレベリングが可能になったので
戦闘バランスは従来の幻水に近くなったかな？という感じ。
修正前は後衛陣顔真っ青リスキル勘弁だったのが、今は破顔一笑二割から元気です。
レベリングして十分に育ててから次へ挑むのは従来のJPRGスタイルで良き！

４．アイテム回り
道具袋は初期から+10だったら快適だったろうなという印象。
金策は交易があるので割とどうとでもなるし、収集物も復活が早いので苦にはならない。

５．ＭＡＰの広さ
あまりにＭＡＰが広く移動手段に速度アップ装備が必須なので、一人の装備枠が潰れる。
先輩走るの好きだったろ？コレ、あげるよ…
とはいえ探索できる範囲や宝箱が多いのはこれも嬉しい所。

声量バランス以外は許容範囲で十分に楽しめてます！
ストーリーもろもろはこれよこれ！！って位に面白い内容なので！！

Finally it is here!!! As a Suikoden 2 fan, I have been waiting for this kind of game for so long! But, I have only played for 3 hours into the game cuz, now I am on my 30s and I have a lot of things to do (and a lot of games to play!) I am very grateful for this game, but there are some things that I wish were different:

1.  2x battle speed. 
This is 2024, we have become busier than ever, no time for slow battles. Try playing Suikoden 2 in emulator where you can speed up the game. The battle becomes so much cooler and awesome!

2. UI is kinda bad.
Switching tabs is pretty slow. Instead, we need an option page at the beginning to easily navigate between items, party and status faster.
Navigating information in general is pretty confusing.

3. Hero combo problems
"Unite" is just sounds cooler.
It is also confusing to use. Lack of necessary description. Eg. Nowa and Lian's Unite: I did not know that this combo's range is S while they are M. Why? Bug?
The animation of initiating unite skill in Suikoden 2 is cooler.

4. Some uncool characters
Understandable, just like Suikoden, some peasants and commoners, not a big deal, but... ugh.
So we begin the game with Hero, Nanami, Gengen and Rikimaru again? A change would be nice.
Not complaining: Seign is super cool, but you should change the color or something. He is obviously Vergil (DMC) + Colonel Mustang (Fullmetal Alchemist). And his aide, Hildi? is just like Mustang's aide.

5. Add "fun" mode, maybe?
Some of us, fans, are older now. We do not have time to play much like we did in high school playing Suikoden 2. While I appreciate the map and the indicators for next mission, it would be nice to have indicators for side quest aka time to recruit heroes, without secret (or give direct guide on how to recruit them all). It is tiring to play and switch between playing the game and reading walkthroughs. Some of us just want to experience the game, enjoy, and unwind, not become more stressed out. A "fun/easy" mode will be appreciated.

6. Battle UI
Battle can be tiring for first timers. If there is no action can be taken in "lens and hero combo", they should be blackened. I had many occasions when I select the options and skills cannot be used, making battle experience tedious.

7. MP
MP is too costly for small damage, wanna use spells more often.

8. No Luca Blight?
I heard that there is not going to be an intense battle like when we fought Luca? oh no, sad...

Overall, I am still looking forward to play this game, and I still recommend this game to people. However, I hope that some of these are taken into consideration by DEV and some changes are implemented for better gaming experience. ENJOY! and THANKS for making this game!

新瓶装旧酒的一款复古日式RPG，大包300，一方3块，还要什么自行车。

有些评测评测系统深度不行，人物构筑不够等等。
我想说的就是，你在吐槽一个游戏前，起码要知道这个游戏的“核心玩法”是什么，也就是这个游戏的“玩点”在哪里。

就像是你去吐槽宝可梦剧情深度不够、马里奥成人要素不足、地平线系列剧情不够精彩一样，是很搞笑的行为。

要策略全战&文明&火纹那么多大战略游戏等着你去运筹帷幄，要人物构筑暗黑like&怪物猎人那么多世界等着你去发挥聪明才智，但是百英雄传不是的，他就是一个收集类RPG，就像是收集“人形宝可梦”一样：每个人物都有单独的全程语音+精美的立绘，不同的剧情你带不同的队友都偶尔会有和他们性格相符的反应和对白，这就够了，这就是这个游戏的“玩点”。所以我建议有些朋友们吐槽之前，先知道这是一个什么游戏，他的核心体验在哪里，而不是要求猫像狗一样听话，狗像羊一样可以吃草。

以下是原评测：
人物全程语音诚意满满，解密、探索要素也都恰到好处，好消息是，记忆里RPG优秀的元素基本他都有，坏消息是古旧的一些问题诸如进房间读图、人物培养深度略差、背包格子限制等也被保留下来了。
相比圣兽之王还有一些差距，但素质仍旧在游戏里属于中等偏上再偏上。
