The developers of Eiyuden Chronicle had an unenviable task before them; threading the needle of being faithful to the memory of a game series that never had a chance to modernize and creating a modern enjoyable experience that didn't feel dated or out of the times. Whether or not you think they succeeded is honestly more subjective than most game opinions people might have nowadays.

Brought to you by a number of the original Suikoden devs, Eiyuden Chronicle seeks to bring a new iteration of that unique series to people; a jRPG known for it's numerous (100 in this case) recruitable characters, political sweeping storylines and base-building aspects. A style of game that honestly few games have brushed with since then, maybe borrowing some aspect here or there but rarely tried for a full throated attempt. So, did they succeed? I think so. While I have yet to finish, unless something goes drastically wrong in the last handful of hours. I have enjoyed my time immensely with this game. There have been stumbles along the way, issues or bugs and things that didn't quite work for me, but nothing that ever removed the fun I was having or feeling I was getting that was scratching a long forgotten itch I had for a style of game we don't quite get in modern times.

I repeat that I don't envy the developer's task. People clamored and paid money on Kickstarter for a spiritual successor to Suikoden. And people's nostalgia gives them fond feelings and soft criticism that with time has sanded off all the edges and pushed down the more unflattering memories. But if you update too much and stray too far, try to do modern takes on long held memories, people will revolt en masse and claim "no, THAT, we wanted THAT." Just, y'know. The idealized one, not the one that actually existed.

There are design philosophies in the game that just aren't modern any more, like walking five feet to a cut-scene and then five feet to another. Maybe dashing and faster movement is an accessory or character ability.  People might complain about "not respecting their time" But the entire time through, it hit that sweet spot for me. These were the types of games I played and they modernized it enough that while not the most updated and efficient for the modern gamer philosophy, gave me a feeling I have not experienced in a lot of years. 

The combat and dungeons are almost certainly better and harder than either has ever been in the Suikoden series, that's for sure. The above-mentioned fondness sure warms up a game series that was never particularly hard or well balanced. People will complain that so few characters get development or have associated quests or long chains of events, expecting them to be like modern CRPG or Persona social links. I beg you to go back and play any Suikoden and see just how many characters get any sort of shine or even have a reason to join a literal rebel army. And ask you how much development time would it take to actually give the majority any of that? I'd give anything for a team of 300 to write hours upon hours of dialogue and storylines for 50 characters at least but realistically that is not what Suikoden ever was or what it ever could be. People have every right to complain about bugs, but on the other hand, oh my god have you ever played a Suikoden game?! People complain about being anime as heck or have weird tone, but again oh my god have you ever played a Suikoden game? They did voice acting for every single 100 recruitable character and almost every cutscene. Not all of them will hit right but it's downright impressive how much quality VA and writing there is (ignore localization whining, it's the usual suspects). 

The combat is fun and actually challenged me. I found much more than a handful of characters I liked to swap around and play with. Building the castle was extremely satisfying, as were all the mini-games I could engage with (or not). Visually it has a great aesthetic with a variety of environments and designs, if not the tightest graphics which I don't much care about. And while the plot wasn't quite as heavy or crunchy as I was expecting, which was a bit of a let down since they were going for a different tone for this game, I still enjoyed it. Also, making the MC voiced and have a personality was a 10/10 decision.

Other can argue the minutiae of merits and you can get your collection of more in depth opinions on combat or bugs or whatever. Maybe in time I'll not feel the same as I do now. But for someone who played through 2 great but flawed, 2 okay and 1 miserable Suikoden games, this game met and exceeded what I was looking for. A jRPG that feels old, but doesn't FEEL old, you get me? I can't recommend it enough.

I'm  really mixed on this one,  like a lot of people came into this looking for a modern Suikoden. While the core mechanics early on are great, it's got some really annoying issues. One of those games where Steam could really use a middling option.

 While I'm not far into the game so far, the gameplay is great, a classic turn based JRPG, levelling up, exploring dungeons, and even early on free access to multiple little towns and dungeons. The difficulty is pretty good, while never strained I do find myself prioritising targets and bosses actually force me to use caution. (Although early on, even with a full roster the team dynamic is a bit shallow while they're introducing more mechanics)

 The art is great, animation is great. But frequently it seems inconsistent with itself. Turning off depth of field helps a lot as a small circle of focus seems to hang on the screen which can be jarring as shading and details seem to flicker into place suddenly. Textures on 3d objects seem to have a wild disparity, some have detailed 'normal' maps whereas towns can often look flat and like a simple 2d texture was slapped on. The sprite work and animation is great but it feels like 3d was used to expedite a lot of the asset creation. Monsters, bosses and locations feel very rushed compared to the character sprites. It's a bit strange as I feel like if the quality of the 3d assets was consistent among itself, even if some of the clearly more cared for textures were simpler. It would be far less noticeable. There's a lot of nitpicking to be had here but overall the sprite work impresses, but I'd highly recommend turning off depth of field.

 The music is pretty good, no complaints but so far no stand out tracks. I'm not far in as of writing. But overall the music is pretty good, even if it does suffer the JRPG curse of having a very repetitive battle theme that wears itself out. 

The real problem I can't recommend it though. The translation. There's a lot of annoying hammy dialogue that would make a trashy anime blush, and while I do expect some of that from a JRPG (I just finished FF8 again, so I can handle trash dialogue) this really goes into a realm of being obstructive. Everyone talks as if they're a 35 year old Discord mod imitating a 9 year old. As much as this just seems like an insult, I have no fucking clue who or what anything is. Character breaks to make little gender comments, they set up the world to have 2 factions at peace but heading for a war early on, but it's hard to keep track of who is with what faction, because half of the characters are wasting words spouting out cringe, it's like watching someone write for Borderlands but carried away fellating themselves before they actually deliver the expository part of the line. At first when I heard about the localisation complaints I assumed it was a bandwagoning mob. However, there's no sense of character in anyone, and the plot feels second to hearing one of the many "spunky teen hyper fun" girls say something silly. Like being trapped in a room full of myspace comments.

 Compounding this issue is the voice-overs. Although impressive there's a large roster of voices that needed to be performed, the quality is wildly all over the place. I had to turn the volume of voices down entirely, leaving me coldly reading the crowded writing to save me from eating my own head in frustration. While a couple of characters are voiced with some kind of professional restraint, like Nowa, Seign and Hilde, every other character (and there's a decent amount even in a short space of time) make me want to finger fuck my own ears. From the first line of dialogue, I had to sigh, as the first person you meet has that cringey false deep voice that seems plucked from a fan fiction read along, before you realise every character you meet is a "oh so whimsical anime" character, over-acted poorly. It's pretty grim. It does feel like a lot of the voice talent was plucked from some cheap anime fan club. From goofy accents, to cringe inducing  repetitive screeches to half of the male cast sounding like a 15 year old putting on a "gruff" voice, it seems to have every voice acting sin in a short space of time. If 505 really wanted to make money, they'd put the volume slider for the voices behind a paywall. It's like the voice director was greatly inspired by stories of the CIA torturing prisoners with bad music and decided to pay homage to that with the medium of VO.

Overall, although I think the whole DEI discourse around this game is a bit overblown, the localisation really does cause a big issue with following a plot driven game genre. Especially as this was tauted as a spiritual sequel to the sadly long dormant Suikoden series, which despite having it's own share of bad tropes and bad dialogue at times, still didn't plague the story or game as a whole.

 It's a shame, as the game itself does have some quality mechanics I'm still keen on getting into, although I am definitely going to be slow plodding through the plot to get there.

I was a kickstarter backer for this game. Supported it from right when the campaign began because I believed in the creators and the product. Unfortunately I had no way of knowing at that time that they would hand the game to a truly, and I mean truly, awful localization team. But look I'm gonna break this down as fair as I can so lets go.

Mechanically: the game is fine. I have no issues with performance personally although I have heard there is some kind of frame rate bug tied to the random encounter rate. Hasn't affected me so its moot. The core gameplay is good. It feels very much like a Suikoden game. Which is what they were going for and what the supporters wanted. Some of the boss fights drag on a touch if I had to be real nitpicky but it's not a big deal.

The art style: the game is visually appealing. Its good looking in many respects from character design to set pieces. You can tell a lot of love went into this games visuals. Pair that up with a generally solid soundtrack and yeah what you have is good all around product in terms of presentation. All good.

However..... the gameplay, the visual appeal, the soundtrack...... none of those things matter if the writing is terrible, if the characters are grating, if the voice overs make you want to turn the game off and play something else. And thats the deal breaker here. And its heartbreaking. Even more so because it seems to be an issue stemming from localization. They re-wrote dialog, and I don't just mean a few throwaway lines, nah, more like entire characters personality sets from the Japanese and it shows through inconsistencies in the writing. And everything is worse for it. It got to the point where I muted the voiceovers because I just wanted to grind through the game in silence rather than hear anymore dialogue from certain characters. Certain characters that you are stuck with for 6-8 hours minimum at the start of the game and can't swap out. I don't blame the voice actors for the most part I'm sure they just did their best with what they were given but the writers really screwed them over.

So yeah. Theres a gem in here. Unfortunately because the localization team massacred the main storytelling mechanism you have to go through to reach that gem..... It isn't worth your time.

I can only imagine what this game could have been if it truly had been made with input from the fans/backers. A real beta with feedback from the players instead of a demo would have made this an instant classic. Instead of an evolution it's just a collection of the worst 90's game mechanics with a season pass.

Things I liked:
1. Characters so far, are all unique and interesting.
2. World map looks nice.
3. Art looks great.
4. I like how the row combat works. Ranged can hit anything, but melee can't target the back since the row is protected.


Things I dislike and feedback:
1. Translation in some parts ruins some of the characters that I have encountered so far. Please be mindful of outsourcing your life's work to groups that deviate from source materials. 
*Back up, folks! I'll handle this one. Rub-adub-dub, open, ya schlub! This was in one my first encounters in the demo and it really took me out of the game. 
2. Garr and Lian VA so far don't really match what I would imagine from them as characters. The Japanese Voices are superior for these two. However, the English Mio is good so far. I am normally not that particular for dubs, but this very noticeable. 
3. Moving camera
The camera should move some during battle, but it's jarring zooming in on each participant on their turn only to select a generic fight option for most situations. Maybe change the zooming to happen after inputting all the commands so we can watch the end result?
4. When the menu appears there is a 4 second delay to just fight which is the most used command since it requires no mp it would make sense that it would be pre-selected.
5. Blurry environments, I get that sometimes the in game character can't see something due to visibility, but it goes a bit far causing blurring of environments.
6. E for everyone rating. Very odd to see a game about heroes, warfare, and villains try to adopt this family friendly approach. I hope they lean into the serious elements in future installments. 
7. Somehow the hero Nowa can do melee attacks from the back row while other melee characters cannot. I get that he's a hero, but consistency is the key.
8. Boss battles depend too much on gimmick's, which started off fun but evolved into a chore. After all of the dungeon grinding I did, it seems strange that a gimmick matters more than levels or gear etc.
8. Rune-lenses, I found a ton of them but equipping them is a nightmare since most characters are very limited early on. With inventory slots at 30, I would have really preferred finding them later in the game so that I could actually utilize them. Right now they're in storage unused.
9. Magic is very cool, but I was unable to use it for 6 game hours due to rest spots being so far away. I didn't want to go into a boss fight with no mp so I just use herbs for everything. 
10. Inn saving shouldn't be a thing. Saving anywhere would make this a much more portable experience. With all the dungeon grinding it would be awesome to just save and come back if you can't clear the dungeon because you have things to do.
11. First duel is lumped together with the first battle making players redo the tedious parts to try the duel again. Players should be able to save after each milestone so the game doesn't become a chore to play.

This is a first impressions review of the game and I liked it enough to pick up the season pass after launch so I'll get down to it.  Disclaimer, this is not a full review since I am still in the early game.  Despite the negative feedback this game has been gotten, I really love it.  Now the #1 issue the game has with the players is the localization not very accurate; however, what little I have played, I have had no problems with it.  Surely, it will take time for someone or a group of someones to make a mod for the game that will attempt to fix that, but nobody knows if it will even happen.  If I can understand the game well enough, then I don't know why anyone else cannot so I still would recommend it.

The gameplay is as you would expect if you are a suikoden fan.  It feels like a suikoden game through and through.  Mind you it has its differences and the first clear one is the lens system which is runes in suikoden.  It certainly works a little differently and each character may have 4 to 8 lens slots, but the lens are categorized and so are the lens slots.  Some slots will allow actual rune magic like what you seen in Suikoden with Fire/Rage Runes, Water/Mother Ocean, etc.  Also the rune charges are now MP costs so if you like to use lot more lower level magic over higher, you can.  Other lens may be stat boosts, resistance boosts, or special skills that may be only usable on certain characters.

Another cool thing is when using auto in combat (much like u could in suikoden) the AI will atomically select commands for your characters depending on the battle planner that lets you fine tune like FF12's Gambit system, but it's not the best thing and I haven't figure out how to get certain characters to use healing magic when needed while making sure the others never use offensive magic.  If anything, it's best to use the No MP use setting and let them use SP as needed and maybe restrict it a little.  You will have to see for yourself.  That's another thing about this game though is everyone has SP on top of having MP.  SP is used instead for certain lens abilities and unlike MP, SP will recharge as combat goes on.

I find the difficulty to be good for the average jrpg player and the game lets you start with harder settings if you desire.  Also the music is fairly decent, but it's not as good as Suikoden music unfortunately.  The sounds are good as well, but nothing outstanding but that's fine.

Overall, I like the game enough to want to see it through the end and the major bugs are planned to be fixed soon so I didn't bother bringing those up.  If localization is holding you back, then I would recommend waiting, but honestly, I wouldn't let it get to me as I still see a nice game here.

I should have waited and buy Suikoden Remaster instead - those are  the thoughts that I've been having for at least the last 5 hours of my Eiyuden Chronicle playthrough (and I have 20 hours in total, at the time of this review).

I know this may be harsh, but this game has so many flaws, that rather than a "spiritual successor", I would rather call it a "cheap imitation". It is definitely partly my fault for expecting too much, but considering who created it and how long it was in development, I think that my expectations for a better game were at least a little bit justified.

What is wrong with it, you may ask? Well, I will try to describe everything that peeves me in this game, although there are many things to list here so be prepared for a wall of text:

First of all, this truly feels like a game from a bygone era, and not in a postive, nostalgia inducing way. I also am not speaking about graphics, because honestly that is one of the things that are fairly tolerable in this game. No, I'm talking about assortment of small, little things that simply annoy the player for the sake of being annoying:
[List][*]Let's start with a very bad menu UI that for some reason pauses every time you switch a tab, making it painful to use.
[*]Then we have a [u]very[/u] limited inventory space that doesn't make game harder whatsover (which was the intention of creators), it makes it painful to collect things in long dungeons. Especially since you can store items from your inventory to warehouse only in your castle.
[*]Things like characters that are not in your active party not getting their HP/MP restored when you rest at inn may seem insignificant, but believe me that when you will want to switch character for some reason and all of a sudden you have to fully heal it, it will get on your nerves.
[*]Having one of your accessory slots permanently blocked, just so you could run in a reasonable manner, seems unnecessary as well.
[*]There are most certainly other small things like this, which I do not remember right now (and more that I will discover later), and each one separately may seem insignificant, but when they are all added up, they seriously lower the enjoyment of the game.[/List]

Unfortunately, there are also far more serious issues. The one that annoys me the most at the moment is an absolute lack of any balancing whatsover. I mean, I've played and love Suikoden and god knows that there were mediocre characters there as well (and quite a few of them). Thing is, not only [i]most[/i] characters in this game are like that, they aren't [i]merely[/i] mediocre. For the most part they are completely awful and useless. Frontline characters with abyssmal defense and equally bad strength (Mio), a character with very high magic and nearly non-existent MP that also does not have any other stats that could redeem him (Leon), and many, many, many others. 

Then, there is a story itself which so far is not engaging in the slightest. I can't come to care about any of the characters so far, especially that after 20 hours, I still have access to only one of the three "main characters" around whom I thought the story of the game would revolve. Not so much. Aside from two very short segments, I didn't interact with two other main characters at all. The fact that the story feels extremely slugish is not helping either.

Terrible english voice acting (and from what I know, translation itself) certainly does not help either, because rather than getting attached to some of the more important story characters, I'm hoping they will get killed off as soon as possible (yes Lian, I'm talking about you!).

Even further amplifying this issue is terrible art style of this game. Suikoden had a plethora of characters from different races and representing different tropes, but here it is taken up to eleven. I have a feeling that 1/3rd of the cast is some sort of dog / tree stump / talking bag, while the next 1/3rd of the cast is some sort of beyblade protagonist / magical girl wannabie / anime character expy that fits the game's setting like pineapple fits a pizza. However, I could even live with ignoring a 2/3rd of the cast, if not for the fact that the remaining 1/3rd of cast is compromised of the most unbalanced / terrible characters in battles...

Now, as for the battles themselves, they feel fun only for a few hours. Once the Suikoden's nostalgia wills stop clouding your mind, you will start to get more and more annoyed by the exceedingly long animations of every attack. Auto-battle does not help to alleviate the issue at all, since you still have to watch it fully. Not to mention that auto-battle has its own issues, where the control of what the character can actually do should be much bigger.

Lastly, there is a music which is actually the smallest of the issues of the game. It is simply... forgettable. Which is a shame, considering that I still remember how great was the music in Suikodens, but it definitely is not as bad as other parts of the game.

Now, this got so much longer than I expected. I apologise for what to most must seem like a rant, but I just had to get it off from my chest. However, if it will save at least one person from buying this game, I think it is a job done well. Unfortunately, I've expected so much from this game, and got so dissapointed that I can't recommend it to anyone, even the most starved for Suikoden-like experience players. 

I actually think that this may be the straw that broke the camel's back and I won't ever try to play again any "spiritual successor" type of game that relies on a nostalgia toward one of the 90s games. Not a single title like that in the last decade has proven to be worthy of my time and probably none will ever do. I would rather stuck to (usually) mediocre quality remasters where at least I know what I can expect, rather than to get my hopes high and then get dissapointed every time with those "spiritual successor" games.

Loving the game so far, pretty much what I expected with some pleasant surprises mixed in.

Combat overall is fairly basic with some varied gimmick boss fights and an excellent auto-battle system that allows you to fine tune exactly how you want your team to fight.

Character design is fun and varied, you're almost guaranteed to find a handful of characters that you'll enjoy playing with and the game allows you to do just that, giving you 3 slots for story relevant characters to accompany you without being a part of your combat team.

English VA is very good and I've found myself waiting to hear all spoken dialogue as a result rather than skipping when I've read the dialogue, interactions have been a joy to witness between companions as a result, characters are also very consistent.

Overall a very good game worth the price. 8/10

Je préviens d'entrée de jeu que je n'ai pas encore joué au jeu, je met cette critique pour mettre en avant un problème qui ennuie un certain nombre de personne et qui selon moi doit être vu par les développeurs pour y apporter une solution.

Le jeu a l'air des plus intéressants, malheureusement il est entaché par des soucis de traductions aussi bien en Français que dans les autres langues, pourquoi? Car tout a été traduit à partir de la version Anglaise, probablement faite aux USA, sauf que la traduction est de base de piètre qualité à de nombreux moments, mais surtout elle se permet des libertés en incluant de la politique en lieu et place du texte original, on est pas dans de l'adaptation ici mais dans du remplacement de texte et de sens à but prosélytique. Et pour ceux qui doutent, une petite recherche suffira pour observer l'ampleur du problème.

J'espère que les développeurs prendront note des nombreuses critiques émises à ce sujet et prendront les mesures qui s'imposent: faire corriger les traductions pour qu'elles soient fidèles à la version originale, et prendre les sanctions qui s'imposent envers la ou les personnes à l'origine de cette traduction qui est à la fois non respectueuse envers les consommateurs, mais aussi envers le travail de l'équipe de développement qui a travaillé dur pour nous fournir un jeu à la hauteur de nos attentes.

J'apporterais les changements adéquats à cette critique si les corrections qui s'imposent sont faites, en rajoutant que dans la plupart des métiers, faire ce qu'a fait l'équipe de traduction mènerait automatiquement à un avertissement voire renvoi pour faute grave, car non respect du contrat signé avec le client.

To address some concerns I've seen in negative comments:

Can the dialogue be corny sometimes?
Yes, but it has charm.  I personally wouldn't use any other words than corny for some of the sections of dialogue.  Pretty much if it's a serious time, it's serious writing.  But if it's a general "let's explore the world" type of time, then sure you can get some corny bits thrown in.

Can the voice actors grate on your nerves sometimes?
Yes, but it depends on the character.  Most characters that I have come across so far have had great voice acting.  There's only one character I've seen so far that I really don't enjoy and I think that comes down to writing for that particular character more than anything else.  I currently have only seen a fraction of the characters though, so I'll need to update this post later with more information.

Is there some minor gender-related dialogue?
Yes, but there was minor gender-related dialogue in the old Suiko games and such too.  I haven't seen anything "wrong" with anything said so far in the game.  Some people are way too touchy nowadays.

For those of you who played the old Suikoden games, there are also subtle references to those games in this one as well.  For example, when introducing yourself to a small group of people a few hours into the game you have the option to call yourself "Albert Munchausen III" which is a reference to Schtolteheim Reinbach III from the Suikoden series.  Also when you're asked to name your headquarters, one of the options is Orange Castle which is what Jowy suggested the company was named in Suikoden II.  As you can see I'm only 11 hours in so I wonder how many more little nods they'll add in over the course of the game.

Anyways, again, I highly recommend this game to anyone who enjoys JRPGs.

This upgrades the Suikoden formula in a lot of ways and if that's all someone wants then it's worth a buy. So far the only bug that I've encountered is a defensive taunt not working at all. The random encounter rate is pretty high and the transition from combat back to the world is a bit too slow. The open world is pretty but devoid of even animals or random discoveries. It could use some work. The linear sections do a good job of hiding treasure which keeps it addicting, however. The boss gimmicks and combat in general is well-balanced in that it offers a good challenge in even the normal mode. Unlocking new party member abilities and seeing how well they work together has been half of the fun.

The cast is likable, it's very easy to swap between characters and then have them equal in level to everyone else after only a few fights. Though I wish the gear prep screen let one use auto equip from storage as shuffling gear between new characters is a bit tedious. Still, building up a home base is as fun as it ever was. The voice acting is great, but the constant comedy might be a bit annoying and some players will want to tape Lian's mouth shut. The story has good pacing, it's easy to follow given how many participants there are. They did a great job here and this seems to be a must for JRPG fans. But that's just some initial impressions.

Suikoden 2 is my favorite piece of media of all time. Period. I never saw any other media that was capable of conveying the challenges of friends going separate ways due life choices. How responsabilities conflicts with your emotions and push you to do things you dont want to for a greater good. I only have 1 tattoo in my body: the Bright Shield Rune merged with The Black Sword Rune - so that tells a lot about my personal connection with this game. With that said... i will trace a few parallels of this 2 games in this analysis.

Eiyuden Chronicles is the closest thing we ever got to Suikoden 2. Story is compeling, but I feel that we lack an overwhelming  BBEG like Luca Blight was in S2. Characters are really good. And to an extend, they even have a better characther design than S2. There were a few companions that I never bothered to level up in S2. In this game, almost every singe character I get is worth it.  I still need to finish the game (i am playing in my other account) , but so far I really liked the story. The conflict between a league of nations and an overwhelming empire is the perfect template to a good story. Clearly the author wanted to SUBTLY trace parallels about real life politics, and this is really good. Is done in a non-patronizing/padering way : The way a proper storytelling should be.

However we have to address the elephant in the room... localization really dropped the ball. It tarnish the experience a bit, as much as it hurts for me to say it. Clearly there is a conflict between what the author wanted to portray, and what the translator wrote. Some companions might have a really out-of-characther/inconsistent behavior during a dialogue - just for you to find out later that this was the translator going out of his way to insert a joke or his political view (even when the character it self had a completely different behavior). It is super inconsistent too. A kind character could have 99% of his lines being polite, but out of nowhere he drops sudden accusatory remark or a stupid name calling - only for you to find out that this is not the original script.

Eiyuden Chronicles did not deserved this. You can see this is a passion project, made by people that genuinely care not about their fans, but also MAKING A GOOD FREAKING GAME AND A MEMORABLE STORY. And to see such a beautiful project being corrupted here and there by the vanity of an INDIVIDUAL is really disheartening. It feels like finally going to Egypt and fulfilling your dream to see the pyramids... and noticing that some moron decided to graffiti a political message  on it. . It certainly dont ruin the experience : it 's still the fucking pyramids. But surely does tarnish it.

Music-wise, i have mixed feelings. S2 had REALLY great tunes,  considering the limitations they had back then. EC is a bit of a hit or miss. Some boss battles have great songs, some areas have boring songs. I also was not quite fond of the "gimmick" option during some battles. It kinda drives away the strategy aspect of a battle, and it feels like it is just another minigame. However, I can see people enjoying this... just not much for me. Thankfully, it is not included in all boss battles, and it leaves a lot of room for the classical turn based experience.

Pixelart mixed with 3d backgrounds is simply amazing. It feels like the perfect mix of retro game and modern game. 
Gameplay wise, I am super happy. Boss Battles looks reaaaaaaly good, probably the best looking battles in classic JRPG. Castle management is back and kicking, with all the updated features I would LOVE to have in S2. Cooking mini-game is back, Duels are back. This is freaking awesome. I feel like going back to the early 2000's, in the best way possible. I loved the racing and the "beyblade" mini-game too. The only thing I didn't quite like were the War mode. I prefered the S2 War mode, which felt more like a Turn-based combat/strategy. This is more like a real-time thing. However I can totally understand that a lot of people might prefer this one better.

Eiyuden Chronicles is a dream game for me, and really deserves attention to ANYONE that likes JRPG. I would love if in a near future, they release an updated localization, exactly how the authors intended. If they did, i feel this game could be as good as S2. As it is, EC is a memorable experience, far better than everything I played in the genre in the last 10 years.

Give it a chance, politics aside. And lets hope we go back to simpler times were people were less vain.

Rest in Peace Yoshitaka Murayama. The most under rated name in the industry.

[h2]良くも悪くも「あの時のJRPG」のままです。駄作ではないですが60点ぐらいの佳作です。
正直期待外れでしたが、値段からいえば妥当な気もするのでギリおすすめにします。[/h2]

良かった点は、SFCやPS1時代のRPGと変わらないので、ダメな点だけ、愛を持って列挙します。

[h3]ダメな点[/h3]
・UIがわかりづらい。メニューや店の、どこで何ができるのか不明瞭。ステータス > ルーンの画面とルーン屋の変更UIほぼ一緒なんだからどこでも装備させてよ。
・ステータス画面のウィンドウ切り替えや回復エフェクト後に操作できない謎ウエイトがあったりと、いたるところで操作不能の変なウエイトがかかっていてテンポが悪い。
・主人公の背後のブラー処理がきつくて目にくる。
・戦闘時のカメラワークが無駄に動いて何やってるかわからない。キャラクターが同時に動くんだからカメラは固定しよう。うん。
・マップの移動が遅い。遅すぎる。「このボタンで歩けます」いや、そうじゃないだろ。
・移動速度アップのアクセサリの意味は？　ワールドマップ上にもっとギミックがあったり、足が速くなるといけなかったところに行けるなどがあるならわかるが、なにもないのだからアクセサリなど装備しなくても最初から移動速度を早くしておいて…
・まとめ買いができない。
・レベルアップが虚無。次のルーン枠が解放されるのは10～20レベルぐらい上がらないといけないので、その間はステータスが上がるだけでプレースタイルに変化がない。
・100人いるから仕方ないが、育てる自由度はない。アイテム付け替えだけ。
・ボスやマップのギミックで何回も同じ演出を見せられるのが苦痛。簡略化してください。
・MPの燃費が悪すぎる。
・アクセサリとルーンまで持てる数が30。このせいで仲間の入れ替えやルーンの付け替え、ダンジョンに潜る前に倉庫とルーン屋を行ったり来たりすることになって地獄。いくつでも持てるようにするか、ルーン屋に行かなくても着脱できるようにしないと面倒すぎて仲間を入れ替える気もおきない。
etc

[h3]不便なだけのお約束を律儀に守るのはJRPGの価値ではないです。[/h3]そこは当たり前に配慮をしてほしい。
QAって思った通りに動いているかじゃなくて、よりよくするために何が必要かっていう視点でもやるべきだと思いますよ。
特に移動、メニュー、戦闘周りは、なん百、何千と繰り返すのですから配慮してしたりないなんてことはないはずです。絞り出してください。

偉そうですが、過去の経験や栄光にひたらず「本当にこれでいいのか」を突きつめてゲーム制作をしてほしいです。
ましてやこれはクラウドファンディングで、制作陣も作りたいゲームだったはずですし、あの幻想水滸伝を作ったスタッフならもっとできるはずです。

今作は微妙でしたが次回作はまた買います。期待してます。

Early review:

After 7 hours, I'm hooked. This game has its flaws (outdated systems, eye-rolling dialog/translation choices, etc.) but its merits far outweigh its problems.

As a game that was designed specifically to hit that nostalgia note, it does it beautifully. Limited storage with low item stacks took a while to get used to, until I remembered that I can actually use items! For so long in JRPGs, I would hoard items and just never use them. Now, it forces me to use items that in the past I would just let accumulate. Having to choose all your team's actions at the beginning of the round instead of right before they act isn't my preferred way of strategizing, but once I got back in the rhythm of it and started using the battle plan function with autobattling, it became something I really enjoyed as a change of pace.

The game isn’t perfect, to be sure. I like some of the dubs, but some characters just don’t sound quite right and sometimes when NPCs are speaking, they jump around between accents and it’s hard to follow. The localization has a lot to be desired as well. While I don’t find it as detrimental to the quality of the game as some of the other reviewers here, I do think it would have been better served if it were closer to the original Japanese script. It just sounds cheesy at times and forced. When it comes to some of the other peoples specific complaints, I haven’t really seen them as issues. 

Localization teams and translators are writers. They have to look at what was originally written and rewrite it in the context of the culture they are writing for while keeping the spirit and intent of the original script. They are writing for the masses, not those who have deep connections to the Japanese language or culture. As someone who knows a bit of Japanese and lived in Tokyo for a few years, I would much rather them keep to a more literal translation, but I’m not like most. The vocal group of reviewers who are saying they have no desire to touch this game due to not being tight to the original Japanese script are entitled to their opinion and I agree with them in that aspect, but I can see past that and just play the game in Japanese if I want to (which I will be doing on my second playthrough). 

This first playthrough though, I’m just enjoying the ride. Some cringing here and there, but it’s been a fun one so far! I’ll update this review down the road.

P.S. For those people worried about the “woke gendering of monsters” in the game (sometimes a character might say something like “we beat him” and another character will respond, “Are you sure it’s a him?” To me, it doesn’t at all feel like some sort of political or gender issue at all. To me, it seems like someone saying “That thing is a giant rock golem, how can you tell it’s a dude?” or “I think that monster is more of an ‘it’.”

It hurts me to my core not to reccomend this. 
The game itself is fantastic and Rabbit & Bear did a great job at not only catching the spirit of classic JRPG's but also the series Eiyuden evolved from. 
The issue is, as many others also pointed out, the localization. 
The English localization is already quite lackluster, taking a lot of liberties, rewriting large parts of the script, inserting contemporary jokes and quips etc.
It gets problematic when further localizations are then based, verbatim, on the english script.
Not only does this further dilute the original authors intent, it also has to deal with the above mentioned inserted quips and jokes that more often than not only work in English and the cultural anglosphere.
For instance, there is a prominent example going around about a quip regarding proper pronoun usage.
Said quip only works in non-genrered languages such as English, yet is still translated 1:1 into gendered languages such as German and Spanish.

So as much as it hurts me, and it does so a lot, i simply can't recommend the game like this.
The localization job is lazy and, in parts, downright broken, especially if you're looking to play it in languages other than English. 

I wish the game all the best in its original language and hope that it enables Rabbit & Bear to continue creating fantastic games such as this, hopefully under a more competent publisher.

【2024.5.9追記】
とりあえずクリアして全員LV99、エンドコンテンツもおおかた終わったので追加レビュー。
ソロゲーなので他の人が買おうが買うまいが僕にとってはどうでもいいのですが、今日現在78%おすすめなのに、レビュー投稿を見ると圧倒的におすすめしない人がい多いです。いろんなところで言えることですが、批判コメントは基本的に声がデカいです。その人の環境でしか起きない不具合なんかも書かれています。レビューを参考にされる場合は、私怨レビューになっていないかよく読んでみましょう。
ちなみに僕のミドルスペック環境では一度も不具合は発生していません。フリーズも熱暴走も。不評レビューを読んでいると、たかがそれくらいのことで神経質なのかせっかちなのかと思ってしまいますが、まぁ捉え方は人それぞれってことで。


【当初の投稿】
まだクリアしてませんが37時間ほどプレイしたので感想混じりでレビューを。
先によく言われる不便について、正直ほとんど意識せずに楽しんでます。
【ファストトラベル】中盤に差し掛かったくらいでできるようになります。できない間も行ったり来たりすることはほとんど無く、不便を感じることはありませんでした。戻る際も、序盤のうちはそんな大した距離じゃないし。
【持ち物少ない】
確かに少なくて序盤はちょっとしたストレスかもしれません。が、そんなにお金に困るゲームではないので、遠慮なく捨てて空きを作れば、中盤以降で2倍に増えます。
【ロード時間】僕のミドルスペック環境（RTX3070）でもほとんど読み込みを感じません。長いシーンでも1秒くらい。
【メニューがもっさり】
確かに少し重いですが、オンラインゲームのラグ程度なのでほとんど気になりません。
【戦闘難易度】死にゲーのようなレベルではありませんが、オートでサクサクというラクなものでもありません。考えながら戦っていたら死にそうで死なない良い難易度だと思います。

【その他総評】
最近はクリアに100時間前後かかる超大作や、オンラインで他者とつながるゲームが増えましたが、近年そういうものに疲れている人が増え始めている気がします。アレもやらなきゃ、まだ積んでる、フレンドがやるからしんどいけどインしようかなど、自分の意思ではないゲームプレイをしている人。そういう人にはこのゲームのような、頭そんなに使わない、クリアまで長時間かからずエンドコンテンツを誰のことも気にせずまったり楽しめるゲームはおすすめです。僕は先日発売された『圧倒的に好評』なゲームのP3Rが全然おもしろいと思えず途中放置しています。クリアまで長時間かかるゲーム疲れるんですよ。やること同じでクリアまで延々とそれやるのがどうして面白いのかサッパリ。
程よい深さ、程よい難易度、好きなキャラで冒険できる楽しさ、取り返しのつかない要素がほとんどない安心仕様、ゲームはゲームらしく気軽に楽しくやりたい人には特におすすめです。

I would really recommend steering away from anyone who tells you this game is unplayable because of the Localization, because that's just flatly false. There are certainly some grammar issues here and there, and tooltips that could use a second pass, but the game is entirely playable without issue.

The story thus far is a simple Fire Emblem Blue Lions "the scrappy good guy underdogs are gonna fight the Empire that is being manipulated from the shadows", but it's passable and engaging all the same.

The cast of characters is pretty great, with outright silly characters like an in-universe Magical Girl Team, to your more serious stoic characters. The graphics are nice and stylized and the music honestly has some really great ambient bangers.

Eiyuden Chronicles isn't a perfect game, but it is a game that is delivering on what it promised to be, and that's good enough for me. I'd recommend trying it out for yourself before passing judgment based on some reactionary comments.

[h1]A slow burn that ignites into an impressive flame[/h1]

[h2][i]TLDR: It has its flaws, but it delivers a great and nostalgic JRPG experience nonetheless..[/i][/h2]

It is pretty much what I hoped for, except for the poor localization. I don't think too much about it and I try not to be bothered  by it at the same time.

It is reminiscent of the Suikoden games and delivers a very nostalgic feel and experience all throughout. It's as if I was reunited with an old friend. It offers similar and new gameplay mechanics, a few mini-games, castle/hq building, and recruitment(none are missable afaik). It's not a 1:1 copy as it is a different game, but expect that there are a few hints and callbacks to the Suikoden series. 

The story/campaign is okay, it's just that I find it predictable as it is not as brutal and dark as that of Suikoden games. 
The gameplay is top notch, nothing too fancy, and they stuck with what has worked for games like these. 
The characters, both recruited manually and through the story are all voiced, some stand out and some not as much, and none are missable which allows just about anyone to completely recruit all playable npcs in the game. The banter and dialogue keeps it fun. Balancing could be better. 
My only gripe is that the localization has issues and isn't the best, but it is not gamebreaking in any way, in fact, it adds to the humour that is already present in the game, at least for me.

Overall, it's a great JRPG, and another great time sinker.

但凡有政確的遊戲，我都予以尊重，並學習互相包容。

這個出發點是好的，是高精神素質的展現，是時代的進步。

但過與不及都不是好事，

當事情走向極端，那就是心理病態了，

再更嚴重點就是心理變態，走火入魔了。

本來除了退款，我應該還要再打個差評的，

但考量到這是村山吉隆先生最後的作品，我還是給好評。

對村山吉隆先生的尊重我做到了，但特定的譯者有嗎？

以前翻譯是：

「信」（faithfulness）指意義不悖原文，即是譯文要準確，不偏離，不遺漏，也不要隨意增減意思。

「達」（expressiveness）指不拘泥於原文形式，譯文通順明白。

「雅」（elegance）則指譯文時選用的詞語要得體。

現在翻譯升華了：

[H1]「政」(Political correctness) 指為了政治正確，譯文可以不準確，可以偏離和遺漏，可以隨意增減意思。譯文不必通順明白，但選用的詞語必須政治正確。機翻不是罪，沒有政治正確才是。[/H1]

[H1]不如標題也改一改，改成[B]"百英雌雄傳"[/B]，避免落了個性別歧視的誤會。但雌字在雄字前面，會不會有玩家覺得這也是一種"性別不平等"，我就不知道了。思來想去，最好的方法就是直接將標題改成[B]"百英傳"[/B]會比較沒有爭議。

然後譯者還要分清楚，在中文裡第三人稱代詞：

神為"祂"，男性為"他"，女性為"她"，動物為"牠"，無生命/植物為"它"。

如果翻譯忽略這些，就是雙標，就是跨性別、種族、有生命、無生命、形而上下之歧視，屬大歧視！

我沒有任何要攻擊閣下的意思，我只是覺得閣下可以做得更好。（為避免"你/妳"之代詞可能造成誤會，所以用閣下代稱，而且還上一個檔次。）

「既然可以運作，那就不要去動它！不作死就不會死。」

我猜閣下是不是屬於那種……看見朋友的電腦用了十幾年了，某天突然想幫朋友的CPU換導熱膏，結果換完後電腦整組壞掉。這大概就是我看到的現象。[/H1]

[h2] 幻想水滸伝が好きな人は受け入れられるかもしれない 、が。[/h2]
幻想水滸伝1と2をやっている人は懐かしさを覚えるゲーム。
本拠地システムや隊列、武器適正距離等、見覚えのある要素ばかりで、私もプレイしてて懐かしさに浸っていました。
しかし、懐かしさのフィルターを外してみれば、ところどころに首を傾げたりする箇所が何個か存在。
下に記載しておきます。

・メニュー画面のカーソル移動の遅さ
　ボタンを押すとワンテンポ遅れてメニューが遷移します。ポンポンポン、ではなく、ポン、ポン、ポンという感じ。連打しても連続して移動するわけではないので、苦手な人は顔を顰めるかもしれません。

For a huge fan of Suikoden like myself, immersing in Eiyuden Chronicles : Hundred Heroes was akin to meeting an old buddy I hadn’t seen in ages. Suikoden itself is already more than just a game to me; it is part of the foundation of my journey as a gamer, having Suikoden 2 as my first JRPG. Understandably, I was beyond excited when Rabbit & Bear Studios announced this spiritual successor.

However, my anticipation was met by the onset of tragedy. Earlier this year, the passing of Yoshitaka Murayama was a bittersweet moment for the gaming community at large, especially for those who esteemed his body of work on Suikoden. Despite the sorrow, the hype surrounding Eiyuden Chronicles did not diminish.

So, what about the game itself? If you stayed waiting for confirmation of how much Eiyuden Chronicles is like Suikoden, consider this a perfectly looking mirror with another name. The classic turn-based combat known from the ancient traditions of JRPGs, today, experimenting with old mechanics and bringing new power, embodies them in familiar forms. Nostalgia awaits around every corner – all points work to reflect Suikoden’s charm.

The big ensemble cast – the game has more than 100 characters with backgrounds of unusual heights. The comics feel more detailed and fulfilling, plunging into storms of unwritten backstories. Wilderness promotes excitement and exploration, down to the last anomaly, while the story in progress already includes a return in depth from past experiences.

Nevertheless, not everything is so rosy in the midst of nostalgia and fun. Some slips in localization break the immersion from time to time, and, though such trifles are not critical, they are hardly invisible to experienced players JRPG fans accustomed to quality handling of localizations.

Such lags do not shake the overall picture: so my rating – 8/10 – may be considered quite accurate personally. The previous development of the project is beyond reach, but it was a delicate attempt to create another homage to the idol. On the other hand, my experience was shadowed by the disappointment of some gatekeepers in the community including the shipping issues experienced by the Kickstarter backers.

Overall, I’m having a great time with Eiyuden Chronicles. It’s both a throwback and a perfect fresh start in terms of adaptation, an event that thrilled fans of the genre. Here’s wishing for even more amazing trips to this wonderful world.

Eiyuden Chronicles is on the surface a Suikoden 2 tribute, yet the game didn’t captivate me enough to keep on playing.  

I loved Suikoden 1 and 2, as well as “Alliance Alive”, so I was looking forward to playing this game.

The game itself looks beautiful overall, some people hate the artstyle, but i really love the 2D-3D combination, just like Live-a-Live remake or Chantelise. The Overworld feels great and vivid, and the zones are like dungeons even if they are linear, they have a lot of details that make them feel great. This unfortunately doesn't apply to the first city, where the npcs go by predetermined paths, repeating the same words and no way to interact with them, making the city feel empty. I would have preferred if they were static or with little movement like in the starting zone. And the blur effects in certain environments look awful.

The combat looks great, but lacks the dynamism of the characters like in previous Suikoden games, now every character waits for his turn, instead of attacking everyone almost at the same time as different enemies. Outside of that, the animations are great and the camera movements make up for the dynamism.

Autobattle it’s great, it not only makes the character attack any enemy like the other games, it makes them use abilities and items to heal HP or revive teammates. Combat planning it's just either basic attacks, abilities or items, the only unit that can use magic at first has severe limitations on healing magic, and protection buff, you can only use her abilities 2 or 3 times before running out of MP. Unison attacks don't really do a lot of damage compared to abilities and you could dispatch monsters in one turn anyways.

Many basics QOL in moderns rpgs feels like they were excluded, like saving anywhere (still got multiple save states), infinite inventory space, skippable events, random encounters, battle speed modifier, difficulty change in mid game, and the difficulty itself being artificial since it only inflates numbers rather than giving the enemies new abilities or being numerous. Which is weird, because the “Alliance Alive” fixed those issues on the 3DS. Besides, the multiple short loading screens and being unable to rebind keys, lack of dialogue logs are annoying.

UI looks lovely and vivid, but menu and battle navigation feel completely opposite of overworld navigation. On one hand, overworld it’s smooth and responsive, a little slow even if Nowa is running, but still feels great. Menus feel stiff, once you select something you feel a small but stand out  holdback on navigation that stops you a little. Character portraits on the menu look good, and I’m glad the game added you a section on the menu to revisit the pop-up tutorials.

Music it’s alright, but nothing special either. I didn’t feel like the battle themes pumped me out like in previous games, nor an upbeat cheerful theme like rock rockland.

Those are small complaints that I could accept and say “yeah, a little annoying details, but still a good game” However my biggest problem it’s related to the story and characters.

Story: It feels like they didn’t try at all  to find a way to hook you in the story at first, it feels rushed and discontinuous on the events, doesn’t set a serious tone or something that interest you at first and yet instead to keeping on with the continuity, they jump on ASAP to the next chapter. The story itself begins with Nowa, an almost identical copy of Riou, a goodie 2 shoes that joins in the mercenaries for… no reason? Or at least it’s one of his responses, waiting to know the world sounds better, yet it doesn't feel like a proper way to introduce your main character. We also got introduced to 5 other characters in the process, 2 of them being familiar faces since they are obviously Jowy and Nanami. 3 mercenaries, 2 nobles from the empire and Nowa are on a mission to retrieve a “primal lens” (don’t know the english name, I was playing in spanish) from some ruins that will eventually be useful for the empire. However, they don’t even explain how those lenses work or why they are so important despite the emphasis in this part. After retrieving the lenses, the game jumps 6 months in the future, where you are ascended as an interim captain with the mercs.

Characters: Like I said, Nowa as a protagonist doesn’t really have a motive in the beginning, making you feel uninterested in his adventure, and neither does feel like he has a real involvement in the story. Compare this to McDohl, the son of a general from the empire that is on a quest to prove himself as an prideful soldier as his father, but is then persecuted by his former nation as the new bearer the “soul eater rune”. Or Riou, a recruit from the Highland empire who survives an ambush from his former comrades, since his squad got killed in order to create a hoax to stop a ceasefire between nations and have a reason to invade Jowston, and gets captured by mercenaries working for said nation. Every one of these situations in less than 2 hours in their respective games.

Even side characters feel annoyed and unnatural in the way they talk, not Nanami specially got me on my nerves and just wanted to skip every one of her phrases or remove her from my party. And none of them it’s really interesting since you don’t really know them at all and they don’t make an effort to be interesting at the moment, Mio being just a Baiken cosplayer and Garr just a blunt head kobold captain. On Suikoden 1 we have your 3 retainers and your best friend, each one with different personalities that clash with each other, but they will give their lives for you because they see you as a friend, not as a master. On Suikoden 2, we have Jowy, your best friend who survives the Highland army ambush alongside you and promises you that both of you will go back home with Nanami, and shortly after, Viktor and Flik, 2 of the main characters from the past game.

And let’s address the elephant in the room. Yes, the localization it’s bad. Makes you wonder if the localizers saw the Forspoken script and thought it was the peak of english literature and decided to use the same type of behavior in the characters but more sanitized to make it pegi 12. And that’s why I decided to play it in my native language (Spanish) to see if there was something different, but to my surprise, the Spanish dialogue has the same expressions as the English one. Which it’s disappointing. Why does english have to be localized from the japanese, yet spanish from english it’s a literal translation? Why not do a literal translation in the first place from Japanese to english? So not only is the script disrespectful as it butcher up the original script, but we also have to use the same butchered script for other languages too.

However, despite that, even if the localization team didn’t participate in the script, the game still gives a bad impression of what they are trying to be, a spiritual successor of the Suikoden series. Because the characters don't feel interesting from the beginning. You had 18 years since Suikoden V, and 7 years since the Alliance Alive to review their stories and characters and what made them memorable since the beginning, and this game didn’t feel like it ignited that flame in me of waiting for the hero to continue on his journey.

And I know, this review may sound harsh and nitpicky, but this game is carrying the legacy of 2 great games that are well known for their story and characters. I didn’t want a magnum opus of a game, but a game that at least combines mostly the small things that make other Suikoden games great (story, music, characters, combat, and all since the beginning of the game). Something that I feel failed to deliver this game.

I might probably still play this game on game pass later on, however, I don’t feel this game holds up the title as a Suikoden successor.

So far, I regret buying this early and whatsoever.

I've not finished the game yet, but I thought I would say my piece here considering most of the negative reviews.

I do agree that the localization is a bit strange at times, sometimes being unhelpful or misleading. However, I don't think people understand that localization is about more than translating the original work. It's also about making it fit in with the targeted culture, keeping it entertaining and whatnot. Most of the examples I've seen seem to be taken out of proportions, as I personally just find them amusing. It's also fascinating how everyone who's a part of this is suddenly a Japanese linguist (even though they seem to just be listening to a couple of influencers on twitter, who sometimes seem to be missing the point of the phrasing completely).

With that aside, I'm having a decent time with the game. It's a good start, for a spiritual successor, and it is far from perfect for sure. I do wonder if it has gotten any polish since the backer beta, as it really needs some right now. Most of my complaints lie with the way the graphics look, how slow the pacing and general navigation of the game can be, and sometimes how obtuse the side objectives are.

While the story and stakes didn't quite reach the heights of Suikoden 2 (because it's rated E?), they were still enjoyable. 

The only drawback I noticed was the overall feel. Compared to Suikoden 2, it felt a bit sluggish, despite its more modern technology and it being 60 frames. This could be due to animation speed, particularly in menus and transitions between battles and the overworld. It feels like an easily fixable issue

Despite some rough translations, I've grown to appreciate the some of the localization gimmicks. I felt the bad review are too dramatic, it's still playable and doesn't break the game. However, I find it annoying when the localization alters some of the intended dialogue, few changes its overall mood for some situations (e.g. those pronouns jokes, breaks the immersion). 

P.S. Please make more Suikoden :(
I love 6 people battle system, all the characters are interesting, and the town building mechanics. I like the many different mini games.

Out of respect for the director who made one of my favourite RPG's in Suikoden 2 I will leave a positive review.

However, I really can't recommend this game. Maybe it was the limited Kickstarter funding but this game just feels like a hollow shell of Suikoden 2. Environments are bland and empty, there is very little reward for exploration, voice lines and cut scenes in boss fights repeat to the point of exhaustion. There are very few battle music tracks, the writing is childish and most of the characters are one dimensional. Most of the 100 characters you recruit I simply don't want to put in my party.

There is no innovation here for the genre, no attempt at improvement, everything is copy pasted from better games., The combat has little depth, can't be sped up and there isn't much leeway when it comes to building out your characters. The inventory limit of 30 is also a head scratcher.  I was hyped for this game, but after 4 years of waiting all I feel is disappointed. Sometimes you just can't beat the originals. RIP.

Update: After putting in more time I can say that the game gets better around the 20 hour mark, but the issues I mentioned earlier still persist. When you are 40 hours in and most of your battles still consist of spamming the attack command, you have really screwed up the combat system.

Here is an idea, have a more in depth combat system, have bosses that require multiple 6 person parties to battle. Innovate at least a little. It saddens me that some talented artists spent years working on all these impressive sprites only to be let down by stagnant, boring game mechanics.

This is a very early review, I'm only less than 10h into the game, so I won't bring up anything related to gameplay, story plots, mechanics, balance, character development, etc.

The things that are not listed but available somehow:
- Refresh rate list as 60 fps and 30 fps, but selecting 60 fps will basically uncap your fps (it won't lock you to 60, I got 165 fps in my counter and 100 fps in another PC using another monitor). Tearing has yet to occur, but a game that has a camera movement this slow, I doubt it will ever be the case
- Resolution that goes beyond 1080p, but somehow has no difference.
- Steam Cloud. Not listed in the store page, but somehow available, so if you are not buying because you need a steam cloud, voila.

Reason why I gave the thumbs down (I really hope the devs fix this because this is a solid game)
- No mouse support (PC port that's basically an emulation of PS1)
- Non-invertible (X or Y) camera pan
- Minimap that has no option of fixing to the north and having a light arc on the character to determine which way the camera is facing
- Keybind that's not reassignable (playing on keyboard using Enter and Backspace key, not the best experience)
- No quicksave or suspend option (I'm early into the game so my best guess is to prevent save scumming something)
- No quest list. You basically need to remember all character recruitment potential by memory, or jot it down yourself
- A battle that has auto, but no option to speed it up
- No dialogue log (press A by mistake? your loss, now watch youtube or load the game again)
- A battle phase prompting to proceed to battle without any clear indication of who does what. If you forget, better press back all the way until the specific character's action.
- The lack of option to select your character before giving them commands, you need to give the commands in the sequence of top left to bottom right. Being able to select a character first, giving action, then graying them to indicate that a command has been given is a very nice QoL improvement.
- The inability to speed up the battle report (you know, XP gained, item gained, level up, your stat increase, etc)

I've bought the game, I'm not gonna refund it, I enjoy the game, and quite honestly I support the devs, Rising was a good game that I enjoy thoroughly, but if the devs think they can get away with sacrificing QoLs for nostalgia content, think again. Will definitely re-review after I've beaten the game, let's see if the devs do anything to fix the issue mentioned above by then

[h1] 王道JRPGの１つの完成形 [/h1]

デジタルデラックス版を購入。
４８時間アーリーアクセスで世界的に開始時間で少し問題がおきましたが運営さんがもう少し公式X（Twitter）でも情報公開していれば良かったと思います。会社じゃなくゲームのアカウントの方でね。
アメリカ基準に時間軸を置いていることでアジアでは深夜開始になってしまいましたからね。休日になった日曜日にプレイしたいと思ってたアーリーアクセスだったので無駄になり残念でした。

幻想水滸伝シリーズは周知しているだけでプレイしたことありません。
結論から言うと非常に良く出来ているJRPGの１つの正当進化系だと思いました。
グラフィックやアクションに拘るあまり画面情報量が煩くなったり操作や覚えることが多いよりはこれで十分。
いいえ、こういうのを待ってました！と。
あの頃、冒険でワクワクし感動した”グランディア”シリーズをどこか思い出す…そんな感覚です。

◆システム
また移動の面倒さに関しての話題もありますが私は冒険している感覚を大切にしたいのであまり簡略化されるよりは良いかと。
もちろん現代社会において時間が限られてたりコンテンツ量が多いための割り振りもあると思いますがそもそも時間無いのならゲームしないほうが。。。。

◆グラフィック
3D空間×2Dドット絵という良いとこ取りで綺麗で見易く快適です。
奥行きも見事に表現されていると思います。

◆操作性
操作性は難しいところもなくUI共に快適です。
私は現在、安価で定評のあるLogicool F310rを使用していますが快適です。
コントローラー推奨ですのでボタンさえ足りていれば問題なくプレイできると思います。
一応キーボードでも操作してみましたが慣れれば全く問題ありません。ですがコントローラーの方がお勧めですね。

◆動作性
オンボードグラフィックボードでも綺麗かつ軽快に動きます。
敷居は低いので多くの方が楽しむことが出来るはずですが度々ロード時間が議題に出たりしますのでインストール先はHDではなくSSDを考えたほうが良いかもしれません。
私はロード時間や待ち時間は現在のところ気になっていませんがオンボードの方は数秒長いところは見受けられます。

◆音楽
とても雰囲気と心地良さがあり秀逸です。
世界作りとして大切ですよね！サウンドトラックは仕事中でも使えそう。

◆システム
フィールドや戦闘では様々なギミックがあります。飽きさせずに悩ませたり考えさせたりととても面白い。
難易度はハードで始めましたが途中きついと思ったら普通に下げることが出来ます。その逆は出来ません。
敵が強くて進めないと思ったらレベリングする強化育成がJRPGの醍醐味ですから。
初回の設定で同じように縛りも設定項目にあります。（周回を視野にいれてるのかな？）
戦闘では”おまかせ”コマンドでオートバトルを作戦によって優先行動を決めることが出来ます。
なので雑魚戦相手は楽に進めることが出来ますね、これは凄く快適でした。
FF１２をやったことがある方は理解しやすいと思います。

城や街、村など人がたくさん居ますが必要な場所や人は限られてて無駄な探索や会話などが無いのでとてもシームレスに移動できます。
RPGで無駄に広かったり多くの人に話しかけたり歩き回るだけでも疲れたり覚えるのが大変なのはストレスなので好感持てます。

◆UI
UIは煩いことなく簡素で無駄なく分かりやすい作りだと思いました。
切り替えボタン名が表示されていてよく考えられていると思います。
ストーリーで右下にチャットが進んでいったりMAPも見やすく自然と押し付けない形で誘導されているよう。
つまり演出が上手なのかな？プレイする人のことを考えられて丁寧に作られた感じがします。

◆気になるところ
・時々見かける名前などが英語で翻訳がされていないところでしょうか？すぐに修正されそうですが。
・頻繁に行うであろう対雑魚戦闘において多々使用する”おまかせ”コマンド（オートバトル）は何か１つのボタンでショートカット出来るようになっていたらもっとシームレスに。
・ステータスの効果がヘルプを見ても載っていないのでどこかに説明が欲しかったかな。
・魔法はMP消費が大きいので安易に使用できないかも（ハードだからだと思いましたが難易度の違いは戦闘AIの違いでステータス等の違いはないみたい）
・難易度ハードにおいて敵の戦闘AIはそのターンで倒れた味方が復活した所に攻撃が行くのでちょっとせこい。
（※↑試練の儀式の場のヒュースバインとナルンガード戦では直前の街で預けた物も引き出せませんしあまりに理不尽な攻撃を受けて勝てないので難易度普通でチャレンジしたら攻撃の集中性、催眠からの回復など差異が大きくみられあっけなく勝てました。最初は難易度普通がお勧めかもしれません）
・仲間も選択肢も多いので自由度が高いからこそ装備やルーンの装備入れ替えが面倒なことに。
・ルーンの種類が多いのに装着出来る数が多くはないので個性とはいえ頭を悩ませたかな。難しくも面白い要素。
・個々の説明や表示がもう少し簡略化や同時表示などが出来ていれば分かりやすいのにと思うことがありました。

◆ポイント
・仲間の補充が必要な時は行ったことがない場所など寄り道してはいかがでしょうか？新たな出会いがあるかもしれません。
・ルーンの付け替えはルーン屋や宿屋、もしくはサポート仲間によるポイントで。セーブは宿屋やポイントで行います。（これが議論の分かれる所みたいですが）
・通常雑魚戦闘中にも宝箱が現れる事があるのでギミックを利用して取得しましょう（尚、失敗することもあるので注意）
・私は使用しませんでしたがSteam掲示板で前作：百英雄伝 Risingのセーブデータを配布している方がいるのでデータ引き継ぎ特典が欲しい方は探してみると良いかも？
・カバンの容量は増やせるようです。なるべく早く増やしたいですね！
・上記”気になるところ”で記載した装備やルーンの付け替えの面倒さは拠点の倉庫で自由に出来ます（ここだけ？）なのでキャラクターが増えても困ることはないかも。

◆総評
メインストーリーを進めつつ仲間が欲しかったり疲れたら寄り道や育成などまったりプレイが好きな方に向いていそう。
戦闘も手応えがありギミックや謎解きなど飽きさせない仕様が所々に散りばめられています。

魅力的なキャラクターは１００人以上登場するでしょう。全員集めることが出来るのか、どのような育成になるのか、そして出会いと別れ。
まだまだ分からないことがたくさんありますが久しぶりにEDまで飽きずに楽しくプレイ出来そうです。
ボイスも付いていることで個々の魅力も十分表現出来ていると思います。リャン先輩、メロールちゃん元気で可愛い！
新たな出会いでどんな声なのかな？どの声優さんが担当しているのかな？なんて何回もワクワク。
好きな声優さんキャラと出会った時は嬉しいですね！

もちろん最新のグラフィックやアクション性などを求める方には肌に合わない可能性があります。
なのでどこか懐かしくも新しい完成度の高いJRPGとして十分お勧めしたい作品だと言えます。

まだ序盤なのでもっと進めて魅力的なところを追記していけたらいいな。
久しぶりの時間泥棒さんへ。そんな時間泥棒を産み出した開発者さん達へ感謝を。

This game brings me straight back to the good old days of Suikoden 1&2! So far, I am having tons of fun playing the story and while I can recommend buying the game, here are some details for pros and cons:

Pros:
-beautiful art style
-voice acting is surprisingly good, even the English ones (the THEATHER MODE is genius. Try it out, do it Anakin!)
-well known & entertaining battle mechanics with tons of interesting combos (party members, hero combos, runes, etc.)
-beautiful music
-interesting characters / personalities & story (while being a bit similar to Suikoden 2 in particular)
-low running speed can be dealt with via items and/or support-slot heroes

Cons:
-a bit slow at the start with many mini-cutcenes that can get a bit annoying at times
-the sudden running animations while everything moves at normal speed (e.g. fire in background) are disturbing any immersion and are quite silly/ distracting
-grinding is a bit slow since monster encounters are taking a bit of time until they spawn (good for exploring, bad for targeted leveling)
-some illogical things, e.g. a mine cart blocking a way... climb in it/ over it? Or how running straight next to a soldier makes him not spot you during stealth missions. Or... being wanted and running around freely, even talking to enemy soldiers in cities.
-the running animation when you walk feels weightless. There are no foot prints, no sounds, no dust, nothing. It feels like you would figure skate / slide over the ground.
-cooking minigame is bugged
-magic is too weak and MP costs are too high to use it regularly
-routes are linear & open world feels EXTREMELY empty
-yeah yeah, translation issues are well-known by now but I am not talking about that woke/ anti-woke nonsense. Some translations are outrageously wrong (I play with Japanese voices and English texts). I get it that some Japanese expressions cannot be properly translated since there is no equivalent, but the interpreters went into completely different directions for no reason. One example: In Japanese, they say 'uh, sou da ne' which means 'uh, right' but the English text reads as (paraphrasing since I didn't take a screenshot) 'yes, the three of us will have our backs!'. Makes general sense in the context the scene is presented in but very liberally translated... not the only one but the most recent I remember. Nothing game breaking but irritating and ruining immersion when you hear and read two completely different things.

Love the original two Suikoden games? Well then, this game is for you. If you do not like JRPGs, or the Suikoden series, then skip on this. Eiyuden Chronicle Hundred Heroes is made for the fans, and the developers have made that really clear. 

Sometimes I play games that are supposedly spiritual successors of other games that I loved, and I feel underwhelmed by the spiritual successor. Like I can see how and what they went for, but they failed to capture the essence. This game does NOT fail to capture the essence. It quite literally feels like a Suikoden game. Sometimes I forget I'm not playing Suikoden, and that is a great feeling.

Edit: Oh, I forgot to mention, it's much, much better with Japanese voice acting. Don't get me wrong, some of the western voice actors are okay, and even good in some cases but the western localization kind of sucks. What's bad is that when you understand the Japanese there are times when you read the English and you're saying, "that's not what they said". Unfortunately, there is no option for Japanese characters, just voices, or I wouldn't waste time with the English text at all. All things being fair, I just wanted to disclose that before you decide to buy.

*This review is based on having played the closed beta and 20 hours of the full released game*

It's hard not to constantly compare Eiyuden Chronicle: Hundred Heroes to the beloved Suikoden series (1 and 2 in particular). I've been a fan of the games for as long as I can remember and am one many who've waited for a sequel to Suikoden. Although we never got it, we have be fortunate enough to experience Eiyuden Chronicle. 

- The visuals are truly stunning. Eiyuden manages to combine tradition with modern and does it effortlessly with gorgeous, colorful backgrounds, mixing 2D sprites with 3D elements. 
- The music has been both soothing and epic when it calls for it, creating a sense of adventure.
- My first War battle had me nervous, haha, but I quite liked what they've done with it and can imagine just how epic it would be as things progress with the story and you control more units in a larger scale.
- The voice acting has been a mix for me - there are some I REALLY love, and others.... could either use some work or perhaps have a mute button for, lol. But overall they've done a fantastic job with the variety of ethnicity in the characters and their voices.
- Eiyuden has outdone it with the Castle and the amount of things you can do with it. I can certainly see this giving players hours and hours of gameplay just trying to improve and build on it. Not to mention the sheer number of side things that can keep you occupied (fishing, farming, guild/hunting/missions, card game, collecting all the cards, etc.) A huge highlight for me for sure.

Eiyuden Chronicle: Hundred Heroes is truly a love letter from Murayama-sensei and team to all of us Suikoden fans.

Overall: While it won't set the world on fire Eiyuden Chronicle: Hundred Heroes is a competently made game from a veteran team at a reasonable price point. Even if you aren't a fan of the Suikoden series from which it derives its a solid traditional JRPG in its own right that will entertain you for its forty plus hour run time if you can get past its flaws. A definite buy even at full price, especially the Digital Deluxe Edition which gives you both the soundtrack and a season pass for just three dollars additional.

Pros:
[+] Combat: It might be turned-based but its extremely busy. You have six characters to play with at a time, each of whom will have four to six runes slots, plus combat gimmicks, initiative positions, formations, teamwork attacks and support characters. Regardless of how you play you'll have plenty to do and customize once the game hits its stride at around Level 10-14.
[+] Presentation: While its not Cyberpunk 2077, the game is beautiful; The use of 3-D backgrounds and forced perspective coupled with very expressive and highly detailed 2-D sprites gives the game storybook feel, as if it were playing out on a pop-up diorama.
[+] Music: Both Naruke and Sakurabe are industry veterans with impressive resumes (Dark Souls, Tales of Destiny, Wild Arms, etc) and they deliver a solid soundtrack that is a joy to listen to. Getting the soundtrack as part of the Digital Deluxe edition was a real treat though unfortunately it isn't the Complete Soundtrack, only covering the first third of the game.
[+] Size: Setting aside the plot and the titular hundred heroes, there is a lot to do in the game; Exploration, base-management, a half-dozen minigames and collectibles.

Neutral:
[~] Traditional JRPG: Eiyuden Chronicle is definitely done in the vein of the JRPGs of the 80 and 90s. Meaning it does not have many of the conveniences that modern players have gotten used to; There's no hand holding when it comes to the mechanics or missable content, points of no return/lock-in pop up out of nowhere, resources are always tight, no fast travel, healing is sparse, fights can be unforgiving, dungeons can be really long and save points can be few and far between (Heck you can't even save on the World Map!).

Cons:
[-] Localization: Even a cursory glance at the Steam forums will tell you this is a massive issue for a lot of “players,” many of whom have sworn that they won't buy the game unless Rabbit and Bear redoes the entire thing to be faithful to the original Japanese text but really its just another overblown manifestation of the culture wars sweeping the industry. While there are indeed some Americanisms, like Mio's infamous gender joke or Lian's use of the word “chud”, it does not really appreciably its characters or its story. All told its more akin to Tidus' Macarena joke in Final Fantasy X than the completely unhinged ADV dub of Ghosts at School. Of greater concern are mistranslations that actually impact the game, whether causing needless ambiguity in the game's mechanics or UI and, in at least one occassion, providing outright wrong information (Reyna's recruitment condition). 
[-] Dubbing: Clearly this aspect of the game was remotely done and was impacted by its slim budget because while voice acting for the main characters voices are passable, the side character VA's performances are uneven. Some VA's just can't act or at least did not receive any direction from the studio (like Francesca) while others' have been subjected to atrocious sound-mixing (example Cassandra), resulting in delivery that is off-key, garbled or overly loud.
[-] Underdeveloped Mechanics: While as mentioned there is a lot to do, its pretty shallow. Many of the mini-games are mechanically simple (heck fishing is just hitting a button when an exclamation point shows up) and some of the new systems added like castle-building are ultimately just pointless fetch quests used to pad out the game. Of special note is the War-system which is a definitive step back from Suikoden II and V, both of which gave you the ability to customize unit rosters and unit types while fighting on a large game board with Advanced Wars style special abilities. In contrast the current iteration has more or less degenerated into a scripted shoving match.
[-] Technical Issues: The game has quite a few, mostly borne out of having adapt to simultaneous console releases. Though most have been patched, several still remain to be addressed like ghost inputs on joyticks for controllers, non-rebindable keys on MKB and noticeably slow menu speeds.
[-] Bad UI Communication: This game has a lot of mechanics. Unfortunately many of them are either hidden from the UI or unexplained in the Help menu (they don't even tell you what the character's stats do!). For example, the game doesn't tell you that all characters have affinities for the six spell elements in the game but nowhere does it appear on the individual characters' sheets. So might end up giving a favorite mage a bad element and they end up underperforming for seemingly no reason.
At least we meet again!!! Buy, play, enjoy, and have fun.
